DOC.HEAD: Iran Moves To Curb A Baby Boom That Threatens Its Economic Future
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Iran's government is intensifying a birth control program _ despite opposition from radicals _ because the country's fast-growing population is imposing strains on a struggling economy. ``If the Islamic Republic's government does not implement proper and swift plans for controlling population growth in Iran, future generations will definitely face severe social and economic problems,'' Tehran's Kayhan International newspaper warned recently. ``Can we be proud of a nation of hungry Moslems who have to beg the infidels of the world for charity?'' declared Mohammed Yazdi, a member of the 12-member Council of Guardians, a legislative watchdog body. Iran has one of the highest birth rates in the world, between 3.5 and 4 percent a year. Even in the Middle East, where soaring populations are the norm, Iran's baby boom is fast outstripping development. Before the 1979 Islamic revolution, Iran had about 35 million people. Last`month, the government's chief statistician, Majid Shamshidi, said the population had reached 55 million. Experts estimate that by the year 2010, Iran will have 140 million people. They warn that unless something is done soon to curb the birth rate and rapidly expand the economy, the country faces a major social explosion. While Iran struggles to cope with its baby boom, rival Iraq is striving to expand its population to keep up with the Iranians should the Iran-Iraq war, halted by an August 1988 cease-fire, flare up again. Iraq has about 16 million people and President Saddam Hussein has declared increasing its birth rate a ``strategic duty.'' He offers hefty financial incentives, including cash grants and interest-free home-purchase loans. Iran launched a half-hearted birth control campaign last year, with some religious leaders encouraging Iran's predominantly Moslem population to have fewer children. Now Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has declared that birth control is not un-Islamic, although abortion is illegal. The Health Ministry has announced it has set up centers in major cities to provide free contraceptives. But these have been reported in short supply. Some newspapers say that unless more is done to get the message across, the government`program will have little impact on Iranians, who have traditionally favored large families. The English-language Tehran Times called last month for a media campaign to warn Iranians of the danger of unrestrained population growth ``to bring this immense problem ... under control.'' Kayhan International declared: ``This phenomenon should be seriously and properly dealt with. Using economic incentives, the government should encourage Iranian couples to have only two children.'' One of President Hashemi Rafsanjani's most important priorities is expanding the economy to at least five times its current size to accommodate the anticipated population growth. As it is, western economists believe the economy, plagued by bad management during the revolution and the 8-year war with Iraq, is already severely stretched and needs massive investment just to cope with the current crisis. Rafsanjani's rivals oppose birth control. They believe that the larger Iran's population the greater its chances`of becoming the undisputed leader of the Moslem world. By the year 2020, demographers estimate that the Moslem population will be 2.5 billion, double the present total and more than one-quarter of the projected world population in the first quarter of the next century. The Third World, which would account for more than 80 percent of the projected world population then, would provide fertile ground for the Islamic revolution, the hard-liners argue. When a 1986 census showed 11 million Iranians had been born since the revolution, then-Prime Minister Hussein Musavi publicly rejoiced that they had been raised to the credo of ``Death to America!'' and ``Allah-o Akbar!'' or God is`Great. The radical Jomhuri Islami daily noted recently amid a broadside of press criticism of birth control: ``The problem is not the increasing population, but the lack of policy and planning and in the end it is the unfortunate population that gets the blame.'' Rafsanjani's post-war development plan calls for building 12 industrial cities in five years`to help absorb the swelling population. Tehran's population has swollen to an estimated 8 million in recent years amid a widespread drift from the countryside to urban areas. Officials`say the city is bursting at the seams, with housing, water and electricity shortages, traffic-clogged streets and worsening pollution. Oil-rich Iran was able to feed itself 10 years ago, but now has to import food worth $2 billion a year. Agricultural output has slumped severely. In 1979, one-third of the population worked in that sector. Now government figures show it's only one-fifth.

DOC.HEAD: New Year Brings Social Security Changes
With PM-Social Security Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some changes in Social Security benefits and taxes that take effect with the new year: BENEFITS: Monthly benefit checks increase 4.7 percent to offset the effects of inflation. The average retired worker's Social Security check will rise from $541 to $566. The increase also applies to recipients of Supplemental Security Income. PAYROLL TAX: The tax rate rises from 7.51 percent to 7.65 percent. Employees will pay $765 for each $10,000 of earnings subject to tax. TAX ON SELF-EMPLOYED: The rate rises to 15.30 percent. In 1989, the rate technically was 15.02 percent but the self-employed got an automatic 2 percent tax credit, so they paid 13.02 percent. They lose the 2 percent credit in 1990, but get to deduct half of Social Security taxes as a business expense. WAGE BASE: Workers and self-employed individuals will pay Social Security taxes on the first $51,300 of earnings in 1990, up from $48,000 in 1989. MEDICARE PREMIUM: Elderly and disabled workers will be charged $28.60 a month in 1990 for supplementary Medicare coverage, down from $31.90 in 1989. The decrease reflects the repeal of catastrophic health-care benefits. Medicare premiums are deducted directly from Social Security checks. EARNINGS LIMIT: Social Security will allow beneficiaries ages 65 through 69 to earn $9,360 a year before reducing their benefits, up from $8,880 in 1989. Those younger than 65 will be able to earn $6,840 without losing benefits, up from $5,480 in 1989. Benefits for those 65 to 69 will be reduced $1 for every $3 earned above the limit; the reduction will be $1 for every $2 above the limit for those younger than 65. Beneficiaries who are 70 years and older can earn unlimited amounts without losing Social Security benefits.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Ceasescu and Noriega Mixed Power with Opulence
DOC.TEXT: Four years ago, it was Imelda's shoes that caused the fuss. Now, it's Elena's shoes. There's something about political power that breeds extravagance, a lesson reinforced by the trappings of wealth left behind last week by fleeing despots in both Romania and Panama. When the Marcoses were forced out of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos' shoe collection _ enough for her to change daily for nine years without wearing the same pair twice _ was the talk of Manila. The pattern is much the same nowadays in Bucharest, where Elena Ceasescu boasted a wardrobe featuring shoes with diamond-encrusted heels one day, only to find herself in front of a firing squad before she could say, ``Hey, wait a second.'' In Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega also cut few corners in pursuit of the good life. He had an array of houses and apartments in Panama, France and the Dominican Republic, a collection of personal aircraft and three large pleasure yachts _ ``Macho I, Macho II and Macho III.'' ``We live in a normal apartment, just like every other citizen,'' Elena Ceasescu told a military court during her closed trial. That's not what Romania's new authorities found when they turned up at the Ceasescu residence. Instead of a ``normal apartment,'' they discovered a 40-room mansion crammed with valuable paintings, exquisite fountains and gold-plated fixtures in the bathrooms. Every room had a television and a videocasette player. ``We had no palaces. The palaces belong to the people,'' the ousted president, Nicolae Ceasescu, told the military tribunal. Some of the Ceausescus' diversions seemed tame compared with Noriega's. The new Romanian authorities came across English instruction tapes, tennis courts and a volleyball court in the presidential compound. Noriega, on the other hand, was discovered to have red underwear to ward off evil spirits, paraphernalia for the practice of voodoo, a collection of pornographic pictures and a sizeable quantity of cocaine. Few absolute rulers seem to have been able to resist the lure of high-living. When Mrs. Marcos fled the Malacanang Palace in Manila in 1986, investigators dicovered a bill for an evening gown and six silk dresses that came to $107,000, roughly 19 times Marcos' annual presidential salary of $5,700. Former Haitian President Jean-Claude Duvalier, who fled the same month as Marcos, was worth an estimated $400 million. The late Nicaraguan President Anastasio Somoza built up a fortune worth about $100 million through investments in prostitution, gambling and construction, according to Walter LaFeber, a historian. The Dominican Republic's Rafael Trujillo controlled 111 companies at the time of his death in 1961 and was worth about $500 million, says biographer Robert Crassweller. Trujillo once reportedly spent $80,000 on a gown for his daughter Angelita. Its train was 75 feet long. The ranks of showy strongmen have diminished lately with the accelerating trend toward democracy. Emperor Bokassa I, who spent $20 million on his coronation 1976, is a dim memory to his former subjects in the Central African Republic. But one high-liver who still survives is Mobutu Sese Seko, president of Zaire, a pro-U.S. stalwart in Central Africa whose worth is believed to range between $3 billion and $5 billion. He has a number of houses abroad and has 11 palaces in Zaire alone. Next to the Sultan of Brunei, though, Mobutu deals in small change. The Sultan, with an estimated worth of $28 billion, has a palace with 1,788 rooms, including more than 200 bathrooms. The Ceasescus' existence almost seemed pedestrian by comparison.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's televised New Year's message to the Soviet Union: On behalf of the American people, my wife Barbara, and my family, I bring you our warmest greetings. A new year is dawning around the world, the first year of the last decade of the 20th Century. And as the world looks back to nine decades of war, of strife, of suspicion, let us also look forward _ to a new century, and a new millennium, of peace, freedom and prosperity. Of course, there are no maps to lead us where we are going, to this new world of our own making. We can find our way only through cooperation beginning with a candid dialogue. It is in pursuit of such a dialogue that I met your president, Mikhail Gorbachev, near the island-nation of Malta. Let me share with you some of the matters we discussed. First, we agreed to redouble our efforts to diminish the horrible threat from weapons of mass destruction; and to pursue, with other nations, an agreement to reduce conventional forces in Europe. Second, we talked about ways we can end regional conflicts and alleviate the terrible toll in human suffering they bring. Third, I want to assure you, as I did your president, that the West seeks no advantage from the extraordinary changes underway in the East. We talked about the magnificent efforts of the people of Eastern Europe to find a free and democratic future. And I told your president that I support the dynamic process of reform in the Soviet Union. We will work together to reduce barriers to trade, investment and the free movement of goods and ideas. In these ways _ and as your economic reforms take place _ the entry of the Soviet Union into the global market can be advanced _ an historic goal that, once achieved, can improve the life of every Soviet citizen. But it is our belief that lasting peace and prosperity comes from a respect for human rights and the sharing of democratic values that are deeply rooted in the human spirit. Your own Leo Tolstoy said that if our hearts are empty, no law or political reform can fill them. The real law lives within our hearts. These values are not exclusively American or Western. They are not the possession of any people or any domain. They belong to all men and women, through all time, and in all places. They are the inalienable rights of man. Of course, much remains to be done. But the progress of the past year gives me confidence that we are heading in the right direction. In this, President Gorbachev has been a good partner in peace. Given the warn-torn history of this century, we should redouble our efforts to forge a new century of peace and freedom. Our nations have produced Abraham Lincoln, Leo Tolstoy, Martin Luther King, and Andrei Sakharov. We have persevered as allies in a terrible war. The challenges we face today are no less daunting, but with the goodwill and determination on both sides I am confident our two peoples will be equal to the task. Thank you, God bless you, and have a Happy New Year.

DOC.HEAD: Worker Buried Under Parking Garage Rubble
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Complete writethru to CORRECT worker's name to Barrios
DOC.TEXT: A demolition worker was buried under several tons of rubble when seven stories of a parking garage partially collapsed in the downtown area. Authorities identified the trapped worker as Basilio Barrios, 36, and said rescue crews prepared to use an 80-ton crane to dig him from 10 to 20 feet of rubble. Two other workers escaped on their own and a third was freed a short time later by District of Columbia firemen, authorities said. Battalion Chief Bill Embrey of the D.C. Fire Department said, `` We will stay here as long as it takes to get him out.'' Fire officials worked carefully to rescue Barrios but estimated the operation will take time because the building is unstable and could collapse more. Investigators are looking into the matter. Authorities said the workers were performing routine demolition work on the second floor of the parking garage. Two stories had been previously removed from the nine-story structure. Barrios was believed to be cutting through a length of steel on the second floor of the garage when several stories of concrete began crashing down. Authorities said there is little hope that he survived. After the building collapse, workers brought in a police dog to help search for Barrios' body. The dog recovered the hose to the torch Barrios had been holding, officials said. A relative at the scene said Barrios came to the United States about a year ago from Guatemala to make money for his wife and five children he left behind. Barrios had planned to return to Guatemala in June, the relative said.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Charges May Break The Noriega Deadlock
LaserPhoto PAN[
DOC.TEXT: Government plans to charge Manuel Antonio Noriega with murder and other common crimes may break a week-old deadlock between Washington and the Vatican over custody of the deposed strongman. President Bush says he wants Noriega behind bars in the United States to stand trial on drug trafficking charges. Panama's President Guillermo Endara, sworn as U.S. troops invaded to oust Noriega, has indicated he's not too eager to have the military ruler turned asylum-seeker remain in Panama. But the Vatican, in whose embassy Noriega sought sanctuary Dec. 24 and greeted the New Year, has made it clear it is reluctant to turn out the general until all the niceties of diplomacy and international law are fulfilled. Up to now, the main stumbling block has been the Vatican's insistence that it cannot hand over Noriega to the United States, which it considers an ``occupying power'' in Panama. It says it considers its embassy accredited to deal only with the Panamanian government, which it insists has not made a formal request for custody of Noriega. It has similarly indicated there are the centuries-old traditions of political asylum and church sanctuary to safeguard, both of which could be obviated in the case of common crimes _ with the Vatican having the privilege of deciding. So far, the Vatican has granted Noriega temporary asylum and it has not ruled out turning him over to Panama, saying in a statement Saturday it ``did not intend to block the course of justice regarding a person accused of serious crimes.'' In what appeared to be an attempt to break the deadlock, Attorney General Roglio Cruz announced Sunday that Endara's government was preparing to charge Noriega with the murder of 10 officers of the now disbanded Defense Forces. The officers were all involved in an Oct. 3 coup attempt against Noriega and were tortured and executed after surrendering, Cruz told a news conference. Later Sunday, about 200 people gathered two blocks from the Vatican mission _ which is surrounded by U.S. troops and armor _ and stood in silent vigil holding lighted candles. They said they came to pray that Noriega be brought to justice. Cruz told reporters that the government of Endara, who was elected in May in balloting nullified by Noriega, would request the ousted general's custody ``Tuesday or before''. And ``Yes, there is evidence'' to implicate Noriega directly with the officers' deaths, Cruz said in response to a question. Even Panama's Roman Catholic clergy wants Noriega brought to justice. A dozen bishops have written Pope John Paul II urging that he be handed over for trial in Panama or the United States and calling him ``the author of abominable crimes.'' As Cruz told it, a preliminary investigation showed that during the coup attempt, forces led by Maj. Moises Giroldi, chief of Noriega's security company in the Defense Headquarters, captured Noriega. Noriega negotiated with his captors, and eventually loyalist forces attacked the Defense Forces headquarters, forcing the rebels to surrender. Noriega's regime announced the next day that 10 of the rebels, including Giroldi, had been killed in the fighting. The 10 were ``executed after they surrendered in a place away from the site where they gave up,'' Cruz said. ``When the coup failed, Giroldi and the others were promised personal safety. But then he was taken by helicopter to the base at the airport and then from there to the military base at Tinajitas, where he was tortured, shot in the kneecaps and elbows and then shot to death,'' a Panamanian officer involved in the investigation said. The officer, who insisted on anonymity, told The Associated Press that ``a lieutenant who at one time shoved Noriega into a truck at the beginning of the coup had his hands cut off, and then he was shot.'' Another officer, Capt. Nicasio Lorenzo, whose body was returned to his family with a report saying he had died of asphyxiation, also was tortured. ``They put a hood over his head and then beat him and choked him until he died,'' the source said. Cruz said indictments were also are being prepared against the Noriega-dominated Electoral Council for trying ``to block the orderly renewal of government powers'' by illegally annulling the May 7 national elections. Noriega may be involved in that one, too. Although he was only the Defense Forces chief at the time, Noriega wielded absolute power behind the scenes. International observers said the elections were annulled when returns showed Endara's slate won by a 3-to-1 margin. The new government was to have taken office Sept. 1 along with a new National Legislature. But Noriega had the old legislature name Francisco Rodriguez, a crony of his, provisional president before that date. And then, less than a week before the Dec. 20 invasion, Noriega had himself named by a rump legislature made up to municipal mayors ``maximum leader'' with virtually absolute power, saying Panama was in ``a state of war'' with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Justice Says More Judges Needed To Fight Drug War
DOC.TEXT: U.S. courts need more judges, particularly in border regions burdened with a heavy load of drug cases, says Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. ``From the federal law enforcement perspective, the war on drugs will fail if the judiciary is not given the judgeships necessary to do the job,'' the Supreme Court chief said Sunday in his annual year-end report on the federal court system. ``Some courts, especially in border states, are approaching the outer limits of caseload and fatigue from handling drug-related cases,'' he said, noting that one in four criminal cases handled by the federal courts is drug-related. Rehnquist urged Congress to ``take immediate action'' to create the 59 additional trial judgeships and 16 more appellate judgeships requested last October by the U.S. Judicial Conference, the policy-making arm of the federal court system. Rehnquist heads the conference. To date, Congress has authorized 575 federal trial judgeships and 168 appellate judgeships. No new judgeship has been created since 1984.
DOC.HEAD: Three Jazz Greats Honored By National Endowment
DOC.TEXT: A Boston music educator, a New York pianist and a Los Angeles trumpeteer received $20,000 fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts that also place them in the ``Jazz Hall of Fame.'' George Russell, Cecil Taylor and Gerald Wilson were awarded the jazz master fellowships Sunday for ``exceptional artistic merit in the field of jazz.'' The trio joins 25 other jazz luminaries, including Dizzie Gillespie, Count Basie and Ella Fitzgerald, who have been selected by the independent federal agency since the awards began in 1982. Russell, 66, of Boston, is a composer, arranger, jazz theorist, drummer, pianist and band leader who has been on the faculty of the New England Conservatory since 1969 and is leader of the Living Time Orchestra. Taylor, 60, of New York City, is a pianist and composer who was cited for his pioneering influences on modern jazz, including a piano playing style that features use of open palms, fists, elbows and forearms. Wilson, 71, of Los Angeles, is a Mississippi-born composer, arranger, band leader and trumpeter who once worked as a sideman and arranger for Count Basie and Duke Ellington, and has led several successful big bands of his own starting in the 1940s.
DOC.HEAD: Panama's New Ambassador Appeals for Help
DOC.TEXT: Panama's newly appointed ambassador is appealing for contributions to a new non-profit corporation formed to help thousands of people left homeless or wounded by the U.S invasion of his country. ``Urgent humanitarian needs are still unmet and all help is needed. We appreciate all offers of assistance from our American friends,''Carlos F. Rodriguez said Sunday in a statement announcing the establishment of AID To Panama. Dr. Jose Trinidad Castillero, Panama's minister of health, has issued an urgent appeal for intravenous solutions, antibiotics, insulin, and anaesthetics. The shortage of blood is so severe, that doctors at Santo Tomas Hospital donated their own blood, Rodriguez said. Checks and other contributions should be made to ``AID To Panama'' and sent to either: Catholic Relief Services, 209 W. Fayette Street, Baltimore, 21202; or, ``AID To Panama'' Sun Bank (Acct. No. 01-890-0114-0297), 777 Brickell Ave., Miami, Fla. 33131.
DOC.HEAD: 1989 Police Death Toll Drops
DOC.TEXT: The death toll among police officers killed in the line of duty fell to 97 in 1989, down from 167 in 1988, says the National Association of Chiefs of Police. Fifty officers died of gunshot wounds, 32 in traffic accidents, eight in plane crashes and seven others in stabbings, fights or other incidents on duty, the group said Sunday. ``Increased use of bullet resistant jackets and the upgraded training in law enforcement agencies, we believe, has played a role in reversing a trend that we thought would never end regarding the deaths of law enforcement officers,'' David Waud, the association's chief of staff services, said in a statement. The average age of officers killed was 27 in 1989. The most dangerous day, on average, was Thursday and the most dangerous hours, between 10 p.m. and 2 a.m. Texas led the count with 11 officers killed, followed by New York and Florida, each with eight, and Mississippi and California, each with seven.

DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr and Bill Cosby, whose television shows often compete for first place in the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings, also are big hits with People magazine readers. In the results of a reader poll published in the magazine this week, the star of ``Roseanne'' headed the list for favorite female television star and was voted most likely to have a flourishing career in the year 2000. Cosby, star of ``The Cosby Show,'' was the favorite male television performer. Tom Selleck and Meryl Streep were the favorite movie stars. Kenny Rogers and Barbra Streisand were voted the best vocalists. Asked whom they would pick if they had to vote among Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford or Richard Nixon, Ford was the top choice, with 38 percent of the people surveyed choosing him.

Rock star John Cougar Mellencamp says he doesn't consider his songs political, even though his ``Rain on the Scarecrow'' has become an anthem for the family farmer. Mellencamp, 37, who lives in the Bloomington area, evolved from the leader of a bar band into a spokesman for small-town and rural life with his albums ``Uh-Huh,'' released in 1983, and ``Scarecrow,'' which came out two years later. ``I don't make political records. I get accused of that all the time, but I don't,'' he said in an interview shown Saturday on MTV. ``I feel at odds with the government all the time, like I think most people do, but I don't sit down and make a political record. ``I guess `Scarecrow' was political because of that one song, `Rain on the Scarecrow.' I'm sure the song's not going to change the world. It might make people think about it a little bit,'' he said. The song became a hit at a time family farmers nationwide faced a growing threat of foreclosure, and Mellencamp has become one of the main figures behind the Farm Aid concerts.

Letter turner Vanna White was among the guests when talk and game show host Pat Sajak tied the knot with former Playboy model Lesly Brown. Sajak, 42, married Brown, 24, in a 40-minute ceremony Sunday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. There was little information available about the ceremony because the couple sold exclusive rights to the nuptials to People magazine. Brown is a University of Maryland graduate and former Miss Georgetown who appeared in Playboy magazine's 1988 ``Women of Washington'' feature. She met the host of ``The Pat Sajak Show'' and ``Wheel of Fortune'' at the celebrity opening of a restaurant in Irvine, Calif., in 1988.

Bo Schembechler is beginning to reflect on what life might be like without football and without the University of Michigan. In an interview Sunday on the eve of the Rose Bowl game, Schembechler said he intends to resign soon as athletic director. He announced his plans to step down as coach before the Wolverines came to the West Coast. The game today against the University of Southern California will be his last. ``This is not easy for me to do,'' he said. ``When you've been in the thick of the fray, you don't want to just fade into the background. What I need when this is done is a new challenge, something exciting.'' Schembechler, the winningest active Division I-A coach with 234 victories, said any new job would have to keep him busy. ``That's the way I've lived my life. I'll have to have things to do. I hope I won't have to travel as much. I'm not retiring from work, only from coaching.''

DOC.HEAD: Urban Cowboy Helps City Kids the Western Way
DOC.TEXT: At Carlos Foster's stable in the Bronx, young cowfolk looking to rope and ride don't just horse around _ they earn their spurs by staying in school and away from the drug-infested streets. The Happy Trails Stables is where Foster, 67, and his hired hands in the Urban Western Riding Program teach inner-city youths trick-riding, calf-roping and much more. ``I use the horse as a substitute for drugs. With the horse I can stop them from playing hooky and from doing drugs,'' Foster said recently from atop his palomino, Santiago. Happy Trails Stables isn't a ranch of wide-open spaces; the din of passing traffic and the shadows of adjacent housing projects intrude on the bucolic goings on. Within the stables, the tradition of the Old West takes precedence. Youths ranging in age from 8 to 20 learn the history of the cowboy. They brush the sweat and dirt from the horses' coats, walk them, clean their stables, ride them in a corral. ``I'm giving these children the opportunity to see what lies beyond the pressures which led him or her to substance abuse or away from school,'' Foster said. Foster was busting broncos at age 5 for a quarter a shot in Dantes Orientees, Cuba. He's lived in New York for nearly 30 years, working waiting and cleaning jobs in the city and skipping out West on weekends to ride the rodeo. He's a tall, thin cowpoke with a thick white moustache and a crop of white hair that is always covered with a cowboy hat. He speaks with a deep voice, his swarthy face breaking up each time he laughs. The inspiration for the Urban Western Riding Program was Foster's successful, 13-year battle against his son's heroin addiction. He felt the skills of the Wild West could help protect kids from urban horrors. He rented horses and charged for weekend riding lessons, raising enough money to rent the corral of the Happy Trails Stables. He now has about 200 students a year. Two years ago, Harry Taylor, 23, was a cocaine addict, living in a pony trailer behind the stables until he hit bottom and asked Foster for a job. ``I owe everything to Carlos because he took me under his wing and taught me that drugs and horses don't mix, so I quit cold turkey to keep up with this job,'' said Taylor. Taylor is now one of the program's instructors and has competed in bronco busting in several rodeos. This year Foster and the city Board of Education co-sponsored a curriculum for truant students from intermediate and junior high schools in the Bronx borough of New York. Each week, 120 students visit the stable for a three-hour riding lesson. Diana Ianuzzi, a teacher and counselor at Intermediate School 80 in the Bronx, said she has a hard time keeping the students calm when the bell rings and it's time to board the bus. ``It's an incentive to bring up grades and enjoy school. In my classes I can actually say within these few weeks I've seen an improvement,'' she said. At the end of the school year, 50 of the children will ride beside more than 100 professional cowboys at opening ceremonies of a Bronx rodeo. Foster is retired from trick riding and calf roping, but he intends to use Western traditions to help children for as long as it works. ``If I could stop two or five kids a year from ruining their lives, that's all I want to do the rest of my life.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Coast-To-Coast To Ring Out The Decade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `In Houston ...', to UPDATE with midnight celebrations; pick up 11th graf, `Not to ...'; SUBS last graf to UPDATE with Boston celebration; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Merrymakers tossed confetti, squawked horns and popped champagne corks and orchestras dusted off the sheet music for another rendition of ``Auld Lang Syne'' this morning to ring in 1990 and a new decade. New York City's nationally televised ball of lights that slid down a pillar high above Times Square to count off the waning year's last seconds had a few rivals this time from such places as Seattle, Houston and Atlanta. Police estimated 200,000 revelers ignored daylong rain and packed Times Square, chanting in unison to count down the last seconds of the 1980s as they watched the lighted ball slide down a pole, just as it has most New Year's Eves since 1907. Nationwide, taxi companies geared up to give free rides home to New Year's Eve revelers who over-imbibed. Highways were wet or icy in places from the Midwest into the Northeast. The countdown Sunday night had an extra ``leap second'' to keep the world's clocks in time with the rotation of the planet. Because New Year's Eve fell on a Sunday, some nightspots around the country couldn't serve drinks. But in Indiana, while taverns lacking Sunday liquor licenses were closed, restaurants and private clubs had special permission from the Legislature to stay open until 3 a.m. instead of the usual 12:30 a.m. Sunday closing time. At 90 seconds before midnight, one of the outside elevator cars on Seattle's Space Needle was to ascend, reaching the top at midnight in a blaze of 6,500 lights. Organizers expected 15,000 people to turn out. In Houston, a 20-foot Texas Lone Star was rigged to rise up the side of the Texas Commerce Tower and arrived at the top at midnight to the accompaniment of a fireworks display choreographed to music. Police estimated about 30,000 people watched from Houston's Market Square. Not to be outdone, folks in Atlanta built a 6-foot-wide foam and fiberglass Georgia peach and dropped it from a light tower at midnight at the Underground Atlanta mall. Police estimated at least 80,000 revelers jammed into the mall. They were mere neighborhood gatherings compared to the screaming crowd in New York's Times Square. The police assigned more than 2,700 officers, many wearing riot helmets, to the area from Sunday evening to 4:30 a.m. Monday. Many area businesses took precautions in case the party got out of control. The first floor of the Marriott Marquis Hotel was sheathed in plywood to ward off overexuberant revelers. In Miami, Chubby Checker exhorted ``Feel good! Let it go! Lose control!'' Sunday night as tens of thousands of people lining downtown Miami streets cheered, oohed and danced to the 56th annual King Orange Jamboree Parade. Cab companies in Indiana got ready for one of the busiest nights of the year. ``It's mass chaos,'' said John McNeely, owner of Bloomington's Yellow Cab Co. ``It's busy from the time it starts to the time it ends.'' McNeely expected to haul more than 1,000 riders between 7 p.m. Sunday and 5 a.m. Monday in a Bloomington Hospital-sponsored program that offered free rides to revelers who had too much to drink. Free cab rides also were offered in Indianapolis, where no New Year's Eve traffic deaths have been recorded since Yellow Cab began its program in 1982. Fort Worth, Texas, offered its second annual First Night, an alcohol-free celebration including a splash of performance art along with more traditional offerings such as opera, dance and classical music. Elsewhere in Texas, the big downtown fireworks display in San Antonio had been called off because of the city's financial problems, but corporate and individual donations put it back on the schedule. And after a blast of unseasonably cold weather, the hard edges of ice sculptures decorating Boston as part of its 14th annual First Night festivities got rounded off Sunday under an untimely drizzle. But despite the rain, an estimated 250,000 people showed up to watch the midnight fireworks over Boston Harbor.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Titan Rocket Launches Communications Satellites
LaserPhoto MLB1
DOC.TEXT: A Titan 3 rocket carrying British and Japanese communications satellites gave thousands of spectators a dazzling New Year's Eve show when it roared into space after nine postponements. Martin Marietta Corp. entered the commercial launch business as the 155-foot-tall booster etched a fiery path in a star-filled sky. More than three hours after the 7:07 p.m. launch, officials reported the two satellites had been deployed properly. Originally set for Dec. 7, the launch was delayed once by a technical problem and eight times by strong, high altitude winds. The wind didn't pose a problem Sunday night and the countdown proceeded without a hitch to an on-time liftoff. The most powerful U.S. commercial rocket carried into space the 14,700-pound JCSAT-2 and the 3,230-pound Skynet 4 satellites. JCSAT-2 will complete a two-satellite Japanese domestic network, providing telephone, television, facsimile and high-speed data services. It is owned by the Japanese Communications Satellite Co. Skynet 4 will be used by the British Ministry of Defense for communicating with land, sea and air forces. The Japanese company and British government shared the $125 million cost of the rocket and launch services provided by Martin Marietta. The Titan 3, built at Martin Marietta's Denver plant, is the second big U.S. rocket to enter the commercial market. McDonnell Douglas had the first, with its Delta rocket hoisting a communications satellite for British Satellite Broadcasting in August. General Dynamics plans to enter the competition in 1990 with its Atlas rocket. The three U.S. companies are competing with the European Space Agency's Ariane rocket. Ariane, which had a big head start on the American companies, has signed contracts covering about half the estimated 15 to 20 launches planned annually in the next several years. That leaves the three American companies and budding Soviet and Chinese commercial programs to compete for the remaining contracts. Martin Marietta has signed on only three additional customers for the Titan 3, but a company official said he hoped Sunday night's success would attract new business. ``We feel this success firmly establishes Martin Marietta as a major player in the world market for commercial launch business,'' said Edward M. Browne, president of the company's commercial Titan division.

DOC.HEAD: Eight More Cold Deaths Pushes Two-Week Toll to 60
DOC.TEXT: Eight more people have died of exposure to the chilly weather gripping northern Bangladesh, bringing the death toll from the cold snap to 60 in two weeks, newspapers said today. In neighboring India, at least 61 people have died of hypothermia in the same period. Itefaq, an independent Dhaka daily, said six people died Sunday in the Panchagarh district where temperatures dropped to 36 degrees, the lowest in three decades. Two people died of the cold in Jaipurhat district, according to Sangbad, another independent Bengali-language newspaper. Most of the cold wave victims had no homes and were sleeping on the ground. In Panchagarh, 220 miles north of Dhaka, the Bangladesh Red Crescent Society, the Moslem equivalent of the Red Cross, said it was distributing warm clothing and blankets to poor people to help them cope with the cold. Winter lows in northern Bangladesh usually hover around 44 degrees. The cold weather strikes hard at this country where the per capita annual income is $160 and even people with shelter are ill-prepared for winter. Most houses in Bangladesh, a country of 110 million people, have mud floors with walls fashioned from thin mats of straw or split bamboo.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A woman who boasted, ``My mother gave me a slow cooker for Christmas. It cooks so slow, the bean soup sprouts,'' is the World Champion Liar for 1989 in the Burlington Liar's Club's annual competition. The tale told by Mary Lathrop of Garden City, Kan., stood tallest among nearly 300 entries from 33 states, Canada, India and Malaysia, John Soeth, the club's president, announced Sunday. Entries receiving honorable mention included: _Ten-year-old Steven West, Pensacola, Fla., who said: ``In Florida we had a hurricane last year with winds so bad it blew the bark off trees and out of dogs.'' _John Bartley, Comstock, Wis., who said: ``A small town in northern Wisconsin purchased a new fire engine and the town council was debating the subject of what to do with the old fire engine. The mayor finally settled the argument when he decided that we will keep it in stand-by and use it only on false alarms.''

Alf and E.T. may have liked the idea, but few people on Earth were willing to dig deep enough to build a $25 million welcoming station for visitors from outer space. Thomas L. Weber, 51, said financial problems caused him to close the office that was the center for promoting the project. ``We got tens of thousands of letters, but we couldn't even afford postage to answer the mail,'' Weber said. ``I guess if people had slipped $5 or $10 or $20 in each envelope, we'd still be operating,'' he said. His plan called for the welcoming station to provide a safe landing area that would accommodate visitors from other planets. The site he selected is on hilly farmland near Elmwood in western Wisconsin. However, the groundswell of financial support he expected from those around the nation who believe in UFOs never materialized. Weber said he spent about $20,000 running the Site Center office. ``About half came out of my own pocket,'' he said. ``I and another person were the major contributors.''

DOC.HEAD: Seven Die in Texas Crash, Six in Chain Pileup in Arizona
DOC.TEXT: A head-on crash killed seven people in West Texas, while fog and ice on an Arizona highway were blamed for a series of crashes that killed six people and injured 34. A pickup truck veered out of control on a hill and slammed head-on into a car on U.S. Highway 67 about 27 miles south of Marfa, Texas on Sunday, killing the pickup's driver and all six people in the car, said Department of Public Safety Trooper Mark Riordan. Riordan said it was the worst crash in Texas since the September school bus crash in Alton that killed 21 students. In Flagstaff, Ariz., authorities said 24 people remained hospitalized Sunday, four in critical condition, after Saturday's 62-vehicle chain pileup on Interstate 40. Four of the six people killed were members of one Indiana family, state Department of Public Safety officials said. Lt. Carlton Hill said there were at least three separate accident sites over a quarter-mile stretch of I-40 about five miles east of Flagstaff.

DOC.HEAD: Women Earn Nearly Quarter of Math Doctorates
DOC.TEXT: Women are beginning to count more in American mathematics, according to a University of Massachusetts professor who says they earned nearly a quarter of all the math doctorates in the last school year. ``It should dispel the notion once and for all that mathematics is a man's game,'' said Professor Edward Connors, who conducts an annual survey of the doctorates issued in the field for the American Mathematical Society and the Mathematical Association of America. The new female doctorates, with median starting salaries of $30,500, even made about $500 a year more than their male classmates, Connors said. In 1987-88, about 21 percent of mathematics Ph.D.s went to women, he said. In 1989 it was a little over 24 percent, with 313 men and 98 women earning doctorates in math. Connors said that the percentage rise was fueled both by increasing numbers of women going on to graduate work in math and the declining numbers of American men in the field. For the third straight year, U.S. colleges granted more doctorates in math to foreign students than they did to American citizens. Out of the 904 doctorates issued in the 1988-89 school year, 46 percent went to U.S. citizens. That was slightly better than in the previous year's figure of 45 percent, but the number of doctorates earned by Americans has been declining since the 1976-77 school year, when 76 percent of the 901 issued went to U.S. citizens, according to the survey. Although women have made up about half of the bachelor's degrees awarded in math for more than a decade, traditionally they have not gone on to advanced degrees, he said. ``It's hard to understand, because the world of mathematics doesn't have the artificial barriers to women and minorities of some of the other physical sciences where much of the work is done in research groups,'' Connors said. ``Mathematicians are by and large a bunch of loners. And the rest of the world regards them all _ men and women _ as sort of different. '' Betty M. Vetter, who conducts surveys on women and minorities in the sciences for the American Association for the Advancement of Science, said it's too soon to tell whether the 1989 statistics signal a trend. However, she said the higher salaries that women mathematicians received most likely were a glitch. ``The only field where women have been able to hold a slight edge in salaries over men has been engineering and that's only at the starting level,'' Ms. Vetter said. ``The real salary problems occur later on, because women still do not have the same opportunities for advancement as men.''

DOC.HEAD: College Seeks Epilogue to Famed Iron Curtain Speech
DOC.TEXT: Westminster College, where Winston S. Churchill's ``Iron Curtain speech'' signaled the start of the Cold War in 1946, hopes Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev will deliver an epilogue. ``We're hoping that a world figure who has played such a major role in East-West politics would see the importance of returning to the place where the Cold War was first defined,'' college president Harvey Saunders said. Fulton, a community of 11,000, has asked Sen. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo., to help try to get Gorbachev to speak at Westminster in June when he visits the United States for a summit meeting with President Bush. While out of office as Britain's prime minister, Churchill was persuaded by President Truman to come to Fulton to accept an honorary degree. In his March 1946 lecture, Churchill said, ``From Stettin in the Baltic, to Trieste in the Adriatic, an iron curtain has descended across the (European) continent.'' The phrase drew little immediate attention from the media, but soon it became part of the Cold War glossary.

DOC.HEAD: Majority In Poll Favor Environment Over Economy
DOC.TEXT: Americans entering the homestretch of the 20th century said they want to clean up the environment even if economic prosperity suffers, a newspaper poll published today found. Respondents to the Los Angeles Times' year-end poll also opposed legalizing drugs by a 2-1 margin, while about half said they keep a gun at home. And a majority of those surveyed favored deep defense spending cuts in light of changes in Eastern Europe, but there was little agreement on how to divide the ``peace dividend.'' The poll contacted by telephone a random sampling of 2,095 U.S. adults between Dec. 16-20 and had a 3 percent margin of error in either direction. By a 2-1 margin, respondents said that entering 1990 they favored ``protecting the environment even if that means some people will lose their jobs and the government will have to spend a great deal of money.'' One-half of those polled favored cutting defense spending; one-third each supported using the money to bolster domestic social programs, reduce the national deficit and cut taxes. A strong majority opposed legalizing drugs, but 3 out of 10 said they thought that it may be the only way to bring the nation's drug crisis under control. Most in that group were younger respondents. Half those surveyed said they keep at least one gun at home, either for hunting, protection, or both. Euthanasia was favored by nine out of 10 polled, while one in 10 reported contemplating suicide. President Bush got high marks, with 73 percent saying they approve of the job he's doing and 21 percent registering disapproval.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS spelling of Ceausescu in summary line and grafs 4, 6, 7, 8 and 17 ^WASHINGTON TODAY: Ceausescu and Noriega Mixed Power with Opulence
DOC.TEXT: Four years ago, it was Imelda's shoes that caused the fuss. Now, it's Elena's shoes. There's something about political power that breeds extravagance, a lesson reinforced by the trappings of wealth left behind last week by fleeing despots in both Romania and Panama. When the Marcoses were forced out of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos' shoe collection _ enough for her to change daily for nine years without wearing the same pair twice _ was the talk of Manila. The pattern is much the same nowadays in Bucharest, where Elena Ceausescu boasted a wardrobe featuring shoes with diamond-encrusted heels one day, only to find herself in front of a firing squad before she could say, ``Hey, wait a second.'' In Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega also cut few corners in pursuit of the good life. He had an array of houses and apartments in Panama, France and the Dominican Republic, a collection of personal aircraft and three large pleasure yachts _ ``Macho I, Macho II and Macho III.'' ``We live in a normal apartment, just like every other citizen,'' Elena Ceausescu told a military court during her closed trial. That's not what Romania's new authorities found when they turned up at the Ceausescu residence. Instead of a ``normal apartment,'' they discovered a 40-room mansion crammed with valuable paintings, exquisite fountains and gold-plated fixtures in the bathrooms. Every room had a television and a videocasette player. ``We had no palaces. The palaces belong to the people,'' the ousted president, Nicolae Ceausescu, told the military tribunal. Some of the Ceausescus' diversions seemed tame compared with Noriega's. The new Romanian authorities came across English instruction tapes, tennis courts and a volleyball court in the presidential compound. Noriega, on the other hand, was discovered to have red underwear to ward off evil spirits, paraphernalia for the practice of voodoo, a collection of pornographic pictures and a sizeable quantity of cocaine. Few absolute rulers seem to have been able to resist the lure of high-living. When Mrs. Marcos fled the Malacanang Palace in Manila in 1986, investigators dicovered a bill for an evening gown and six silk dresses that came to $107,000, roughly 19 times Marcos' annual presidential salary of $5,700. Former Haitian President Jean-Claude Duvalier, who fled the same month as Marcos, was worth an estimated $400 million. The late Nicaraguan President Anastasio Somoza built up a fortune worth about $100 million through investments in prostitution, gambling and construction, according to Walter LaFeber, a historian. The Dominican Republic's Rafael Trujillo controlled 111 companies at the time of his death in 1961 and was worth about $500 million, says biographer Robert Crassweller. Trujillo once reportedly spent $80,000 on a gown for his daughter Angelita. Its train was 75 feet long. The ranks of showy strongmen have diminished lately with the accelerating trend toward democracy. Emperor Bokassa I, who spent $20 million on his coronation 1976, is a dim memory to his former subjects in the Central African Republic. But one high-liver who still survives is Mobutu Sese Seko, president of Zaire, a pro-U.S. stalwart in Central Africa whose worth is believed to range between $3 billion and $5 billion. He has a number of houses abroad and has 11 palaces in Zaire alone. Next to the Sultan of Brunei, though, Mobutu deals in small change. The Sultan, with an estimated worth of $28 billion, has a palace with 1,788 rooms, including more than 200 bathrooms. The Ceausescus' existence almost seemed pedestrian by comparison.

DOC.HEAD: Disgraced Ex-President Shouted Down In Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Emerging from self-imposed exile, former President Chun Doo-hwan appeared before Parliament but his answers to questions on corruption during his tenure were drowned out by angry, shouting lawmakers. During Sunday's hearings, which were broadcast to the nation, the disgraced ex-president refused to make an outright apology, as opposition parties have demanded, but said he would take ``moral responsibility'' for wrongdoing under his rule. He has denied any personal corruption, but 48 of his relatives and associates have been convicted of embezzlement and other crimes. ``I didn't do anything wrong,'' Chun said. ``It's a lie! It's a lie!'' one opposition lawmaker shouted as Chun denied almost all charges of corruption, power abuse and misdeeds. The testimony, which lasted more than 12 hours, was interrupted repeatedly by shouting matches that forced adjournments and a virtual free-for-all involving about two dozen legislators. A melee broke out after opposition legislators angrily accused Chun of lying about his involvement in the crushing of a 1980 civil uprising in the city of Kwangju. About 200 people died and 1,500 were wounded in the uprising, which was suppressed by the military. Chun was a top general at the time and became president the same year with military backing. After the hearing, Chun returned to the Buddhist temple where he has lived in self-imposed exile since leaving office in 1988 after a seven-year term marred by charges of corruption, human rights abuses and misconduct. Aides said he would not come back to testify. Chun was forced to agree to democratic president elections in 1987 after months of anti-government protests. His hand-picked successor, Roh, was elected Dec. 17, 1987 in South Korea's first direct presidential election in 16 years.

DOC.HEAD: Reeling From Coup Attempt, Aquino Announces Big Cabinet Reshuffle
DOC.TEXT: Corazon Aquino has made the most extensive Cabinet reshuffle of her presidency less than a month after a failed coup, changing such key posts as finance, justice and military affairs. Her spokesman, Adolfo Azcuna, claimed the changes announced Sunday had not been prompted by the coup attempt _ the most serious of her nearly four-year tenure _ but ``by the same reasons, perhaps that precipitated the coup.'' Public criticism had been directed at the departments of transport, education, agriculture and agrarian reform, whose secretaries were among those replaced in the shakeup. It was the most sweeping Cabinet revamp since Mrs. Aquino took office in the February 1986 uprising that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos. ``The thrust of these changes is the need always to adjust to new situations to assure improved delivery of services to our people,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a nationally televised statement. In her announcement, Mrs. Aquino said Jose Cuisia, administrator of the Social Security System, would take over as Central Bank governor. Retired Maj. Gen. Mariano Adalem was named presidential adviser on military affairs, replacing retired Maj. Gen. Jose Magno. Adalem was also appointed acting chief of the National Intelligence Coordinating Agency. There had been widespread criticism of the intelligence service's failure to predict the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, in which at least 113 people were killed and more than 500 injured. Mrs. Aquino retained Fidel Ramos as defense secretary despite demands by mutineers that he be replaced. Ramos has crushed all six coup attempts while serving as military chief of staff and later defense secretary. Also retained was Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus, who was widely criticized for sloppy management of a department where former Marcos supporters hold key positions. Mrs. Aquino named Jesus Estanislao, former economic planning secretary, to be secretary of finance, replacing Vicente Jayme. Jayme, who underwent cardiac surgery this year, was appointed presidential adviser on economic and financial affairs. In other changes: _ Labor Secretary Franklin Drilon as secretary of justice, replacing Sedfrey Ordonez who was named ambassador to the United Nations; _ Senen Bacani, a former agribusiness executive, as secretary of agriculture, replacing Carlos Domingez who resigned; _ Isidro Carino, a university president, as secretary of education, replacing Lourdes Quisumbing, who resigned; Mrs. Aquino reorganized her Cabinet after coup attempts in November 1986 and August 1987, but the changes failed to satisfy military dissidents or lead to significant improvements in her administration.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 1,700 Injured As Filipinos Greet New Year
With PM-New Year's Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Filipinos greeted the New Year with a barrage of fireworks and gunshots in the air which left more than 1,700 injured and triggered at least five fires in the capital, officials said. Explosions rocked Manila and colorful streamers roared into the sky throughout the night, despite police warnings that they would enforce a ban on private fireworks displays because of fears of a new attempt to topple President Corazon Aquino. A spokesman for the police Capital Command said there were no reports of anyone arrested. A check of 28 Manila-area hospitals showed 1,640 people were treated for gunshots and fireworks-related injuries, including burns and missing fingers. Forty-eight of those were wounded by stray bullets, hospital sources said. In addition, hospitals in nearby Bulacan province, center of the country's fireworks industry, reported 75 people were treated for fireworks injuries. Most of the injured were children, officials said. Last year, police said nearly 1,000 people were injured and 41 killed during New Year's revelry in Manila alone. Also this year, a garment factory in the Bulacan town of Balagtas was razed when firecrackers thrown by revelers triggered a fire. Damage was estimated at $45,000. Fires were reported overnight in five areas of Manila, where most structures are made of wood. Damage was estimated at $591,000. In a New Year's message, Mrs. Aquino urged Filipinos to overcome the political uncertainties of the past year and work for stability. On Dec. 1, thousands of military mutineers launched the sixth and bloodiest attempt to topple the nearly four-year Aquino administration. Key mutiny leaders, including former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, remain at large and have threatened to continue efforts to oust Mrs. Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: Parties From Rio To Berlin; Eastern Europe Fetes New Freedom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with 1,700 injured in Manila, five fires SUB 5th graf, `In the ... about 70,000. Picks up 6th pvs, `The pope ...' ^LaserColor BER10
DOC.TEXT: Revelers frolicked on the Berlin Wall, Romanians watched their first televised New Year's Mass in 40 years and Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared that socialism can prosper with democracy in the new decade that begins today. Festivities ranged from solemn to raucous. More than 2,000 people lit candles and rallied in the rain in Hong Kong in support of democracy, expressing hope that China's leaders would grant greater freedoms to avoid the type of bloody revolution that convulsed Romania. Romanians were not the only Eastern Europeans to celebrate an end to repressive one-party Communist rule. Poles, Hungarians, East Germans, Czechs and Slovaks also had peaceful revolts to take pride in. In the Philippines, a barrage of fireworks and gunshots in the air left more than 1,700 people injured and triggered at least five fires in Manila, officials said. And in London's Trafalgar Square, at least 114 people were injured during the annual New Year's party that drew about 70,000. The pope expressed joy over new religious freedom in the East bloc, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said ``the overwhelming lesson of the 1980s is that socialism has failed.'' Gorbachev and President Bush exchanged televised greetings to their respective nations. In separate comments to the Soviet people, Gorbachev declared that true socialism is still very much alive. ``The necessity to combine socialism with democracy has again been vigorously reaffirmed in the dramatic events that occurred in Berlin, Sofia, Prague and Bucharest,'' Gorbachev said. ``The postwar division of the continent recedes into the past,'' he said. ``The 1990s could become the most fruitful period in the history of civilization.'' Along the Berlin Wall, thousands of Germans rang in a new year of unity at a huge party punctuated by drums, saxophones and whistling firecrackers. Hammers clanged against chisels as souvenir hunters mined for chunks. Tens of thousands of people poured from both directions through the newly opened wall, which in the past two months has been transformed from a symbol of suppression to one of reconciliation. Thousands more scaled the wall and tumbled into the other Germany as the formerly feared East German border guards watched with amusement. ``The wall is open for the first time in my life. We want to celebrate along with everyone else,'' said Hans-Juergen Witfeld, who traveled from the Ruhr Valley city of Dortmund with eight friends. A projection screen set up near the wall at the Brandenburg Gate collapsed after midnight under the weight of revelers who had climbed its scaffolding, killing one man and injuring more than 50, East Germany's official ADN news agency reported. In Bucharest, Romanians prayed for peace, prosperity and their new freedom, celebrating their first New Year's Eve in 24 years without the oppressive yoke of Nicolae Ceausescu's dictatorship. ``Happy New Year Dignity, Happy New Year Democracy,'' the Bucharest newspaper Truth proclaimed in a front-page headline. Interim President Ion Iliescu, in a New Year's speech, made a renewed commitment to multiparty democracy and pledged that the popular revolution that toppled Ceausescu would ``remain unvanquishable.'' One Romanian newspaper carried a warning from police asking holiday merrymakers not to use fireworks and noisemakers in the capital, where the streets were filled with nervous soldiers armed with automatic weapons. Romanian television broadcast a special Romanian Orthodox New Year's Mass, celebrated by Patriarch Theocrist _ something unthinkable for decades under harsh Communist rule. ``The prayers are for the freedom we have now. We have this liberty at the price of blood,'' another cleric, Father Agatangel, said at the same service. Other Romanians prepared to celebrate in traditional fashion with cabbage rolls, drinks, family and friends. Strands of brightly colored lights adorned some trees. Snowmen stood everywhere, many dressed in army helmets and a few with the word ``victory'' written with stones. President Francois Mitterrand of France ended the bicentennial year of the French Revolution by celebrating ``the fall of the other Bastilles in the Europe where dictators still ruled'' in 1989. ``We have just helped the most dazzling victory for democracy,'' Mitterrand said. ``1789-1989: no one could have dared to dream a celebration like this for such a beautiful anniversary.'' Pope John Paul II said during a Mass in Rome that 1989 had been an ``extraordinarily important year for all humanity, and in particular, for several European countries, which have seen new prospects of liberty and national cohesion develop within their borders.'' In Brazil, more than 1 million people filled Rio's Copacabana beach to celebrate the Feast of Iemanja, the goddess of the sea. Just before midnight, people lay gifts to Iemanja on the shore, to be carried away by the waves. Some even place their offerings on elaborately constructed rafts. Millions of Japanese streamed to temples and shrines to usher out the Year of the Snake and welcome the Year of the Horse with prayers for health and prosperity. The Oriental calendar names years for the 12 animals that, according to legend, called on the dying Buddha. Soviet cosmonauts appeared on Soviet television Saturday night from space with a tiny tree and a doll of Grandfather Frost, the Soviet version of Santa Claus. They said they wished they had some champagne to toast the new year. But like many Soviets in this time of shortages, they had to make do with fruit juice.

DOC.HEAD: President Declares General Amnesty
DOC.TEXT: President Ibrahim Babangida today declared a general prisoner amnesty that was expected to result in the immediate release of thousands of inmates. The order, in a New Year's address to the nation, follows criticism from a local human rights group that scores of prisoners died in the last year due to overcrowded, unhygienic conditions. Babangida, in a television and radio address, ordered freed all who have completed three-fourths of their terms, those jailed for minor offenses whose sentences do not exceed one year and others jailed for life but who have served more than 10 years. The president also ordered released those awaiting trial who have been held in prison or police custody for more than a year, except prisoners being held for drug-related crimes and charges of manslaughter, murder, armed robbery and economic sabotage. Nigeria's leading human rights group, the Civil Liberties Organization, has been fighting legal battles with the military government to free inmates in pre-trial detention who at one point in 1989 numbered about 1,000. Some had languished in custody untried for as long as five years. The organization also has lambasted the government for the unhygienic and overcrowded conditions of the prisons and said that in one prison alone, Lagos' Ikoyi facility, 78 inmates had died in 1989 due to poor sanitation, poor feeding and lack of adequate medical facilities. The government did not say how many of Nigeria's approximately 23,000 prisoners would be released as a result of Babangida's order, but observers estimated the number would be in the thousands. Babangida said the move was aimed at decongesting Nigerian prisons, which are stuffed to almost twice their official capacities.

DOC.HEAD: British Artist William Scott Dies, 76
DOC.TEXT: William Scott, a British artist acclaimed for his still-life paintings and drawings of simple foods and kitchen utensils, has died at age 76 at his home in southwest England. Scott, who died Thursday of Alzheimer's disease at his home outside Bath, played a leading role in bringing British painting back into the international mainstream after World War II isolation. He represented his country successfully at art festivals throughout the 1950s and 1960s. In 1961, he won the international critics' prize at the Sao Paulo Biennale. In 1966, he was named a Commander of the British Empire. The son of an Irish signwriter, Scott was born Feb. 15, 1913, in Greenock, Scotland, and was brought up in Northern Ireland. He studied at the Belfast College of Art and the Royal Academy of Art in London in the late 1920s and 1930s. Scott initially reacted against the surrealist tendencies of the 1930s, but by the 1960s his work had become increasingly abstract. He once described himself as belonging to ``the generation in between'' the representational and non-representational phases of modern art. He was noted above all for his paintings of objects such as kitchen pots and pans, baskets and bottles, eggs and loaves of bread laid out on kitchen tables. ``His works are characterized by an exceptional ability to control the rhythmical spacing of shapes and the division of picture areas,'' commented The Times of London. ``His often very beautiful colors ranged from the richly voluptuous to a fondness for pure black and white: a blend of sensuality and austerity which is characteristic of his work.'' Few British painters have been more widely represented in the world's galleries. Scott's work is included in permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Goteborg Museum in Sweden, the National Gallery of Modern Art in Rome and the Tate Museum in London. Survivors include his wife, Mary Lucas, and two sons, James and Robert.

DOC.HEAD: Holidays Helped Girl Who Was Switched With Another At Birth
DOC.TEXT: Excitement about the holidays has helped 11-year-old Kimberly Mays cope with the news that she and another girl apparently were switched at birth, the man who raised her said. ``I don't think Kim's been terribly bothered with the thoughts of anything over the past few weeks,'' Robert Mays said. ``She's been very excited about Christmas,'' told the Sarasota Herald-Tribune in a story published Sunday. ``Kids don't let a lot get between them and Santa Claus.'' It was Mays' first interview since he faced a roomful of reporters five weeks ago to discuss his reaction to genetic tests that revealed Kimberly is not his biological daughter. Under an agreement reached between Mays and Ernest and Regina Twigg of Sebring, Kimberly's biological parents, the fifth-grader is allowed to remain with Mays. Mays had refused to allow the genetic tests of his only child for more than a year until the Twiggs agreed to drop any custody claim of Kimberly if tests revealed she was their daughter. Robert and Barbara Mays' biological daughter, Arlena, who was raised by the Twiggs, died in 1988 at the age of 9 of a congenital heart defect. Barbara Mays died of cancer in 1981. ``There's been virtually no discussion, none whatsoever, about the Twiggs with me since the day after the blood tests came back,'' he said. Mays said he has tried to impress on Kimberly that she can take as much time as she needs to sort out her feelings. ``I think, considering everything she's been through, she's doing remarkably well for an 11-year-old child,'' said Mays, who has shielded Kimberly from reporters throughout the ordeal. Mays said he's been too busy as a roofing supply salesman and preparing for the holidays to make any decision about whether to sue Hardee Memorial Hospital in Wauchula, where Kimberly and Arlena were born and the switch apparently took place. The Twiggs initially filed a $100 million lawsuit against the hospital, but have withdrawn that lawsuit and filed another one seeking unspecified damages. Hospital officials, who denied any wrongdoing, have been mum ever since the test results were disclosed. Mays also said there has not been enough time to schedule psychological tests of Kimberly to determine whether she would suffer from meeting the Twiggs and their children. The Twiggs say they would like to get to know Kimberly and introduce her to her brothers and sisters, who range in age from 21 to 6, but not if psychologists hired by both families agree that it would be traumatic for the young girl. The Twiggs also have agreed not to establish contact with her, and will refrain from sending birthday cards or Christmas presents until the psychological evaluations are complete.

DOC.HEAD: Sounds of Southern California New Year's Eve Gunfire Ring In 1990
With PM-New Year's Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Well-armed New Year's Eve revelers rang in 1990 with the rat-a-tat-tat of gunfire in Southern California today, despite police warnings that the tradition shooting into the air is dangerous as well as illegal. Shots could be heard from all compass points downtown after the stroke of midnight. ``We're used to it. It sounds like a shooting gallery,'' said police Sgt. T. Brown. ``The dopes won't learn unless they get hit themselves. Death toll figures tomorrow will tell the story.'' There weren't any immediate reports of people being hit by stray slugs. Weeklong warnings by police agencies that shooting into the air is a felony _ and a potentially deadly way to celebrate the new year _ failed to halt the practice. Aerial gunfire has killed dozens of people in recent years, with most hit in the head by slugs falling far from where the bullets were fired. Weapons experts say bullets return to earth at the same speed they were traveling when the left the muzzle of the gun, making them equally lethal on the way down. While police tried to pinpoint midnight firing sites, some residents cowered at home in fear of the rain of lead. Michael Piper said he and his wife, Sandy, felt safer in their middle-floor apartment in the Highland Park neighborhood of Los Angeles than at a gathering in a one-story house. ``We left the party early to greet the new year alone,'' he said. ``I wouldn't want to be outside without a bulletproof vest and an army helmet.'' City police routinely ground their squadron of patrol helicopters during the height of the shooting. Law officers in Southern California spent the final days of 1989 warning against the misuse of guns and abuse of alcohol to celebrate the New Year, but said they expected the worst. ``It's a major concern of ours every year,'' said Costa Mesa police Lt. Alan Kent. ``And we haven't noticed it getting any better.'' In Los Angeles, both police Chief Daryl Gates and Sheriff Sherman Block held news conferences warning that it's a felony to fire a gun into the air in a residential area. The Los Angeles Police Department set up at least eight command posts to make arrests. In Santa Ana, an Orange County city where the gunfire is common, officers have posted thousands of safety leaflets in English and Spanish warning against the practice.

DOC.HEAD: No Survivors Found in Plane Wreckage
DOC.TEXT: Searchers found the wreckage of a single-engine airplane in a remote, wooded ravine three days after it was reported missing, authorities said. All three people aboard were killed. Searchers in aircraft were unable to find the white Beechcraft plane because of dense tree cover, but a ground team located it Sunday about 15 miles northwest of Merrill in northern Wisconsin, Lincoln County Sheriff Ronald Krueger said. One victim was found in the wreckage and the other two had been thrown clear, Krueger said. The victims were the 42-year-old pilot, his 14-year-old son and his 17-year-old nephew, all of Illinois, the sheriff said. Their bodies were badly burned and there were no signs any of them survived the initial impact, he said. Kruger said a fallen tree had damaged the plane's emergency locator signal, complicating the search.

DOC.HEAD: No Sweat, Say Passengers on Threatened Flight
DOC.TEXT: Bomb threats against a Northwest Airlines Paris-to-Detroit flight didn't rattle the 22 passengers who kept their reservations. ``I wasn't worried a bit, especially after all the security we went through to get on the flight,'' Mike Matour, 22, of Philadelphia said after Flight 51 landed without incident at 4:41 p.m. Saturday at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. Northwest spokesman Kevin Whalen, who took the flight, said 105 of 127 passengers canceled their reservations after learning a telephone caller said Flight 51 would be targeted. Whalen said the flight had nine crew members. Airline officials in Paris said earlier that the plane carried 28 passengers and 14 crew members. The jet can hold 284 passengers. Northwest disclosed the threat after reports of it emerged in Europe. The Federal Aviation Administration and airlines have come under pressure to disclose such threats since the December 1988 bombing of a Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, Scotland, killed 270 people. A threat against Pan Am before that flight was circulated within the U.S. government, but not to the public. FAA spokesman John Leyden said U.S. airlines receive about 300 threats each year.

DOC.HEAD: Soggy New Year's in East; Clouds Threaten Rose Bowl
DOC.TEXT: Cold rain kept crowds smaller than usual at outdoor New Year's celebrations in the Northeast, and showers were possible at today's Rose Bowl game in normally sunny Pasadena, Calif. The weather front that pelted the Northeast with rain and sleet Sunday was moving out to sea, leaving behind colder temperatures and a chance of snow. Flurries were forecast today for western New York state, Pennsylvania and New Jersey as well as in the Great Lakes region. Clear skies were expected over the nation's midsection, with snow in the Rockies and rain in parts of California and the Pacific Northwest. Snow was expected in the Cascade range of Washington and Oregon. In Pasadena, clouds drifted over the thousands who spent the night waiting on the streets for Tournament of Roses parade to begin. There was a 30 percent chance afternoon showers could fall on the Rose Bowl game between the University of Michigan and the University of Southern California. Highs were forecast to be in the low to mid-60s. A mass of cold air bulging south from Canada was expected to plunge temperatures to highs in the 20s in the upper Midwest and the 30s in inland New England and the Rockies. Above-freezing weather was forecast in most of the rest of the country, with highs in the 60s and 70s in the southeast and the desert Southwest. Miami Beach, which shivered through an unusual cold wave just a week ago, was expected to warm to the 80s again after setting a record high for the date of 82 degrees Sunday.
