DOC.HEAD: Soviet President Says After A Hard Year, The 1990s Could Be The Best Yet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to ADD that Gorbachev's speech broadcast just before midnight, year Gorbachev took office. Picks up 11th graf. `The year ...' ^With PM-World New Year, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says he's just had the toughest year of his tenure _ one of strikes, ethnic violence and economic strain _ but thinks the 1990s could be extraordinarily peaceful and harmonious. Speaking in his annual New Year's television address to the Soviet people, Gorbachev also made it clear that he disagrees with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's year-end conclusion that socialism has failed. ``The necessity to combine socialism with democracy has again been vigorously reaffirmed in the dramatic events that occurred in Berlin, Sofia, Prague and Bucharest,'' Gorbachev said in the speech just before midnight Sunday. Communists in East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Romania and Poland were forced by pro-democracy movements to give up their absolute power in 1989, and Communists in Bulgaria are trying to stem public protests with reforms. Gorbachev wished Eastern Europeans success in their revolutionary renewal and promised Soviet solidarity. ``The postwar division of the continent recedes into the past,'' he said. The Cold War is ending, and people now speak of his idea of a ``common European home'' as a realistic prospect instead of fantasy, he said. ``The 1990s could become the most fruitful period in the history of civilization,'' he predicted, if people concentrate on ``solidarity, cooperation and accord.'' He was clearly appealing for unity not only internationally but domestically. In 1989, the Soviet Union was riven by calls for secession and by ethnic strife that killed hundreds of people. His New Year's wish was that 1990 pass ``under the watchword of mutual understanding and consolidation.'' The past year has been the most difficult of his tenure, said Gorbachev, who came to power in March 1985. ``But no matter how difficult 1989 was, we are seeing it off not only with a sense of bitterness, but also as a year in which much indispensable work was accomplished.'' The year brought the Soviet Union's first ``genuinely free elections,'' its first Congress, parliamentary experience and ``a rapid rise in the democratic culture of the people,'' Gorbachev said. Last spring's elections to the Congress of People's Deputies were the first contested elections in Soviet history, and the balloting produced true competition in many districts. However, in some areas, Communist bureaucrats kept an iron grip on the electoral process. Gorbachev said better times lie ahead. ``It is not easy for seeds to grow in our soil,'' he said, apparently referring obliquely to democracy. ``But if they survive and strike root _ and we must see they do _ they will yield rich fruit for the entire country and every person.'' The Soviet leader recorded a separate New Year's message for the American people that was to be broadcast on U.S. television today. In his message to the Soviet people, President Bush pledged to work with Gorbachev to ``reduce barriers to trade, investment and the free movement of goods and ideas'' so the Soviet Union's ``entry into the global market can be advanced.''

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup of Seattle Oil Spill Under Way
DOC.TEXT: A south wind frustrated efforts to clean a spill of about 2,000 gallons of marine diesel oil in Elliott Bay. The source of the spill, spotted Friday night, was not known, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Michael Cobb. Crews collected about 500 gallons of oil by mid-Sunday, but wind kept the remainder under a pier. Officials said the oil could be cleaned up when the winds abate. The spill blackened the shoreline, but no seabirds or mammals appeared affected. Because the origin of the spill was unknown, the estimated $60,000 to $75,000 cost of the cleanup will be paid by a federal fund.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Launch Talks for New Government, Widespread Curfews
DOC.TEXT: With the government shaken by the firing of a Cabinet minister for alleged contacts with the PLO, rival political leaders negotiated with small parties today to try to form a new governing coalition. In the occupied lands, the army confined at least 1.1 million Palestinians to their homes in an attempt to prevent violent outbreaks. Today is the 25th anniversary of the founding of PLO Chief Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah movement. Curfew orders banning people from going out were in effect for the entire Gaza Strip and four of the largest cities in the West Bank. The Cabinet crisis was triggered by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the right-wing Likud bloc, who on Sunday handed a letter of dismissal to Science Minister Ezer Weizman of the center-left Labor Party. Shamir accused the 65-year-old former defense minister and fighter pilot of meeting PLO officials and exchanging messages with Arafat in violation of government policy. Weizman has not directly commented on the accusations, but he said in repeated radio and television interviews that other Israeli officials were also involved in at least indirect contacts with the PLO. Labor, headed by Vice Premier Shimon Peres, responded to Shamir's move by threatening to leave the government unless the prime minister rescinds the letter, which formally goes into effect Tuesday. Both Shamir and Peres held meetings today with leaders of four religious parties, each aiming to persuade the small parties to join a new coalition to replace the current Likud-Labor government. The religious parties have 12 seats in the 120-member Parliament, giving them significant clout in deciding whether the 39-seat Labor or 40-seat Likud could rule separately, along with right- or left-wing allies. Some Labor and Likud leaders sought a compromise that would leave Shamir's year-old government intact, an aide to Shamir said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Labor said on Israel radio that he saw ``the continuation of the national unity government as the need of the hour.'' Rabin added that the dispute over whether Israel should speak to the PLO ``is not a subject worth breaking up the government.'' Environmental Affairs Minister Roni Milo of Likud also said ``I believe the prime minister is interested in seeing the government last.'' One compromise idea under discussion was to leave Weizman in the Cabinet as a minister-without-portfolio, while removing him from the 12-member, decision-making Inner Cabinet, Israeli media reported. If no agreement is reached, the 26-member government could fall in a parliamentary vote of no confidence scheduled for later in the week at the urging of left-wing parties. Labor was reportedly considering supporting these motions. Shamir declined to be specific about Weizman's alleged meetings with the PLO, saying only that the minister had passed messages to Arafat and met other PLO officials. Israeli media said the source of Shamir's information was the Shin Bet, Israel's secret security agency. Shamir claimed in a nationwide television broadcast Sunday that these actions undermined his attempts to get Middle East peace talks underway without PLO involvement. Israeli media indicated Shamir was angered by alleged contacts with PLO figures via an Israeli Arab physician, Ahmed Tibi, who has reportedly visited Tunis. The Yediot Ahronot daily said Weizman had also been trying to arrange a meeting with Arafat. Other reports said Weizman had met Nabil Shaath of Arafat's Fatah faction and Geneva PLO representative Nabil Amlawi. Rabin confirmed on the radio that Weizman had conveyed some messages at least indirectly to the PLO to persuade the organization to accept peace proposals of U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Baker has called for direct Israeli-Palestinian talks as a step toward bringing about elections proposed by Israel in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Drums, Saxophones And Fireworks At Berlin Wall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6 `After midnight...rescue workers' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with 135 injured in screen collapse, 68 neo-Nazis arrested. Picks up 7th pvs, `A West ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-World New Year, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A cacophony of drums, saxophones and firecrackers pierced the air early today and fireworks illuminated the Berlin Wall as tens of thousands of people from East and West celebrated New Year's together. Tens of thousands poured in both directions through the newly opened Brandenburg Gate each hour, and thousands more scaled the wall and tumbled into the other Germany as border guards watched with amusement. In a revival of the city-wide street party that erupted when the Berlin Wall opened Nov. 9, young people scrambled atop the divide to take in the scene on both sides, bobbing and rocking to the erratic rhythm of the concert without conductor at Brandenburg Gate. Hammers clanged against chisels as hundreds mined the wall for souvenirs. After midnight, some scaffolding supporting an outdoor projection screen near Brandenburg Gate collapsed under the weight of revelers, killing a man and injuring 135 people, East Germany's official ADN news agency reported. Seventy-seven of them were hospitalized, it said. ADN said drunks and a carpet of broken glass from champagne bottles hindered rescue workers. In other border areas, police police arrested 68 neo-Nazi activists overnight after they tried to stage illegal demonstrations. Authorities in both German states had formed joint patrols to prevent disturbances threatened by right-wing radicals. A West Berlin counter-culture group had appealed to Berliners on both sides of the crumbling divide to bring musical instruments and inspiration to the battle-scarred gate, for a concert to fete the first New Year's in four decades that Germans have celebrated together. ``We just wanted to be here for it. It's fantastic,'' said 21-year-old Kerry Bundgaard of Phoenix as her father videotaped the scene. ``The wall is open for the first time in my life. We want to celebrate along with everyone else,'' said Hans-Juergen Witfeld, who traveled from the Ruhr Valley city of Dortmund with eight friends to spend the holiday in cold and misty Berlin. At midnight, fireworks filled the midnight sky over Brandenburg Gate. The soot-stained monument was swathed in smoke as young people from around the world clamored atop the surrounding wall and scaled even the tarnished bronze chariot that crowns the columned gate. Since East German authorities began punching holes in the graffiti-splattered concrete that had severed Berlin since 1961, the wall has become more a bridge than a barrier. Tour buses from throughout Europe shuttled thousands to the heart of the party, a stretch of pock-marked wall between the Brandenburg Gate in East Berlin and a towering Christmas tree on the west side. Tourists filled every hotel and restaurant to capacity on both sides of the wall and jammed streets and parking lots with impromptu parties. Enterprising youth like 15-year-old Salim Mussa hawked chips of the wall for up to $30, West Berliners rented out hammers and chisels, and the West German government operated a mobile information booth for any East German visitors considering relocation in the West. Border police said they had no estimate of the numbers crossing between the two Germanys.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Matisse Paintings Stolen From Family Apartment
DOC.TEXT: A cat burglar stole eight works by French master Henri Matisse worth $12.5 million from the family home on the Riviera, police said Monday. The works include the celebrated oil paintings ``View Over Collioure Port,'' ``Woman in Brittany'' and ``Devilacqua,'' investigators with the Nice police said. Two other oil paintings, a linoleum engraving and two pencil sketches were also stolen. Police did not immediately reveal the titles of these works or estimate a value of the individual pieces. One of the century's most praised artists, Matisse lived in the plush apartment located in the hills overlooking the Mediterranean for many years before his death in 1954. The apartment has been unoccupied for most of the past 20 years. The painter's daughter-in-law, Maria Matisse, discovered the theft Friday on her first visit to the residence since November. The burglar apparently climbed a rain gutter to a third-story window, unlatched the wooden shutters and cut through the glass to make his entry. The window was not protected by a burglar alarm. Police said the theft resembled a recent wave of cat burglaries in the upper middle-class neighborhood. The collection of works kept at the apartment are well-known and police said it would be difficult for the thieves to sell them on the legitimate art market.

DOC.HEAD: Crew Safe After Ship Sinks
DOC.TEXT: The 28 crew members of a 600-foot Greek freighter that sank in the Pacific Ocean should arrive Wednesday aboard a Coast Guard cutter, authorities said. The Vulca went down Sunday morning, 800 miles northeast of Hawaii after efforts to pump water from its two forward holds failed, the Coast Guard said. The ship was carrying scrap metal from Los Angeles to South Korea when it began taking water Thursday. The Philippine crew members and Greek officers fled unharmed to the cutter Sassafras on Saturday evening. The cause of the original flooding was not determined, and there was no estimate on the value of the ship and its cargo, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Celebrate New Year's With First Guarantees Of Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Iliescu abolishing Securitate, no overnight clashes, ADDS background and details. Pickup 13th graf `Bogdan also said...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM and CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: Romanians today celebrated their first New Year's in more than two decades free of Nicolae Ceausescu's despotism, and their revolutionary leaders issued decrees that began to dismantle Communist rule. Romanian Radio reported no overnight clashes between the army and die-hard Securitate units, suggesting a slow return to normality after two weeks of unrest believed to have claimed thousands of lives. ``The Communist Party is dead,'' Deputy Foreign Minister Corneliu Bogdan told reporters Sunday, two weeks after security forces fired on anti-government protesters to touch off the revolution that toppled Ceausescu. Bogdan assured Romanians that there was ``no danger'' of Communists returning to undisputed power. In a New Year's address, interim President Ion Iliescu announced the abolition of the death penalty and re-introduction of the concept of private ownership. He formally announced the abolition of the feared Securitate, the East German news agency ADN reported from Bucharest. Iliescu also signed a decree that provides the legal basis for the creation of new political parties _ an important step toward free elections promised for April. The decree says officials of the defense and interior ministries, judges, prosecutors, members of state radio and television cannot join political parties, to ensure their impartiality, the official Agerpress news agency reported. At least six new political parties have emerged since Ceausescu's was overthrown Dec. 22 by a nation outraged over the massacre by security forces of hundreds of people in the western city of Timisoara. The army had joined the people in toppling Ceausescu after 24 years of autocratic rule. Ceausescu and his wife Elena were summarily tried and executed Christmas Day, convicted of ``genocide'' and other grave crimes. Iliescu is a former Communist Party secretary who fell out of favor with Ceausescu for speaking his mind but has the political experience that dissident intellectuals and other former opposition figures lack. Bogdan, his country's U.S. ambassador for more than a decade before falling into disfavor in the early 1980s, told his news conference that party members were in the minority in the provisional government. But he said their expertise is needed to smooth the transformation to democracy. He said those in provisional government did not consider themselves Communist Party members after the oppressive Ceausescu era. ``I was one of them,'' he said of the Communists. ``I will pay for it,'' he added, without elaborating. It was unclear how many people were in the government, but divergent reports concurred that there were more than 20. Bogdan gave neither overall figures nor the proportion of Communists among the leadership. Bogdan also said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze would be visiting later in the week. Iliescu made public agricultural production figures according to which the year's total cereal production amounted to 16.9 million tons, instead of the claimed 60 million tons. Other totals also well below claimed amounts. He also decreed land on which farmers live and surrounding plots private property, re-establishing a concept banned for decades. Iliescu said farmers would again be allowed to sell produce and animals raised on leased land. To pay off the country's foreign debt, Ceausescu had in recent years exported Romania's best agricultural products while forcing privation and rationing upon his people. The new government is now opening warehouses and making those items available to the people. Although Iliescu abolished the death penalty, he pledged a ``tough trial'' nonetheless for ``all those guilty of crimes'' _ an apparent allusion to Ceausescu loyalists. The former head of Securitate, Iulian Vlad, was detained for questioning Sunday along with three ranking members of the ministry controlling the police, Agerpress reported. It did not specify what charges, if any, the four face. Thousands of Securitate agents surrendered after Vlad ordered them to last week, but several hundred are believed still at large and prepared to die fighting. Hungarian television, meanwhile, reported that an assailant it did not identify stabbed Nicu Ceausescu, the son of the late dictator, immediately after he was shown on Romanian television Dec. 22. The assailant was arrested, while the younger Ceausescu underwent an operation for his stomach wound ``which was successful,'' Hungarian TV said. Nicu Ceausescu had been a regional Communist chief. On New Year's Eve, Adevarul _ the former Communist daily that is now non-affiliated _ and other newspapers reserved much of their space for rejoicing, but the anticipation of the celebrations was tinged with caution. One newspaper carried a warning from police, asking holiday merrymakers not to use fireworks and noisemakers in the capital, where the streets were still filled with nervous soldiers armed with automatic weapons. Nonetheless, Romanians' mood seemed mostly euphoric. Romanians on the street greeted each other and foreigners with cheerful shouts of ``Multi Ani'' _ the equivalent of Happy New Year _ as they trudged through the snow and slush.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta, Houston and Seattle Offer New Rivals for N.Y. Tradition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `In Philadelphia...' with 7 grafs to UPDATE arrest figures, New Year's baby, Dinkins sworn in and Mummers Parade called off; picks up 15th graf pvs: `Because new...' ^LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Some 200,000 partygoers threw streamers and squawked horns as the ball dropped in New York's Times Square, while some people in Los Angeles celebrated with gunfire to mark the start of a new year and new decade today. The nationally televised lighted ball sliding down a pole high above Times Square, a tradition of most New Year's Eves since 1907, had a few rivals this year _ a foam-and-fiberglass Georgia peach in Atlanta, a Texas Lone Star in Houston and an ascending elevator car on Seattle's Space Needle. The countdown Sunday night had an extra ``leap second'' to keep the world's clocks in time with the rotation of the planet. Untimely drizzle rounded off the edges of ice sculptures decorating Boston as part of its 14th annual First Night festivities, but an estimated 250,000 people showed up anyway to watch midnight fireworks over Boston Harbor. Some people in Los Angeles celebrated with an illegal and dangerous fireworks tradition of their own _ shooting guns into the air. Gunfire was heard throughout the city around midnight. ``We're used to it. It sounds like a shooting gallery,'' said police Sgt. T. Brown. ``The dopes won't learn unless they get hit themselves. Death toll figures tomorrow will tell the story.'' There weren't any immediate reports of people being hit by stray rounds. Revelers in New York ignored daylong rain and packed Times Square, though the crowd was smaller than the 600,000 police had expected. Only 20 arrests were made this year, more than 50 fewer than last year. This year, eight were charged with robbery, two with attempted robbery, five with assault and five with disorderly conduct, said a police spokesman, Lt. Raymond O'Donnell. ``It was a very slow night. I think the rain contributed a little bit to us, to help us,'' he said. A baby girl born at 20 seconds past midnight was thought to be the first New Yorker born this decade. The Brooklyn child was born to Luzanne Small, 23, and Laxley Chin, 22, said spokesman Tom Dugan at Long Island Cottage Hospital. And in a judge's apartment the city's first black mayor was sworn in a few minutes after midnight. David Dinkins took his oath as New York's 106th mayor from his former law partner, state Court of Appeals Judge Fritz W. Alexander 2nd. Public ceremonies were planned later today. Dinkins, 62, succeeds Edward I. Koch, the outspoken three-term mayor who was defeated in the Democratic primary in September. Meanwile, the revelers at Times Square chanted in unison to count down the last seconds of the 1980s as they watched the ball drop. ``I want to party all night! All decade!'' said Robyn Rzepecki, 19, of Scituate, R.I. The celebrations continued today. Crowds gathered overnight in Pasadena, Calif., along the 5{-mile route of the 101st Tournament of Roses Parade, taking pizza deliveries and whooping it up on the sidewalk in anticipation of today's celebration. ``It's a real circus,'' said Ferris Reid of Aurora, Ill. ``But I don't think I'm crazy being here all night. Being crazy was staying back in Illinois in the winter.'' In Philadelphia this morning, the annual New Year's Day Mummers Parade was postponed until Jan. 6 because of gusting winds and possible snow. Because New Year's Eve fell on a Sunday, some nightspots around the country couldn't serve drinks. Other celebrants didn't want them. In Decatur, Ill., about 300 revelers at an Alcoholics Anonymous party drank coffee and soft drinks. ``We've got a bunch of people here that know how to drink. They just don't do it anymore,'' said one man. ``It's probably the only place in the city tonight without alcohol where people are dancing and having a really good time.'' At 90 seconds before midnight, thousands watched the outside elevator cars on Seattle's Space Needle ascend, reaching the top at midnight in a blaze of 6,500 lights. In Houston, a 20-foot Lone Star was rigged to rise up the side of the Texas Commerce Tower and arrived at the top at midnight to the accompaniment of a fireworks display choreographed to music. Police estimated about 30,000 people watched from Houston's Market Square. Folks in Atlanta built a 6-foot-wide foam and fiberglass Georgia peach and dropped it from a light tower at midnight at the Underground Atlanta mall. Police estimated at least 80,000 revelers jammed into the mall. In New York's Times Square, a small army of sanitation workers early today attacked the litter from the last hours of the 80s. ``An average of 25 tons of party hats, confetti, empty bottles, lost shoes, and forgotten New Year's resolutions have been swept up each year,'' said Vito Turso, spokesman for the Sanitation Department. In Miami, ``Feel good! Let it go! Lose control!'' was the message Chubby Checker spread Sunday night as tens of thousands of people cheered, oohed and danced to the 56th annual King Orange Jamboree Parade. Nevada resorts had an all-star lineup including comics Jay Leno and George Carlin and crowd-pleasing singers such as Wayne Newton and Dolly Parton. Tony Bennett left his heart and long-running singing engagement at the Venetian Room of the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco for a one-night show Sunday in Las Vegas at the Riviera hotel-casino. He apparently won't have the Venetian Room to go back to. The Four Freshmen performed for a crowd of 500 at what was billed by the hotel owners as the famous club's farewell performance. ``They're whooping it up, but there was definitely a melancholy note,'' said bellman Scott Cameron.

DOC.HEAD: Study to Track Response of Veterans Who Return to Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: The words of a South Vietnamese soldier hold new meaning for David Pye as he prepares to return to the country that still feeds his nightmares. The young man, who served on a night patrol with Pye, told him more than two decades ago: ``I would like to be able to lay my head down at night and not hear small arms fire.'' Pye, who runs a veteran's outreach center in this seaside town north of Boston, is one of 12 veterans returning to Vietnam this month to see if a peacetime visit will help silence the sounds of combat that echo in their dreams and memories. The 16-day excursion, sponsored by a University of Massachusetts center devoted to the examination of war and its aftermath, is part of a study on post-traumatic stress disorder _ the flashbacks, nightmares and depression that afflict many veterans who fought in Vietnam. A second group of veterans, who also will participate in the study, is scheduled to make a trip in May. All the veterans participating in the trip are counselors. ``There have been some ad hoc studies done, but they are not conclusive,'' said Kevin Bowen, the Joiner Center's executive director and Vietnam veteran. ``There has been a lot of anecdotal evidence that going back to Vietnam has a real healing effect on vets.'' Researchers will conduct interviews and tests on the participants before they go to Vietnam, immediately after they return, and six months and a year after the trip. By studying the responses over time, the researchers will try to determine whether visiting Vietnam reduced the level of post traumatic stress. Since learning he would be returning to Vietnam, Pye said he has had several nightmares _ dreams he hasn't had for 18 years. ``The closer we get to the date, the higher my anxiety is,'' he said. Pye, 43, first came to Vietnam on a troop ship on New Year's Eve in 1966. He remembers watching the ``fireworks'' for a few days before landing. ``I was, of course, scared,'' he said. Gumersindo Gomez, another veteran who will be traveling with the group, said his dreams often take him to a jungle river, where he wades knee-deep in water while the enemy shoots from the sides. ``Every night I've been having nightmares,'' Gomez said. ``These are combat-related nightmares _ the fear of being killed.'' Neither Gomez nor Pye has returned to Vietnam before, and despite the anxiety both feel at the upcoming journey, the two men hope the experience will help them exorcise old ghosts. Bowen remembers the anxiety of waiting to return to Vietnam for the first time. He was drafted into the Army after dropping out of college, and served from 1968-69. Bowen has been back four times. He first went in 1987 with a group of college professors, and since then on various projects sponsored by the Joiner Foundation. In many ways, the most profound observations were also the simplest. The country was silent. And the land was beautiful. ``There was nothing in the sky,'' Bowen said. Now, Bowen has established a new relationship with Vietnam and its people. ``I got to places where I lost friends and that was very powerful,'' he said. ``Going to the memorial in Washington was one thing. To be able to say goodbye _ to be able to do that there _ is just as important.''

DOC.HEAD: 1989 A Record Year For Manatee Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A record number of manatees, 160, died in Florida waters in 1989, and state biologists fear recent cold weather will kill more of the lumbering marine mammals. ``We're quite worried about the increasing number of deaths,'' said Bruce Ackerman, a researcher with the Department of Natural Resources in St. Petersburg. Biologists estimate at least 1,200 manatees, an endangered species, live in Florida. The population had been estimated at as many as 10,000 a few decades ago. In 1989, 51 manatees died after hitting boats or barges, and five were killed by other human-caused problems, such as entanglement in fishing nets, according to the Department of Natural Resources. In 1988, 133 manatees were found dead in Florida. Boats killed 43 manatees, then a record. Environmentalists and government biologists cite these statistics when they promote boating speed limits and increased protection of manatee habitat, issues state lawmakers could debate this spring. Manatees frequent rivers, estuaries, canals and protected coastal areas that also are magnets for the state's more than 710,000 registered motor boats. The average adult manatee is about 10 feet long and weighs 1,000 pounds, though some weigh three times that much. Gray and slow-moving, they can be difficult for speedy boaters to spot, said Lori Price, captive marine mammal specialist for the Department of Natural Resources. ``I think very few of them (boaters) actually maliciously intend to run down a manatee,'' she said. ``They're very difficult to see.''

DOC.HEAD: China Criticizes Gorbachev, Goes it Alone in New Ideological Order
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Seven months after Deng Xiaoping told Mikhail S. Gorbachev that their decades-old ideological schism was healed, Chinese leaders are privately accusing Gorbachev's reforms of leading the socialist world astray. Chinese authorities, in internal documents and closed meetings, reportedly blame Gorbachev and his ``new thinking'' diplomacy for unleashing the forces that have ended 40 years of Communist dominance in East Europe. Diplomatic sources say China was being careful to avoid a public break with the Soviet Union and other fast-changing socialist states by stressing that China never interferes in the internal affairs of other nations. The sources say open disapproval of the upheavals in East Europe would show the Chinese people how isolated their hard-line leaders have become from the popular reforms sweeping the socialist world. The authorities have taken a different tack, drumming home in recent days the inevitability of Communist rule in China and the correctness of their harsh suppression of political opposition. Privately, however, Deng and other leaders feel betrayed by the revolutionary events set off by Gorbachev, and are deeply concerned that democratic unrest may spread to China, the sources say. This concern was heightened by the violent overthrow of the Nicolae Ceausescu government in Romania. Ceausescu, an old friend of China, tried and failed to use the Chinese method of silencing dissent with armed force. Following Ceausescu's downfall, several illegal anti-government posters have appeared on Beijing campuses, among the first small signs of resistance since the military crackdown of the student-led movement in June. One internal document circulating among high officials that lays down official position on Romania reportedly cites Gorbachev's policies as one factor behind the turmoil in Romania. It also speaks of the subversion of hostile foreign forces, a reference to the West. Senior party leaders have also criticized Gorbachev in meetings convened over the past few weeks to discuss East Europe, sources say. In May, Gorbachev traveled to Beijing for the first Chinese-Soviet summit in 30 years. He said the normalization of bilateral relations, confirmed in his meeting with Deng, was of ``epoch-making significance.'' It has produced more Chinese-Soviet trade and increased the pace of talks on the future of the disputed Sino-Soviet border. Premier Li Peng is still expected to return Gorbachev's visit next spring. But the democratic reforms in Eastern Europe have revived old suspicions and ruled out the possibility for ideological brotherhood. A visit to China last week by Valentin Falin, head of the Soviet Communist Party's International Department and the highest party official in China since May, went unnoticed in the official Chinese press until he met on his final day with party General Secretary Jiang Zemin. Reports on that meeting had Jiang lecturing Falin that socialist reform must ``take the right route.'' The Soviet side had no comment on the talks, and Falin declined even to talk to the Soviet press. Foreign Ministry spokesman Jin Guihua, asked about Gorbachev's ``new thinking'' diplomacy that encourages socialist countries to choose their own paths to political reform, said the concept ``requires careful and serious study.'' But a Soviet source said it was ``very clear the Chinese are now critical'' of the idea. Sources say senior Chinese leaders are criticizing Gorbachev for ``confusing people'' about socialism. Analysts point out that the situation now is far different from the 1960s, when Mao Tse-tung accused Moscow of revisionism and the two countries split over ideological differences and leadership of the Communist world. China's doctrinaire hard-liners still believe, as Jiang said in a recent speech, that China ``should occupy the ideological front with Marxism.'' But with the Communist world in disarray, vying with the Soviet Union for ideological leadership is no longer a real prospect. Instead, China's leaders are trying to survive by staying above the fray. The future of socialism is bright, the Chinese are being told to believe, but only if China goes its own way.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Cut To Four Detectives, Three Aides
DOC.TEXT: The Green River Task Force, which once had 56 officers and support workers assigned to track the deaths and disappearances of dozens of women, is being cut this week to seven people, The Seattle Times reported Monday. The investigation into the deaths and disappearances of 49 women from 1982 through March 1984 once included several law enforcement jurisdictions but now will be limited to King County officers. The case is among the largest unsolved serial murder cases in the United States. ``We plan to keep the four detectives in the case through 1990. It is still a major commitment, but there is only a workload for so many,'' Sheriff James Montgomery said. The remains of 41 women have been found. Victims have been from the Seattle and Portland, Ore., areas and most had ties with prostitution. No one has been charged in the case. The task force reached its peak in personnel in 1986, but it has steadily been whittled down as suspects were eliminated and the trail became colder. The four remaining detectives will continue to gather information on 40 possible suspects who have yet to be cleared and process tips that continue to trickle in. They will be assisted by two clerks and a computer analyst. Montgomery said he would quickly add personnel if there were new leads. The county has spent about $16 million on the case. Other jurisdictions that have contributed personnel to the task force include the Seattle police, the FBI, the Washington State Patrol and the Port of Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Rivalry Breaks Out
DOC.TEXT: A rivalry broke open Monday between the two most powerful Afghan rebel groups after one party convicted and hanged four members of the other for a massacre of guerrilla commanders. The schism places another obstacle in the insurgents' struggle to topple the Soviet-backed Kabul government and replace it with an Islamic administration. The guerrillas also said Monday that three weeks of savage fighting with Afghan government forces have destroyed much of the Afghan garrision town of Khost. Gulbaddin Hekmatyar, leader of the fundamentalist Hezb-i-Islami guerrilla group, demanded that Burhanuddin Rabbani of the more moderate Jamiat-i-Islami stand trial for the hangings Dec. 21. ``They took a dastardly action. We didn't imagine Jamiat would resort to such a heinous act,'' Hekmatyar told a news conference in Islamabad. He called for the appointment of an independent tribunal to put Jamiat leaders on trial for the hangings, which he said were the product of a ``mock trial.'' Hekmatyar said he was ordering his own men to stay calm. ``I want to call on all Hezb-i-Islami commanders not to knuckle under to their emotions,'' Hekmatyar said. However, he warned Jamiat guerrillas not to cross Hezb territory in Afghanistan until the dispute is settled. A Jamiat spokesman said its northern commander, Ahmad Shah Masoud, ordered the execution of Syed Jamal and three other men of the Hezb party in Taloqan, capital of northern Takhar province. ``According to the report, Jamal confessed his crimes against the mujahedeen and the people,'' said the spokesman, who identified himself only as Omar. The guerrillas are known as mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. Hekmatyar has acknowledged that Jamal and some other Hezb men captured about 30 Jamiat commanders and murdered some of July 9 in the same province. He says nine were killed but Jamiat claims it was all 30. Masoud later captured Jamal and dozens of other Hezb members. Unconfirmed reports indicate that hundreds may have died in subsequent clashes between the two groups in various parts of northern Afghanistan. Both parties are based in Pakistan, which funnels U.S.-supplied arms to them and five other guerrilla factions. They have been fighting for 11 years to topple Kabul's ruling Marxists, who themselves are split into two rival factions. Soviet troops intervened between December 1979 and February 1989 but Moscow continues to arm Afghanistan's military. Despite predictions of their early defeat after the Soviet pullout, the Afghan Communists still hold the country's major cities. The guerrillas control about 90 percent of the countryside. The clashes in northeastern Afghanistan are mainly a turf war in the homeland of the Tajik tribe, which dominates Jamiat. The ethnic Pathans of Hezb-i-Islami are a minority in the northeast, but form an overall majority among the country's 15 million people. More than 5 million have fled the war to refugee camps in Pakistan and Iran. Thirty guerrillas were killed and 80 injured in the fighting near Khost, 15 miles west of the Pakistan border, said Fazal Akbar, head of pro-guerrilla Afghan Information and Documentation Center. Akbar quoted a guerrilla commander as saying 150 government soliders were killed or wounded. ``Most parts of the city of Khost have been destroyed,'' said Akbar, quoting Mali Khan, commander of Harkat-e-Inqilab-e-Islami rebel group. Mali Khan also claimed that the guerrillas shot down an Afghan military aircraft Dec. 25, but he gave no further details of the plane or its occupants. There was no comment by the Afghan government to the report, which could not be independently verified.

DOC.HEAD: New Telephone Feature Stirring Concerns over Privacy
DOC.TEXT: An ``electronic peephole'' that displays the telephone number of incoming calls is worrying defenders of privacy rights and stirring concern on Capitol Hill. But others say the new gadget will short-circuit nuisance calls and will be a boon to law enforcement. The new service is known as Automatic Number Identification, or Caller ID, and is being offered for about $6.50 a month plus another $60 to $80 for a small viewing device that flashes an incoming number before the phone is answered. Businesses love it. But privacy advocates say it's Big Brother and will lead to ``phone prefix discrimination'' and other social ills as people selectively decide what calls to answer or to ignore. ``This changes the nature of phone service. It suddenly is interactive,'' says Gary Marx, a professor of sociology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ``The phone companies are trying to create the argument that your phone number is something you have no rights over,'' Marx says. ``This service essentially says ... you don't control your phone number, we do.'' Opponents of Caller ID also say it is a device of telephone merchandizing companies to mine for gold: the names, telephone numbers and buying habits of people who make phone orders or inquiries. Mark Plotkin, a Washington political fund-raiser and liberal commentator, says using phones to gather information on people has ``frightening Orwellian implications for the future.'' ``First it's the phone number and then it's all sorts of information on the screen ... what color he is, what political party he belongs to, his religious background,'' Plotkin says. Caller ID is drawing the attention of Congress. It will be one of several privacy issues to be discussed in House and Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearings this spring, congressional sources say. ``We will urge Congress to adopt legislation to require blocking devices,'' says Janlori Goldman, a staff attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union. Heated debate has surrounded proposals to introduce Caller ID in several jurisdictions nationwide. California already has passed a law banning the service unless customers are given the ability to block it on their phones. Caller ID will begin Jan. 9 in Pennsylvania, despite strenuous opposition. But state phone regulators said Bell of Pennsylvania must allow police and domestic violence intervention agencies to block the service at will. New York state regulators refused to allow Rochester Telephone Co. to offer the service unless customers had a total blocking option. Caller ID has been available on a limited basis in New Jersey since October 1988. It was introduced in Maryland and Virginia in the past two months, and phone users in Charleston, W.Va., are ordering it now, according to Bell Atlantic spokesman Ken Pitt. South Central Bell, a division of BellSouth, began offering the service in the Memphis area in December, and expects to begin offering it in North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida within the next six months, said Jim Whitehead, an official with BellSouth Services. Nynex will offer it in Bennington, Vt., before next summer, Nynex official Joe Gagen said. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. also offers the service to its 800-number customers to enable businesses to quickly call up computerized records when customers call. New Jersey Bell spokesman James W. Carrigan said that following the introduction of Caller ID, requests from customers for traps or call trace records declined 49 percent in Hudson County during a six-month period. Statewide, the number of requests decreased 18 percent ``and we expect that to increase with the availability of Caller ID,'' Carrigan said. Caller ID also is being used by police to trace bomb threats and false alarms. And it is valued by takeout operations such as pizza parlors to verify phone orders. Retail businesses and banks say Caller ID allows them to have customers' records available before a company representative picks up the call _ even though it makes some customers uneasy to be greeted by name before they identify themselves. For the average phone user, phone company officials say Caller ID simply lets them see who's trying to enter their residences by telephone. ``You have the right to know when you answer the door to know who's there,'' Pitt says.

DOC.HEAD: New Cordiality May Turn to Discord Over Moldavia
With AM-Romania, Bjt
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The new cordiality in Romanian-Soviet relations following the overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu may turn sour over the issue of Moldavian territory annexed by the Soviets in 1940. Moscow accepted a Romanian invitation for Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to visit in January, the official Soviet news agency Tass said Sunday. But it remains to be seen whether Moldavia will be on the agenda. On the surface, Moscow is only delighted with the revolution that ousted and executed Ceausescu, who was publicly if politely chided for his corrupt nepotism by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev on a visit two years ago. Romania's new president, Ion Iliescu, is an acquaintance of Gorbachev from days when both worked in Communist youth movements, East bloc diplomats say. The Soviet president underlined the chumminess in a congratulatory telephone call to Iliescu last week, an item given prominent publicity in the Romanian newspapers. Iliescu, 59, a once prominent communist who fell afoul of Ceausescu in 1971 and spent the next 18 years in the political wilderness, is well liked by Soviets in Bucharest, who say he has a Russian wife. ``He speaks good Russian, English and French and is overall a cultured man,'' a Soviet diplomat smiled approvingly. But both the Soviets and Iliescu, who spent time as party leader in the northern city of Iasi near the border with Soviet Moldavia, must know that the new friendliness could turn sour if people on both sides of the border start wanting to unite. ``It's a key issue and one that everybody will be watching closely,'' said a Western diplomat who asked not to be identifed. ``The Soviets must be concerned.'' East bloc diplomats, asking not to be identifed, act as if there is no potential problem. ``Under the old regime, every day there was an article pushing their nationalism,'' said one. ``That will change now.'' Another expressed confidence that the borders drawn in 1940 when the Soviets used a secret protocol to the Hitler-Stalin pact to annex part of Moldavia would stay as they are. ``It's history,'' he said. ``Yes, we've now admitted that Romanian and Moldavian are in effect the same language, but I don't think the borders will shift.'' Ceausescu himself drew attention to the Moldavian issue when he said at the congress that unanimously re-elected him president only a month ago that the Hitler-Stalin pact should be annulled and ``all the consequences'' of it eliminated, possibly suggesting Moscow should relinquish control of Moldavia. Moldavis is known under Romanian rule as Bessarabia. That remark was typical both of the nationalism fed by Ceausescu's dreams of a great Romania with himself its undisputed heroic leader, and of the distance he always kept from Moscow. Ceausescu refused to take part in the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia, ignored Kremlin bans on trading with the West and refused to station Warsaw Pact troops on his territory. Once Gorbachev's reforms took hold of the Soviet Union, Ceausescu reduced relations to a bare minimum of trade. Intellectuals invited to Moscow would find it close to impossible to get permission to go. Romanian officials questioned on Soviet reforms sneered and implied that the Soviets were no liberals if they had annexed Moldavia. It seems the Kremlin's only requirement as its former satellites break away is a promise to remain in the Warsaw Pact alliance. On Friday, Corneliu Bogdan, a fluent Russian, English and French speaker who is deputy foreign minister, duly gave that assurance, following the pattern set by Solidarity and civic forum, the opposition movements that now share power with Communists in Poland and Czechoslovakia. But many Romanians perceive Communism as a system imported from the Russians who also ``stole'' Moldavia, and their resentment could boil over into anti-Soviet policies and demands for their old territory. With just a week passed since Ceausescu was ousted, no diplomats or Romanians can forecast the outcome of the promised free elections. Already, however, conservative parties banned after the Communist takeover in 1947 are re-emerging. These groups have a strong strain of nationalism. Romania's new leaders might therefore be less amenable to the Soviets, who face their own problems, with the strength of the Popular Front movement in Moldavia pushing for more independence from Moscow, and the decision by the National Congess, last week to declare the secret protocol of the Hitler-Stalin pact null and void.

DOC.HEAD: Revelers Lined Up Overnight for Tournament of Roses Parade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with winners in main categories, crowd count, arrests, peaceful night, color, quotes.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Crowds gathered overnight along the 5{-mile route of the 101st Tournament of Roses Parade, and today the sun shone on an estimated 1 million curbside spectators. Sixty floats, 22 bands and 275 equestrians lined up behind grand marshal Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, the first U.S. astronaut to orbit the Earth. ``This is a beautiful, beautiful planet here that we all share,'' Glenn said before the parade. ``I'm optimistic we can make that world of harmony we all want.'' The Grand Marshal's Trophy for most creative design went to the General Motors-United Auto Workers entry ``People in Tune with Technology,'' depicting a futuristic spaceship which rotates upward and extends into a 60-foot robot. The Sweepstakes Trophy for most beautiful float went to Century 21 Real Estate Corp.'s ``The World is Your Backyard,'' depicting a Victorian home and gazebo shaded by trees with multihued flowers as stained-glass windows. The Rose Parade preceded the 76th Rose Bowl football game between the University of Southern California and Michigan. Officials have in the past several years routinely predicted 1 million visitors for the parade, and did so again this year despite the difficulty in measuring such a gathering and indications through grandstand ticket sales that the 1990 crowd might be thinner. But ticket sales have long taken a back seat to television rights for the parade, and tournament officials said some 350 million viewers were expected as the parade was broadcast to 90 countries. Propped along the parade route in beach chairs and sprawled on blankets, overnight celebrants took pizza deliveries, unpacked elaborate feasts and fired up barbecues. Ferris Reid drove to California from cold Aurora, Ill., and spent the night at his parade-watching spot. ``It's a real circus,'' he said. ``But I don't think I'm crazy being here all night. Being crazy was staying back in Illinois in the winter.'' The National Weather Service had forecast a cloudy day, but a reddish sun rose and only a few wispy clouds hung over the San Gabriel Mountain range. It was in the 40s at dawn. Police said it was an unusually quiet night. More than 1,100 officers patrolled the streets on foot, on motorcycles, in cars and in helicopters. There were 208 arrests by dawn, most of those for being drunk, said Janet Hinton, a police spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Killed in Natal Violence
DOC.TEXT: A gun battle between warring black factions in a township outside Durban killed 10 people and wounded 15, police said Monday. Members of the United Democratic Front, a national anti-apartheid coalition, started the fighting Sunday night by setting fire to the house of a member of Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu group, in the township of Wartburg, police said. Police said other Inkatha members joined in to help, and in the ensuing gun battle, nine United Democratic Front members and one Inkatha member were killed, while 15 members of the front were wounded. Police said they made no arrests. Supporters of the two groups have been feuding for political power in the Zulu townships of Natal province since 1986, and more than 2,500 people have been killed. December was the most violent month yet in the townships around the port city of Durban, the most populous city in the province. Church groups have scheduled a Jan. 5 meeting to discuss how to end the fighting. Several previous peacemaking attempts have failed.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Calls For Decade of Peace in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino called Monday for a ``decade of peace'' in this troubled land and announced plans for a national peace conference to bring stability and social justice to the Philippines. The call came during a New Year's Day ceremony at the presidential palace in which Roman Catholic leaders also urged stability in a country fighting Communist and Moslem insurgencies and hit by six coup attempts in less than three years. Mrs. Aquino said peace ``cannot come from the Marxist left that would impose their evil and godless ways on us, nor can it come from the fascist right, whose lust for wealth and power would bring us back to the dark days of the tyrant.'' ``I shall invite the leaders of the private and church sectors to join the government in convening a national peace conference so that we can work out, resolve and act to attack the deep sources of our divisions, our conflicts, our injustices and inequities in society which are obstacles to peace,'' she said. Communist rebels have waged a 21-year insurgency and dissidents in the military have launched the coup attempts, the most recent on Dec. 1. At least 113 people were killed and more than 500 injured during the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. Key mutiny leaders, including former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, remain at large and have threatened to continue efforts to oust Mrs. Aquino. Mrs. Aquino gave no date for the conference, nor did she say what groups she will invite. Mrs. Aquino has refused to resume peace talks with the Communists until they lay down their arms. She has also ruled out talks with dissident soldiers involved in previous coup attempts. In her speech, she also made no mention of aspirations for self-rule by the country's 4 million-strong Moslem minority, which has also been waging a 20-year revolt for independence in the south. The Communists, Moslem rebels and Honasan's followers say Mrs. Aquino's hard-line conditions have made it impossible for them to join in any dialogue with the government. On Sunday, Mrs. Aquino made the most extensive Cabinet change of her presidency, appointing new leaders for finance, justice and military affairs. Her spokesman, Adolfo Azcuna, said the changes were made in hopes of improving government performance, which has been widely criticized as ineffectual. Elsewhere, Filipinos greeted the New Year with a barrage of fireworks and shooting of guns that killed eight people and injured more than 1,700, officials said Monday. Fireworks accidents triggered five fires in the capital and burned down a garment factory in a nearby province, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leaders Say Bombs Cause Backlash of Determination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with turnout, security, picking up at the 4th graf previous, `One of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX3
DOC.TEXT: Black leaders undeterred by a wave of fatal bombings and threats turned out today to renew their commitment to the civil-rights movement, starting with a New Year's Day commemoration of the Emancipation Proclamation. ``I do not sense any feeling of fear. The reaction on this has to be positive, appropriate. It has to be without fear,'' said Maynard Jackson, who is to be sworn in as Atlanta's mayor on Tuesday. ``I do sense a determination to work harder for human rights for all people.'' An NAACP official had said a strong turnout at today's ``Emancipation Day'' program would show civil-rights activists aren't intimidated by the mail bombs that killed a federal judge and a lawyer. A city police bomb squad, with a sniffing dog, searched the Hoosier United Methodist Church about an hour before the program began. Half an hour later, about 75 people were in the church and more were streaming in. Four police cars were parked in front of and alongside the church but access to the building was free. NAACP officials had said earlier that the FBI also would be on hand. ``One of the big objectives of terrorist activity is to induce fear and disrupt regular activities,'' said Earl Shinhoster, regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``I hope this would be a time to band together against fear and show the resolve to continue our work.'' But Shinhoster, whom the FBI has given close protection since the bombings, said there would be tight security at the NAACP-sponsored events marking President Lincoln's signing of the proclamation that freed slaves in the South. The FBI and local law officers planned to be at the Atlanta program at Hoosier Memorial United Methodist Church, one of the higher profile events. ``No doubt, we have thought to take extra security precautions, here and elsewhere in the South as well,'' said Shinhoster, who was scheduled to speak at a Tuscaloosa, Ala., program today. The mail-bomb deaths of U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance on Dec. 16 and Savannah, Ga., lawyer and civil-rights leader Robert Robinson two days later are believed to be linked. Two other bombs _ one delivered to a federal courthouse in Atlanta and one to an NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla. _ were intercepted before they could explode. Robinson worked with the NAACP. A letter to an Atlanta television station from a group claiming responsibility for the previous bombings said last week that two more members of the NAACP would be killed. The writer expressed anger at crimes by blacks against whites and at federal court decisions on school integration. The letter also threatened that any time a black man rapes a white woman in Alabama, Florida or Georgia, a federal judge, an attorney and an NAACP official would be assassinated. The FBI, which has been working on the case since Vance was killed, refused to comment on the investigation. Jackson said Sunday that letters threatening more assassinations had led to a ``backlash, not a backlash of fear, but of determination.'' Despite the security concerns, Shinhoster said the bombings have led to ``a coming together among those of us in the ... human rights community.'' Both whites and blacks, he said, can see that the bombings are ``as much an attack on America and her institutions as ... on individuals.'' He said the terrorism ``creates a new opportunity to forge new relationships between blacks and whites.'' The celebrations of the Emancipation Proclamation, which President Abraham Lincoln issued to free slaves in the Confederacy during the Civil War, have been sponsored by the NAACP for 70 years, Shinhoster said. Informal celebrations date from the time the proclamation went into effect Jan. 1, 1863.

DOC.HEAD: Ireland Assumes Presidency of Common Market From France
DOC.TEXT: Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey took over the rotating presidency of the European Economic Community for six months Monday and pledged support for the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. ``It's an enormous load of responsibility at this stage to help guide them politically and to extend economic aid to them,'' Haughey said. ``The Community held up a beacon for these countries,'' he said. ``That places a terrific responsibility on the Community to help guide them. Most of these countries have never known democracy. We will have to provide an awful lot of aid.'' Haughey spoke at Dublin Castle, the 13th century building that will be used to host EEC meetings during Ireland's presidency. He raised the Irish tricolor flag, and his son, Dublin's Lord Mayor Sean Haughey, raised the EEC flag. Similar flag-raising ceremonies were held in 19 other Irish communities. Ireland took over the EEC presidency from France, and will hand it over in six months to Italy.

DOC.HEAD: 10,000 Demonstrate in Support of Democracy in China
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 people staged a noisy but peaceful demonstration Monday outside the Xinhua News Agency office in Hong Kong in support of democracy in China. The demonstrators shouted slogans and carried banners that read: ``We Love China, Not Communism'' and ``Today Romania, Tomorrow China.'' They also voiced support for the overthrow of Communist governments in Eastern Europe. The protesters earlier rallied in downtown Hong Kong before marching the several miles to the Xinhua office. The demonstration was staged by the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Movement in China, which has been accused by Beijing of trying to use the British colony as a base for subversion in China. On Sunday night, the alliance staged a candelight vigil at a downtown park in support of democracy in China and Romania. Alliance chairman Sezto Wah told about 2,000 people at the vigil that recent events in Romania have given tremendous encouragement to people in China. ``The alliance is firmer than ever in its conviction that final victory shall belong to the people and that one day democracy shall bloom in China,'' he said. Wah and another alliance leader, Martin Lee, were expelled by Beijing last year from a Hong Kong-China committee drafting the constitution for the territory when it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. China has pledged to retain Hong Kong's capitalist and legal systems for 50 years after the takeover. The crushing of the pro-democracy movement in Beijing last spring by Chinese troops has raised fears in Hong Kong that China may renege on its promises.

DOC.HEAD: Precede HOUSTON
Bushes, Grandparents Again, Go Fishing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 14 grafs new with Mrs. Bush comments; picks up at pvs 5th graf, `They're gutsy;' deletes last 5 grafs pvs
DOC.TEXT: President and Mrs. Bush, grandparents for the 12th time, rose before dawn and flew here today to begin the new year and end a vacation by fishing for bass. A beaming Barbara Bush broke the news aboard Air Force One as it left Houston that youngest son Marvin and daughter-in-law Margaret have adopted a second child, named Charles Walker Bush. ``Want to hear the great news?, Marvin had a little baby ... a little boy,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters. The infant was born in Texas in November and the younger Bushes, who live in Arlington, Va., got word Friday that he was theirs' while vacationing at Disney World in Florida with their 3-year-old daughter, Marshall, who also is adopted. The president and first lady left Texas after paying an emotional visit Sunday to the bedside of soldiers recuperating in San Antionio military hospitals from wounds suffered in the invasion of Panama. The president after paying tribute to the ``gutsy, courageous young men,'' said it was ``only fair and right'' that the dictator they toppled, Manuel Antonio Noriega, be brought to justice in the United States. Mrs. Bush said she and her husband spent a quiet New Year's Eve at their Houston hotel suite, retiring by 9 p.m. without even popping the cork on a bottle of champagne. ``We had Chinese dinner and candlelight _ only because someone gave it to us _ and we were the earliest people in bed in America, I think,'' she said. ``I haven't seen midnight in in 40 years.''he said. The Bushes were returning to the White House tonight, then flying to Boston on Tuesday for the funeral of a brother-in-law, Alexander Ellis II, who died Friday at 67 after a stroke and long illness. ``We heard about the baby the day that our brother-in-law died. There's something nice about that, isn't there? It's sort of magical,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``I cried all day. I cried from happoiness and sadness all day. The first lady called Ellis, husband of Bush's sister Nancy, ``a wonderful man'' and noted he was ``the first of us'' from their generation to die. Bush, an avid angler, was to cast for bass at a private 55-acre lake in Pintlala, Ala., owned by pal Ray Scott Jr., publisher of Bassmaster Magazine. The Bushes were moved to tears Sunday as they visited the 44 hospitalized servicemen at the close of a hunting vacation in Texas. ``They're gutsy, courageous young men,'' said Bush, who praised the Panama invasion as ``a superb operation.'' He added, ``there should be no second-guessing.'' On continuing efforts to pry Noriega out of the Vatican embassy in Panama City, where he has been holed up since Dec. 24, Bush said, ``there's a lot going on and discussions about what'll take place.'' ``We want him brought to justice. It's only fair and right to these kids lying here ... and I'm determined to see that that happens,'' Bush told reporters. Panama's attorney general, Rogelio Cruz, said Sunday he is preparing to bring murder charges against Noriega for the deaths of 10 rebel officers after Noriega and his Panamanian Defense Forces quashed a Dec. 3 coup. However, Panama's new president, Guillermo Endara, said later Sunday he is asking Pope John Paul II to release Noriega to U.S. authorities because the Latin country's courts are in disarray and currently incapable of trying Noriega, wanted in the United States as a drug trafficker. Bush, after making his rounds at Brooke Army Medical Center and Wilford Hall Air Force Hospital, called it ``very, very moving for me and for Barbara.'' Many of the wounded sported their Purple Hearts on their deep blue pajamas or pinned them to pillowcases. At the bedside of Army Sgt. James Almeida of Taunton, Mass., who suffered multiple fragmentation wounds, Bush asked the sergeant's 8-year-old daughter, Noella, if she had a good Christmas. ``Yes,'' said the child. ``What was your favorite present?'' Bush asked. ``My daddy,'' the child replied. In a lighter moment, Bush narrated a home video for the brother of wounded Army Pvt. Scout Tout of Amarillo, Texas, and tried his Spanish with Sgt. Roy Burgess's Panama-born wife, Violetta. Burgess is from LaBelle, Fla. Bush, saying he is ``not too good at that kind of thing,'' asked his wife to relate an exchange with another soldier left paraplegic in the Panama fighting. ``He thanked George and gave him a flag, a little American flag, and he said, `This is from all the men in Panama and I want you to have this from them and we thank you for sending us,''' she said, adding, ``You can't fake that.''

DOC.HEAD: It Is Still a Knock on the Door, and `His Deep Regret ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Panama invasion wasn't an hour old before the telephone awakened Army Col. Mel Hoherz. It wasn't a day old before Hoherz had dispatched officers on those dreadful knock-on-the-door missions to inform families that a son or husband had died in combat. As with everything, the Army has a system for this _ and a 214-page Regulation 600-8-1 on what to do when a soldier is killed. An Army manual even tells the visiting officer what to say: ``The secretary of the Army has asked me to express his deep regret...'' Hoherz, son of a career Army officer, grandson of a German pacifist who fled to America to avoid military service, is in charge of seeing to it the process runs smoothly. ``We try to do it with dignity,'' he said in a recent interview. ``Everyone grieves differently, and sometimes they grieve angrily, in anger at the Army, and we know that, but we try to be helpful.'' Hoherz's job is to see to it that the body is accompanied to the gravesite by a soldier _ sometimes by a buddy who has been designated for the task by the surviving family. Hoherz dispatches the ``notifier,'' who brings the first word _ but often no details _ and offers whatever comfort a stranger can. By regulation, the message is always delivered in person. He makes sure that another officer follows up with the forms that will bring the family the benefits to which it is entitled _ usually a $50,000 life insurance payment plus a $3,000 death gratuity payment; the soldier's unpaid pay and allowances; a monthly check for the widow until she remarries and surviving children until they are age 18 (23 if they go to college); and Social Security benefits. He tries to nudge families toward opting for a military funeral. ``We can do it with great dignity and they don't need an unexpected $5,000 expense at a time like this,'' Hoherz says. The Army will provide a steel casket worth $2,000, six pallbearers and a seven-member firing team that fires three volleys of shots. And Hoherz makes sure word reaches the White House, where President Bush has determined to write a personal letter to the family of every military man killed in the line of duty. Panama marked the first American battle deaths since the Grenada episode in 1983, which killed 19 U.S. servicemen. In Panama, the U.S. military suffered 23 deaths _ 18 Army, four Navy, one Marine _ and 322 wounded. Among Panamanians, 297 soldiers and some 300 civilians were killed. Panama aside, the Army had 116 military related deaths in 1989 _ helicopter crashes, training accidents, heart attacks and the like and about 625 other accidental deaths, mostly car crashes. Hoherz's outfit _ the Casualties and Memorial Affairs Operations Center in suburban Alexandria, Va. _ seeks to notify the family within four hours of receiving word of the casualty. The old process is still used. An officer or senior non-commissioned officer is sent from a nearby military base. Sometimes he brings along a chaplain. No mission is undertaken between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. In these days of family mobility and frequent divorce, Hoherz says, notifiers often must do detective work to track down relatives or estranged wives, sometimes using the police or postman or utility company records. How to do it is spelled out in a 53-page manual that uses the initials ``NOK'' for ``next of kin.'' ``As a notifier, you represent the secretary of the Army,'' the manual says. ``You are expected to be courteous, helpful and sympathetic toward the NOK in this sensitive mission. Your presence should soften the blow, if possible, and show the Army's concern for its personnel, their dependents, and their NOK.'' The visit is followed by a telegram or a mailgram. Its purpose is to confirm what has been said and to make it clear the family has not been the victim of a macabre hoax. Meantime, at the scene of combat, there is a written report on the fatal event and an investigation ``if it is an unexplained death,'' Hoherz says. Families are entitled to these reports and to autopsy reports, but they must ask for them. A company commander, in theory at least, knows the people in his unit. ``If he's doing his job, he'll know them by name and well enough to know where they come from and whether they're married, that sort of thing,'' says Hoherz. The company commander writes a letter of condolence to the next of kin. It is sent within 24 hours if field conditions permit. This letter often brings the first full account of how the soldier died.

DOC.HEAD: North Demands North-South Korean Travel; Defends Socialism
DOC.TEXT: North Korean President Kim Il Sung said Monday a border wall in South Korea should be torn down and free north-south travel ensured as a step toward reunification. In a New Year's speech distributed by North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, the hard-line Communist leader also denounced what he called a grave ``imperialist'' challenge to socialism. ``There can be no change in the truth of history that mankind must follow the road of socialism,'' Kim said, without directly mentioning the collapse of Communist governments in Eastern Europe. He did refer indirectly to the opening of the wall between Communist East Germany and the capitalist West. In urging the removal of a concrete wall south of the border, Kim declared: ``Now that both the United States and South Korean authorities welcome the opening of the barrier of division in another country, there is no reason why the concrete wall in Korea should not be destroyed.'' North Korea and South Korea, divided since 1945, technically are still in a state of war. An armistice, rather than a peace treaty, ended the 1950-53 Korean War. The demilitarized zone between the two is heavily guarded, and Koreans need permission from both governments to cross the border. In South Korea, a dissident Christian pastor has been sentenced to 10 years in prison and a radical student is on trial for unauthorized visits to North Korea that they said were aimed at promoting unification. Kim said the two ``came to Pyongyang, at the risk of their lives, as messengers bearing the South Korean people's unanimous desire for reunification.'' Commenting on Seoul's insistence that contacts with North Korea go through official channels, Kim said reunification is an important question that ``cannot be placed at the mercy of a few authorities or of a specified stratum.'' Seoul says North Korea has been encouraging South Korean dissidents to visit Pyongyang to try to encourage discord. Kim said that when free travel is ensured, ``it will be possible to achieve the consensus of the will and united efforts of the Korean nation for reunfication.'' Negotiations on travel, politics, the economy and culture ``must be held without delay,'' he said, reiterating a call for a conference that would include leaders of South Korean opposition parties. ``In our area north of the military demarcation line, there is no barrier except barbed wires which mark a boundary. We can remove them anytime,'' Kim said. Talks so far on easing tensions and working toward reunification have made little progress, with each side insisting on its own proposals. In Seoul, South Korean Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon said he expects arms control talks between the two nations will be possible in the mid-1990s, the Korea Herald said Monday. ``Our efforts to achieve peaceful unification of the divided Korean peninsula need to initiate arms control talks between the two halves,'' Lee said in an interview with the English-language daily. Lee also said North Korea, beset by economic difficulties resulting from its continuing arms buildup, could not continue to ignore the democratric reforms sweeping Eastern Europe and may be forced to come out of isolation. In his remarks on the international scene, Kim said ``the imperialists are making frantic efforts to undermine socialism.'' ``Recently, the U.S. imperialists declared before the world the end of the cold war and the advent of an era of peace, but this was immediately followed by their open invasion against Panama, a sovereign state. This shows clearly that `peace' and `detente' claimed by the imperialists is a big deception and that they are outrageous aggressors.'' Kim said ``the road to socialism is an untrodden path. Therefore, in the course of advance one may encounter unexpected incidents and undergo trials and tribulations. The way of building socialism should also be steadily improved and perfected in keeping with the change in the situation. But there can be no change in the truth of history that mankind must follow the road of socialism.'' Japanese radio monitors said that in Kim's New Year messages to other leaders, North Korea gave first place to China instead of the Soviet Union. Like Kim, Chinese leaders have vowed not to deviate from socialism. North Korean media did not mention messages to East Germany, Romania, Hungary and Yugoslavia, although messages to those East European countries have been prominently mentioned in past years.

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup of Springfield Superfund Site Moves Closer to Completion
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: One of the latest Superfund successes felt like a long wait to Ralph Bidgood, whose four-year ordeal began the night he discovered some people probing the dirt behind his mobile home. ``There were people in white suits and rubber gloves and rubber boots walking around and I started wondering what was going on,'' Bidgood said. He found that his home sat atop a toxic waste dump that had been oozing arsenic, benzene, cyanide and lead into drinking wells and the nearby Black River and Seavers Brook for up to 40 years. An EPA official termed the site ``a chemical time bomb'' and said it was the only Superfund site in New England that had people living on top of it. Bidgood's ordeal is over. On Friday, his trailer _ like 33 others in the park _ was purchased by the polluters and Bidgood moved to an apartment. Three remaining trailers will soon be purchased. ``This is the first and probably the only site in New England that involves permanent relocation of residents,'' said Paul Keough, acting regional administrator for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. He termed the site a time bomb in 1988, well after it was added to the Superfund list in 1982. In an agreement announced last month, four parties _ Springfield, Emhart Industries Inc., Textron Inc. and Browning-Ferris Industries _ have admitted liability for the pollution and agreed to pay the EPA $1.75 million. The site was once a town landfill. They also will provide millions to build a pipeline system to collect the seepage and a treatment plant to remove the chemicals, Town Manager William Steele said. The treatment and monitoring will continue for 30 years. The companies also set up a trust fund to buy the mobile homes. The total cleanup cost could reach $15 million, Keough said. He said he could not estimate how much of that would be federal money, nor could he say how much in federal funds has been spent so far. The EPA also has identified nine other parties that may be held liable for the pollution. That investigation is continuing. Although the EPA has been criticized by state and local officials for the long process, most officials agree that a settlement probably would not have been reached without its involvement. ``The potentially responsible parties would like to pretend that those dumps don't exist at all,'' said former U.S. Sen. Robert Stafford of Vermont, who drafted the Superfund legislation while chairman of the Committee on Environment and Public Works. ``They won't do anything until the EPA gets after them.'' The federal Superfund program cleans toxic waste dumps around the country. A 1985 reauthorization of the program set aside $8.5 billion for the cleanups. The EPA's National Priorities List currently names about 1,250 hazardous waste sites. The EPA tries to get polluters to pay for the cleanups. Nationally, it has collected more than $1 billion in cleanup expenses. Springfield, a town of about 10,000 in southeastern Vermont, was dominated by its machine tools industry for about 150 years. From 1946 to 1968, those factories dumped their industrial waste in the town landfill, which was built on eight acres on a hill overlooking the town. ``Everything was done according to the environmental regulations at the time,'' Steele said. ``The whole thing was done with the idea, `Well, let's do something environmentally sound. Rather than dump it in the river, let's put it in this landfill.''' After the dump reached capacity and closed, it ultimately was used as a mobile home park beginning in 1971, about the same time that surrounding residents began complaining of odor and discoloration of their well water. ``They studied the problem for eight years,'' Steele said. ``There was a perception that the EPA was taking too long.'' Keough said the lengthy process is necessary and added that the EPA's cautious and expensive pace may even encourage polluters to admit liability. ``I think there's a feeling in the private sector that they can do it quicker and cheaper than the federal government,'' Keough said. ``It's to their advantage to get on board early.'' Bidgood, 43, moved to the site several years after it was put on the Superfund list but said he didn't know that until several years later when he saw the environmental inspectors digging in his yard. Bidgood settled with the polluters for $31,000. While packing his belongings Thursday, he vowed not to release the polluters from any future liability if he gets ill. ``I'm not really scared about it, but I'm not signing off on it,'' he said. ``I just want to get out of here.''

DOC.HEAD: The Bells of St. Basil's Ring for First Time Since 1922
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: The bells of St. Basil's Cathedral rang out over Red Square Monday for the first time since 1922, when the atheist Soviets clamped down on the operations of the Russian Orthodox church.
