More than 100,000 Muscovites poured into the vast square more often used military parades, and streamed past the Kremlin and the mausoleum of Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin to gather around the colored cupolas of St. Basil's for several bell concerts on New Year's Day. ``It's a surprise for the heart,'' said a middle-aged woman with a wistful smile. ``It's like visiting the past,'' said Victor Kisin, a member of the Soviet parliament, who leaned against a lamp post listening to the discordant song. The crowd covered all ages, from toddlers bundled against the cold to elderly women wrapped in traditional flowered Russian headscarves, listening raptly to the bells as they throbbed and occasionally clanked. When the scheduled 15-minute concert was completed, the crowd clapped until bell master Ivan Danilov continued with two encores. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, authorities have dramatically reduced harassment of religious believers. Thousands of churches, mosques, and other religious buildings, which had been converted into museums, cabbage warehouses, offices and even a swimming pool, are being returned to their original uses. St. Basil's is still a museum of architecture. Completed in 1560, its brilliantly colored, fanciful onion domes are a world-famous symbol for the Soviet Union. Its religious use was reduced in 1922 when it was downgraded from a cathedral to a church, and religious operations ceased entirely in 1929, museum officials said. While many Soviets are rediscovering religion, the audience for Monday's bell concert reflected the fact that after decades of suppression, most Soviets view religion more with curiosity than with fervor. ``Such traditions are wonderful,'' said one woman, lamenting the decades during which the bells were silent. Once, she said, Moscow had 40 cathedrals and their bells gave the city its character. ``We lost our roots,'' added Victor Moiseyenko, who brought his toddler, Irina, to the cathedral so she might find them. Whipping in the wind in the background were bright blue and white banners containing snowflakes and holiday greetings. New Year's decorations this year were remarkably free of the usual political slogans.

DOC.HEAD: US Wary as Cuba Assumes Prized UN Seat
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Cuba is beginning the new year on an upbeat note after a string of setbacks as it assumes a U.N. Security Council seat for the first time since the 1959 revolution. Some U.S. officials are concerned that Cuba's election to a council seat will give President Fidel Castro new leverage for influencing council debates and promoting anti-American policies. But more optimistic officials believe Cuba may feel constrained in its new role to diminish its alleged support for leftist rebels in El Salvador. Cuba will assume its seat as the United Nations gears up to send a peacekeeping force to Central America to ensure that rebel forces such as the Salvadoran insurgency do not receive outside assistance. In response to American criticism, Cuba contends that no country tramples on U.N. principles more relentlessly than the United States. As Cuba sees it, the invasion of Panama is just the latest example of the U.S. interventionism. After the invasion, there were large demonstrations in front of the American diplomatic mission in Havana. Cuba's accession to a Security Council seat is a bright spot in an otherwise-bleak period for the island nation. Cuba had close ties with all of the governments in Eastern Europe that have been forced out in recent months. Ideologically, Cuba has never been more isolated. The ouster of Panama's Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was also seen as a loss for Cuba because the leaders of both countries had a shared hostility for the United States. U.S. officials are particularly disappointed over Cuba's elevation to a council seat because other Latin American countries rallied behind Cuba's candidacy last year over U.S. objections. U.N. tradition holds that the election of a given country is automatic if it receives the endorsement by consensus of other countries from the same region. The United States tried to encourage other hemispheric countries to oppose Cuba's candidacy. Several tested the waters but dropped out, leaving Cuba uncontested. On the other hand, the administration did block a movement in the Organization of American States in the fall to allow the Cuban government to reclaim its OAS seat. Cuba was expelled from the OAS in the early 1960s. A State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Latin Americans yielded to Castro's U.N. candidacy because ``they were unwilling to take on the guy who can make trouble for them and intimidate them.'' Gillian Gunn, an associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, offered a more charitable explanation. Ms. Gunn, who visited Cuba in November, said Cuba's image in the hemisphere was enhanced during the crucial period in the first half of 1989 when the issue of who would win the council seat was being decided. Cuba's improved standing was the result of its decision in December 1988 to withdraw its troops from Angola and Castro's attendance at three Latin American presidential inaugurations in late 1988 and early 1989, she said. Castro's presence implied respect for democratic processes in the hemisphere. American officials were disappointed that Latin American and Caribbean democracies _ now the overwhelming majority _ would rally behind an unelected president for one of the 10 non-permanent Security Council seats. But there was some sentiment in the hemisphere that Cuba deserved the seat after having been systematically excluded for more than 30 years. In addition, a Latin American president told a U.S. diplomat privately that Castro is likely to behave more moderately if he is treated as a member of the club rather than as an outcast. But, said Otto Reich, a former U.S. ambassador to Venezuela, the Latin Americans are wrong to think that Castro is no longer a threat. ``They are engaging in a bit of self-deception by thinking that he has,'' Reich said.
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Gedda has reported on foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lanka To Negotiate On Indian Troop Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: Sri Lanka will negotiate with India this week to speed up the withdrawal of Indian peacekeeping troops, a Foreign Ministry official said Monday. The pullout had been scheduled for Sunday but was delayed until March 31 after V.P. Singh replaced Rajiv Gandhi as India's prime minister in December. Foreign Secretary Bernard Tillekeratne will fly to New Delhi on Tuesday to start the discussions, the Foreign Ministry official said. Depending on how the talks go, Foreign Minister Ranjan Wijeratne may join Tillekeratne in the Indian capital on Thursday, the official added, speaking on condition of anonymity. In New Delhi, however, a spokesman for the Indian Foreign Ministry said no dates for the talks had been fixed. The Indian spokesman, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said he expected Wijeratne to arrive about Friday. The Sri Lankan official said there have been ``positive responses from New Delhi'' that India might speed up its March 31 deadline for pulling out the last members of the peacekeeping force, the official said. But the Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman said: ``I don't know, really, what they're basing that on.'' The Indian government invited both Wijeratne and Tillekeratne, who is the second-highest official in Sri Lanka's Foreign Ministry, to New Delhi for talks this week, Indian officials in Colombo and New Delhi said. In September, India and Sri Lanka agreed the Indian troops would leave by 1990. But India said the pullout would take longer after Singh took office. Indian Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral said the withdrawal should be completed by March 31. Sri Lanka says it wants the deadline moved up so it can be host of a seven-nation summit of South Asian leaders in early April. Colombo was scheduled to be the venue for the 1989 summit of the South Asia Association for Regional Cooperation, but President Ranasinghe Premadasa refused to be host while foreign troops remained in his country. Indian soldiers were sent to Sri Lanka in July 1987 under an accord signed by Gandhi and Premadasa's predecessor, Junius R. Jayewardene. The peace pact was designed to end a revolt by Tamil guerrillas who sought to create a separate homeland for their ethnic minority in northeastern Sri Lanka. India initially deployed only 2,000 men to supervise a surrender of arms by Tamil fighters. But the largest Tamil militia reneged on the pact and started fighting the Indians. New Delhi's involvement in the internal affairs of its small neighbor escalated, with the peacekeeping force numbering about 100,000 men at its peak. In 1989, Indian troops withdrew in phases from six of the eight districts where they had been based. An estimated 25,000 remain. India got involved in Sri Lanka because of pressure from its politically powerful Tamil minority who sympathized with fellow Tamils in Sri Lanka. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The island's government and military are controlled by the Sinhalese, who account for 75 percent of the population. At least 17,000 people have been killed since the Tamil insurrection began in 1983. About 11,000 people, including 1,100 Indian soldiers, were killed in the northeast where most Tamils live.

DOC.HEAD: Pontiff Celebrates World Peace Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th pvs, `Monsignor Piero...' to CORRECT that Panamanian government sted Vatican asking for Noriega; picks up 10th pvs, ``The ousted ...''
DOC.TEXT: Hailing 1989 as ``so rich in profound changes,'' Pope John Paul II on Monday dedicated the first day of the new year to peace and the triumph of life over violence and revenge. The Roman Catholic leader, after a midmorning New Year's Day Mass in St. Peter's Basilica, shed his gold-embroidered robes and miter for a red cape and white skullcap and came out under a chilly noon sun onto his balcony overlooking St. Peter's Square. Listening to his prayer were tens of thousands of people who filled the cobblestone square, made festive with a 100-foot, tinsel-draped tree from Austria. The pope spoke of the ``the contemporary world's expectations for peace, the expectations of our days so full of significant deeds, so rich in profound changes.'' He also cited ``the intense desire that justice and love prevail over all the temptations toward violence, revenge and corruption.'' The Polish-born pontiff noted the start of the millennium's last decade, by praying: ``Let us ask God to help us ... construct the hoped-for civilization of love.'' He also noted that in these times ``we feel with growing evidence how important are, and how high the cost is of, the rights and values of solidarity between nations.'' There was no mention of specific world conflicts in his prayer from the balcony nor during his homily during Mass. Monsignor Piero Pennacchini, a Vatican spokesman, said the Holy See had no comment Monday on word out of Panama that the Panamanian government will ask the Vatican embassy there to hand over Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The ousted Panamanian military ruler took refuge in the Vatican's mission in Panama City Dec. 24, and the United States and the Holy See have been negotiating over his fate. President Bush wants the Vatican to turn over Noriega so he can be tried on U.S. charges of drug trafficking. During his balcony appearance, John Paul expressed the wish that governments worldwide would ``dedicate themselves to the cause of peaceful co-existence, of respect for civil rights and fundamental liberties.'' In the late 1960s, Paul VI began designating the first day of the year as ``World Peace Day,'' and this year's theme was the environment. ``Indeed, peace requires a particular responsibility of man for all creation,'' John Paul said in his sermon during morning Mass. The pope said the commandment, ``Thou shalt not kill'' also applied to abortion and to the following ``methods of struggle: violence, terrorism, war, mass extermination.''

DOC.HEAD: Doc Dying of AIDS _ Who's to Blame?
LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Veronica Prego had everything to look forward to at the age of 25 as she embarked on a medical career. Until, she says, she pricked her finger with an AIDS-contaminated needle and the future came crashing down. Seven years later, Prego's $175 million negligence lawsuit is going to trial Tuesday, while she fights to survive the ravages of AIDS. Prego's lawyer, Diane Wilner, says Prego sued Kings County Hospital, its parent agency, the city and two doctors to ensure that other doctors are protected. It's her No. 1 priority _ at least, on the days that she's not being rushed to an emergency room with AIDS-related maladies. ``She will die from it _ that's a fact,'' said Wilner. ``The only question is when.'' But there are many other questions _ about how Prego contracted the disease, about how much a hospital should do to protect workers from AIDS. The case is ``terribly important'' because it could set a precedent that hospitals are liable when an employee is infected, said Larry Gostin, associate professor of health law at the Harvard School of Public Health and executive director of the American Society of Law and Medicine. Even before the trial, there has been sensationalism. There have been charges that the defendants' lawyers stalled so Prego would die before the case went to trial. The state attorney general's office subpoenaed her sympathy cards to ferret out sympathetic jurors. In legal briefs, lawyers for the Health and Hospitals Corp., which operates city hospitals, have complained about newspapers' ``sleazy'' reporting on the case, charging that they printed ``propaganda'' without regard to the truth. It comes down to what a jury will believe happened in January 1983. Prego was a medical school graduate working under a licensed physician in preparation for a hospital internship. She says she was cleaning up after an intern, Dr. Joyce Fogel, when she reached into a tangle of gauze and bed linens in which Fogel had ``negligently and improperly'' left a bloody needle. The hospital's side: ``Dr. Fogel has stated adamantly that she wasn't present when the blood was drawn and did not cause the injury _ she wasn't there,'' said Fred Winters, spokesman for Health and Hospitals. ``There are two different versions of how Dr. Prego received her injury,'' said Winters. The defense has refused to elaborate. Wilner said Prego reported her injury because the needle had been used to draw blood from a known AIDS patient. ``The powers that be assured her there were no reports of a health care worker getting AIDS through occupational exposure. At that time, that may very well have been a true statement,'' Wilner said. Prego argues that the hospital failed to provide puncture-resistant containers for contaminated needles. Winters said HHC hospitals were ``in the forefront of following the known precautions'' against AIDS transmission at the time. In 1985, Prego tested positive for exposure to the AIDS virus when she agreed to take part in a study on the incidence of the virus among health-care workers. Prego says the researcher, Dr. Sheldon Landesman of the State University of New York, told hospital personnel she was infected, even though she had been promised the results were confidential. He has denied any breach of confidentiality, but she has sued him as well. In November 1987, Prego was diagnosed as having AIDS. She completed a fellowship from home and now works on research when her health permits. Despite her illness, she intends to testify at trial. She is not available for interviews. The Centers for Disease Control has documented 19 cases, and are investigating several others, of health workers who contracted the virus at work. Twelve of them were stuck by needles, said CDC spokesman Chuck Fallis. Kings County Hospital and the HHC say they acted prudently to protect employees from AIDS. They argue that Prego's should be a worker's compensation case. Prego has said she fears the city ``wants me to die'' before trial can start. Hospital officials vehemently deny that. ``We have taken every step we can to expedite Dr. Prego's case so that she will have an opportunity to pursue her claim,'' said Winters. He said the hospital had waived a procedure that would have delayed the trial another year.

DOC.HEAD: Parties Announce Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files; raises reference to marathon talks to 3rd graf; deletes outdated material below
DOC.TEXT: Labor and industry officials today announced tentative settlement of the bitter, nine-month Pittston Coal strike that has idled 1,700 miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. ``We came to what I really believe is a ... reasonable solution to both sides. It is fair and it is honorable,'' special mediator W.J. Usery said at a news conference in the office of Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. Agreement was reached in the first hours of 1990 following six days of marathon negotiations. United Mine Workers President Richard Trumka said it is too early to say when the miners will return to work and that they would first have to ratify the agreement. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed, with both sides saying they wanted the miners to hear details from their leaders. Trumka said the specifics should be in the hands of the rank and file within eight to 10 days. Both sides they were happy with the agreement. ``We just couldn't be happier to stand before you today _ We think we've met the essential objectives of all those concerned,'' said Pittston Co. Chairman Paul W. Douglas. Mrs. Dole said one of the most difficult issues was ``the long-term security'' of the pension and health care benefits for the miners and their families. Pittston had balked at continuing payments into a pension fund, a move that had preciptated the walkout. Mrs. Dole said she will appoint a commission to ``review all aspects of the pension and health-care issue and make recommendations to me for dealing with it.'' She said the commission would report to her within six months. Trumka stressed the commission was not part of the settlement and said the provisions for resolving the dispute over Pittston payments did not involve any type of interim arrangment. ``The funds issue has been settle between Pittston and the United Mine Workers,'' the union president said. The strike, which was punctuated by large labor rallies, vandalism and rock-throwing confrontations between strikers and other company workers, began April 5. Organized labor rallied around the strike, with some 46,000 coal workers in 10 states walking off their jobs in sympathy strikes at one point. In Charleston, West Virginia Gov. Gaston Caperton said, ``I think that it's the greatest way we could start the new year. This has been a very long strike and a very difficult strike for the miners and their families.'' Both sides had been under a gag order during the talks at a downtown Washington hotel. Usery, a former labor secretary, had said he hoped to reach a tentative settlement by New Year's Day. The union workers struck in April after Pittston decided to end contributions to the UMW retirement and health plans for some 130,000 workers. The union said the decision could cause other coal companies to follow suit and retired miners would lose their benefits. Pittston, the nation's largest coal exporter, says it cannot afford the payments because it faces high costs to ship its coal overseas. The UMW also said job security was threatened because Pittston had refused to go along with an industry agreement to give laid-off workers the first chance at new job openings. The UMW raised a strike fund of more than $100 million, giving striking workers about $200 a week to live on, plus a Christmas bonus. Miners normally earn up to $635 a week. The union also is facing fines of $63.5 million for violating court orders limiting picketing and other strike activities. Pittston hired replacement workers, but production has been well below pre-strike levels. The company reported its coal operations lost $3.6 million in the second quarter of 1989 and $9.8 million in the third quarter, compared with profits of $9 million and $7.4 million in the respective quarters of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: James, Elizabeth Most Popular Names for 1989 British Babies
DOC.TEXT: James and Elizabeth, the names of British kings and queens, were the most popular names for babies born in 1989, according to the social editor of the Times of London newspaper. Of the 2,780 boys whose births were announced in the newspaper last year, 392 had James as one of their names, 120 ahead of the runner-up, William, said social editor Helen Beard. Of the 2,645 birth announcements for girls, 254 had Elizabeth among their names, 106 ahead of the second most popular choice, Charlotte, she said. Of the first names chosen, James was also the most popular for boys, as it has been every year since 1964, Ms. Beard wrote in her annual letter to the editor outlining parents' selections. James was followed by Thomas, William, Alexander, Edward, Charles, Oliver, George, Robert and Henry. Elizabeth was only the 10th most popular choice as a first name for girls, the newspaper reported. Charlotte was the top choice, a position acquired in 1983 but surrendered to Emma and Alice in 1987 and 1988 respectively. Charlotte was followed by Emily, Sophie, Emma, Alice, Olivia, Alexandra, Katherine, Lucy and then Elizabeth. Britain has had two queens named Elizabeth, including the current monarch, Elizabeth II, and two King James. William, Edward, Charles, George, Henry, Charlotte, Alice and Alexandra are also names associated with the royal family past and present.

DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Restoration Recalls End of Prague Spring
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Gene Kramer, a member of The Associated Press staff in Washington, was the AP's Prague correspondent in 1968-72.

Week after week, despairing Czechoslovaks saw the tormented face of once-jaunty Alexander Dubcek on television imploring calm and discipline while he waged a losing struggle to salvage some freedoms of the 1968 ``Prague Spring.'' That was in occupied Czechoslovakia after Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops invaded nearly 22 years ago. Dubcek faded from view in late 1969 and was seldom mentioned publicly during a politically grim ``Prague Winter'' that lasted a generation. Czechoslovakia's political winter is ending now with a dramatic, Soviet-blessed peaceful rollback of hardline communist rule. Last Thursday, Dubcek was elected chairman of the federal assembly, restoring him to honor and position after two decades in political oblivion. Also, dissident playwright Vaclav Havel was elected president of the republic, Czechoslovakia's first non-communist state chief since Eduard Benes resigned in 1948. Dubcek's return to official life at age 68 is regarded as historic justice in a country that made him one of communism's few idolized party leaders. There even were Dubcek fan clubs after the Soviet invasion. But popular demands for multi-party democracy suggest Czechoslovaks will not settle now for what Dubcek offered 22 years ago _ ``socialism with a human face.'' Dubcek said in 1968 he wanted to transform Czechoslovakia's hardline, Stalinist system into a kinder, gentler form of communist rule that permitted free assembly and speech. He said the communists should preserve their monopoly of power not through repression but by earning the right to lead. Dubcek, ousted from party leadership and later from membership, has not said whether he will seek reinstatement. A prominent Czechoslovak-American, Ohio State University historian and journalism professor Jiri Hochman, said the Communist Party ``has become irrelevant and Dubcek must know it.'' But, he said, ``knowing him I would guess he would like to get back'' in the party. ``Prague Spring'' euphoria in Czechoslovakia was marked by a series of cliff-hanging facedowns between the Dubcek camp and forces headed by Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev. Dubcek argued that reforms would rejuvenate rather than weaken communism. Even after the Soviet invasion, popular outrage in Czechoslovakia enabled the Dubcekites to hang on for months of struggle to preserve some freedoms. Support for Dubcek upset Soviet plans to install a puppet government and prompted the Kremlin to bring Dubcek, Prime Minister Oldrich Cernik and other arrested Prague leaders to Moscow to negotiate their resumption of office and a forced program of ``normalization.'' With a new slogan of ``We Are With You, Be With Us,'' the haggard, sad-faced Dubcek made frequent television appearances cautioning his countrymen not to provoke the Soviets. He often broke the bad news about ``normalization measures'' that included ouster of popular leaders, ``temporary'' basing of Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia and restored censorship. Some critics say today that Dubcek gave in too easily, failing to exploit his own popularity and the country's solidarity. Dubcek never once drew a line on the rollback and warned the Soviets not to cross it, said Dr. Jiri Kotas, a Czech who has lived in exile in Canada since 1979 and is organizing a conservative party to enter Czechoslovakia's promised free elections in June. The Kremlin slowly achieved the results Brezhnev sought. Some said the Prague Spring really ended with the ``ice hockey riots'' in March 1969. Czechoslovakia's victory over the Soviet Union in a semifinal match at the Stockholm world championships unleashed pent-up Czechoslovak political feelings. Dancing in the snow-covered streets turned into anti-Soviet rioting. Moscow branded the episode a serious provocation and threatened to redeploy military force against civilians. Dubcek went on television with ``an urgent request for peace and discipline.'' On April 17, 1969, hardliner Gustav Husak replaced him as party chief and Dubcek was demoted to federal assembly chairman, ironically the same post he reassumed Thursday. In December 1969, Dubcek was sent as ambassador to Turkey. Passing up an opportunity to defect to the West, he returned to Czechoslovakia and in mid-1970 was expelled from the Communist Party. Dubcek spent the ensuing years clerking and running a forestry office in Slovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Basketball Coach, Sons Jailed After Fight Prompted by Bomb Hoax
DOC.TEXT: A brawl triggered by a bomb scare in a hotel led to the arrest of a college basketball coach, his two sons and four other people, officials said. ``This was a disturbance of major proportions,'' police Maj. Edward J. Collins said. Police said said Sunday morning's half-hour melee involved as many as 75 people, including patrons of the Marriott Hotel's bar, hotel security guards, police and members of the Florida Institute of Technology team, which hours earlier had won a holiday tournament at Bryant College. The coach, Thomas J. Folliard, 49, was charged with obstructing a police officer, a misdemeanor, and held overnight. About 1 a.m., police received two calls _ which police said were made from a pay phone in the Marriott lobby _ saying a bomb had been planted in the sound equipment of a band playing in the Cahoots Lounge. As police evacuated the bar, a fight broke out between security officers and Gregory McGiver, 24, a member of the Folliard party, police said. A police officer wrestled McGiver to the ground. A brawl ensued, authorities said. When police cleared the bar, the sound equipment was searched and no bomb or evidence of tampering was found. The two Folliard sons, who live with their father in Melbourne, Fla., were treated for minor injuries before being jailed. Thomas Folliard Jr. was charged with simple assault and obstruction of a police officer, and Kevin Folliard was charged with obstruction and resisting arrest. Four other people, including McGiver, were arrested on similar charges. They were released Sunday on bail pending a Jan. 12 court hearing. By Sunday afternoon Folliard and his team had checked out of the Marriott and caught a plane to Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Gorbachev's Greetings to American People
DOC.TEXT: Text of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's New Year's address to the people of the United States, as translated from Russian by the official Tass news agency:

Dear citizens of the United States of America, I greet you on behalf of the Soviet people and convey the words of hope to you. The year 1990 can and must bring nearer a genuinely peaceful period of world history. There are still both hesitations, wait-and-see attitudes, doubts and suspicions. But all this only reaffirms the crucial nature of the current situation. The entire world proceeds ahead. It wants happiness, freedom and prosperity. And it would be naive, senseless and dangerous to try to thwart this aspiration for a better future. We are deeply convinced that an epoch of peace is feasible. We, the Soviet Union and the United States, it seems, have already made a choice, the choice in favor of cooperation. During the Malta meeting, President Bush and I agreed that it was essential to get away from the Cold War and to abandon the Cold War instruments as well, so that 1990 and subsequent years could open up a period of genuine cooperation before us. In that case, in an atmosphere of greater trust we would begin to build a world ruling out subversive action, pressure, interference and armed invasions that do not credit either to weapons or politics. We in the Soviet Union have begun to advance towards such a future. This goal is served by our perestroika. But we are convinced that all societies existing on earth are in need of reasonable transformation. Philosophers and historians maintain that the end of any century creates a special psychological atmosphere that combines nostalgia for the outgoing year, uncertainty and even some fear about new and unknown, and invariably hopes for a better life. And still, there is a great difference between people of the end of last century and the end of this century. The main difference is that we realize that the stronger the hope, the more vigorous and joint efforts are needed to translate it into reality. I suggest making the 1990s a decade of the drawing of the United States and the Soviet Union closer together on the basis of universal human values and the balance of interests, and together with all countries ridding the world of fears and mistrust, of unnecessary weapons, of outdated political concepts and military doctrines, and artificial barriers between people and states. The year 1990 could become a genuine turning point in the efforts to limit and reduce arms. We, on our part, shall do everything for that. At the same time, our two countries could do much for further improvement of the overall moral and political climate in the world. In this case one may have no doubt that we shall bring nearer the transformation of the world and will make it more calm and reasonable. The 1990s may become a decade when freedom, democracy and equality will begin to be established on a global scale and in an increasingly irreversible way. People may say that all these are long-known truths and age-old values. this is so, indeed. But never before were we prepared so well for implementing them as now, at the turn of the 20th century. Let us work purposefully, patiently and with belief in their triumph. I want to wish good health and every success to all citizens of the United States. I wish your children and grandchildren to become happy dwellers of the 21st century which will, of course, be better than ours if we combine our efforts for the sake of that. I wholeheartedly wish all Americans a happy new year. Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Clergymen, Israelis Targets of Letter Bombs
DOC.TEXT: Police said Monday they have discovered 10 letter bombs sent from Cyprus in the past three days and addressed to Christian clergymen and Israelis throughout the country. All were dismantled by demolition experts at a postal center before reaching their destinations, said National Police spokesman Adi Gonen. He refused to identify the addressees. The booby-trapped envelopes were postmarked Dec. 27 in Nicosia or Larnaca, said postal service spokesman Assaf Becker. They contained enough explosives ``to kill anyone who tries to open the envelope,'' Becker said on Israel radio. Police suspect other letter-bombs could be on their way and cautioned citizens in radio announcements against opening any envelopes lacking a familiar return address. In a related development, police safely dismantled a cluster grenade planted beneath the front wheel of a vehicle owned by the wife of Vice Premier Sonya Peres in north Tel Aviv, Israeli radio reported. An Israeli extremist group called the Sicarites claimed responsibility in a phone call to Armed Forces radio station, the radio reported. The Sicarites are named for a radical sect that assassinated opponents in Roman times.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Invites Soviets To Look To `Peace, Freedom and Prosperity'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 6 grafs to include Gorbachev message; picks up at pvs 5th graf, `Given the'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush in a New Year's message invited the people of the Soviet Union today to ``look forward to a new century, and a new millennium, of peace, freedom and prosperity.'' In a video message broadcast on Soviet television, Bush said, ``There are no maps to lead us where we are going, to this new world of our own making. We can find our way only through cooperation beginning with a candid dialogue.'' He praised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as ``a good partner in peace'' and said, ``On behalf of the American people, my wife, Barbara, and my family, I bring you our warmest greetings.'' In a companion message sent to U.S. broadcasters, Gorbachev said, ``The year 1990 can and must bring nearer a genuinely peaceful period of world history. There are still both hesitations, wait-and-see attitudes, doubts and suspicions. But all this only reaffirms the crucial nature of the current situation.'' Gorbachev called for making the 1990s ``a decade of the drawing of the United States and the Soviet Union closer together on the basis of universal human values and the balance of interests, and together with all countries ridding the world of fears and mistrust, of unnecessary weapons, of outdated political concepts and military doctrines, and artificial barriers between people and states. The messages continued an exchange began by Gorbachev and former President Reagan in the mid-1980s. ``Given the war-torn history of this century we should redouble our efforts to forge a new century of peace and freedom,'' said Bush, who taped his message in Washington before going to Texas on vacation last week. Bush noted that ``our nations have produced'' Abraham Lincoln, Soviet novelist Leo Tolstoy, civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. and Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov. ``We have persevered as allies in a terrible war. The challenges we face today are no less daunting. But with goodwill and determination on both sides, I am confident our two peoples will be equal to the task.'' He said such a dialogue took place at his recent summit in Malta with Gorbachev, saying ``I told your president that I support the dynamic process of reform in the Soviet Union.'' ``We will work together to reduce barriers to trade, investment and the free movement of goods and ideas. In these ways, and as your economic reforms take place, the entry of the Soviet Union into the global market can be advanced.'' Bush reiterated that the United States, as well as NATO allies, ``seeks no advantage from the extraordinary changes under way'' in Eastern Europe. ``A new year is dawning around the world _ the first year of the last decade of the twentieth century. And as the world looks back to nine decades of war, of strife, of suspicion, let us also look forward _ to a new century, and a new millennium, of peace, freedom and prosperity,'' the president said.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Strike Cripples Business, Transport in Holy City
DOC.TEXT: Stores closed and buses and trucks stayed inside depots in this holy city Monday in response to a strike called by Sikh militants in Punjab state. The All-India Sikh Students Federation claimed their strike was successful throughout Punjab, but Punjab's top police official said traffic and business functioned normally in much of the northern state. K.P.S. Gill, the state's director general of police, said there had been no reports of strike-related violence. The strike appeared complete in Amritsar, site of the Golden Temple, the Sikh faith's holiest shrine. Although New Year's eve is widely celebrated in India, stores normally are open Jan. 1, since it is not an official holiday. The Sikh students federation, which functions as the youth wing of the movement to create a separate Sikh homeland in Punjab, called the strike to press demands for general amnesty for Sikhs arrested since 1978. They also demanded punishment for Hindu rioters who killed more than 2,000 Sikhs in northern India in 1984 after Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated by two of her Sikh bodyguards. Mrs. Gandhi was killed in retaliation for her decision to send the army into the Golden Temple to dislodge armed Sikh separatists. About 1,200 people, mostly Sikhs, were killed in the 1984 raid. Sikh agitation for independence or autonomy for Punjab exploded into violence seven years ago. Sikh extremists have killed at least 7,500 people in Punjab since 1982. Five people were killed in the first hours of 1990, Press Trust of India reported. The news agency said the victims included a Sikh police constable who was dragged out of a New Year's celebration at his family's home in the village of Ratta near Amritsar. The constable, Jaswant Singh, was shot and killed in a field early Monday. Although the Sikh radicals initially targeted Hindus in their campaign of violence, in the last few years they have attacked Sikhs who do not support their cause. The radicals have rarely called strikes to highlight their cause, relying mostly on individual killings at night and occaasional massacres. The police blamed at least 1,821 deaths in 1989 on the extremists in Punjab where Sikhs are in a slight majority. Nationwide they comprise 2 percent of the population. Sikhs militants have accused the Hindu-dominated national government cultural and political discrimination. Hinuds make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Border Patrol Comes Under Gunfire from Jordanian Border
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: An army patrol was shot at Monday from across the Israeli-Jordanian border, but there were no casualties, the military command said. The patrol moving along the border near the northern settlement of Hamat Gader came under fire from the direction of the Jordanian border before dawn, the military said. ``Soldiers in the patrol returned fire but later searches in the area failed to find anything,'' said an army spokesman, who cannot be identified due to standing regulations. He said there were no Israeli casualties and no damage caused from the shooting. Jordanian soldiers also were seen searching the area on their side of the border, he said. Hamat Gader is about 4{ miles east of the Sea of Galilee. Two Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded in a similar shooting attack on Sept. 16, which news reports in Israel blamed on a Jordanian soldier who had abandoned his position. It was the ninth incident on the Jordanian border since December 1987. At least two of the incidents involved Jordanian soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia Rebels Claim 4 Killed in Air Raids
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels Monday said government warplanes bombed two villages in the drought-stricken northern part of the country, killing four people and destroying badly needed crops. The rebel Tigre People's Liberation Front, in a clandestine radio broadcast, said four government MiG-23 fighter jets bombed the villages of Adua and Edaga Hamus in Tigre province Thursday, killing five cattle in addition to causing the civilian casualties and destroying the crops. ``The barbaric act is aimed at subjecting inhabitants of the area to starvation,'' said the rebel broadcast monitored in Nairobi. Adua and Edaga Hamus are in northern Tigre, about 25 miles south of the border with Tigre's northern neighbor, Eritrea. The United Nations says crop failures in both provinces have left as many as 4 million people threatened with famine and estimates at least 700,000 tons of emergency food will be needed to stave off starvation. Ethiopia's government estimates only about 1.8 million people will be threatened with starvation. Complicating the situation are two long-running civil wars in Eritrea and Tigre that have placed many people behind rebel lines and beyond the reach of emergency aid. Ethiopia's government two weeks ago said it had asked several indigenous agencies to study ways in which food could be delivered to those behind rebel lines in Tigre and to submit a report this month. The Tigre People's Liberation Front, which took up arms against President Mengistu Haile Mariam's Marxist government in 1975, controls all of Tigre and has moved south and west into neighboring provinces since launching a major offensive in September. The rebels, who also are Marxists, seek to oust Mengistu and create a government modeled after the harsh rule of communist Albania. In Eritrea, the Eritrean People's Liberation Army has been fighting a 29-year secessionist battle for their province. Rebel and government claims in the fighting are impossible to verify independently as reporters have been denied access to the northern regions.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Dead, 7 Wounded in Anti-Narcotics Raid
DOC.TEXT: Anti-narcotics police fought a gun battle with drug traffickers Monday in Iran's southeastern Kerman province, killing five smugglers and wounding seven, Tehran radio reported. The radio, monitored in Nicosia, said 925 pounds of drugs was seized. Law enforcement agents ambushed the drug traffickers as they drove through the Kavir-e-Lut desert in Kerman, the report said. Iranian media reported similar ambushes or raids last year, part of an anti-narcotics crackdown launched in December 1987. By official accounts more than 1,000 alleged drug smugglers have been hanged in Iran since then. Possession of even small quantities of drugs with intention to sell carries a mandatory death sentence under Iranian law. Iranian opposition groups and other independent organizations have claimed that many political prisoners are among those hanged on drugs charges.

DOC.HEAD: President And First Lady in Bass Country
With AM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: The Pintlala Baptist Church may have a new recruiting tool: Members get to shake hands with the president of the United States. About two dozens members of the rural church exchanged personal New Year's Day greetings with President Bush and his wife, Barbara, as the couple arrived to fish for bass at Alabama sportsman Ray Scott's 55-acre private lake. The hand-shaking took place as the president's 15-vehicle caravan, including press and security, stopped inside the gate of Scott's Pintlala estate, where the church members had been allowed to line up, holding signs of greetings. ``It was a surprise. We weren't told that he would stop,'' said one of the well-wishers, Susan James. ``My heart was racing. Getting to shake hands with the president of the United States on the first day of a new decade ...'' The church members didn't let on that this is getting to be old hat. Scott, the millionaire founder of the Bass Anglers Sportsman Society and a friend of Bush for more than a decade, played host to Bush in December 1988. Pintlala, which boasts a single stoplight, turned out its residents in force that time to greet the then-president-elect. Monday, cardboard signs held by church members and several dozen onlookers outside the Scott gate spelled out their uniform glee at getting to see the president once again, with the first lady as well. ``Good Job George'' and ``Hi Barbara!'' and ``Catch A Big One'' were among the placards. There was little in the way of comment on domestic or foreign matters, except for a sign held by George Dudinsky, a retiree who immigrated to America from Hungary in 1951 and was in Pintlala visiting relatives. His sign, with a slight flaw in grammar, reflected a sentiment from Eastern Europe: ``Hungary Love You.'' Scott invited three-time Bassmasters Classic Champion Rick Clunn of Montgomery, Texas, and Forest Wood, the founder of the Ranger Bass Boat Co., to join the Bushes' fishing party. Gov. Guy Hunt and his wife, Helen, and other dignitaries greeted the president and first lady when they arrived at Maxwell Air Force Base in Montgomery, prior to the motorcade 15 miles south to Pintlala. Hunt and other Alabama Republicans were not included in Scott's group tossing artificial lures into the water on a crisp, sunny winter day in the rolling, swampy terrain of south Montgomery County. Asked at the airport if he has any New Year's resolution, the president responded, ``Peace, a world at peace.'' Outside Scott's gate, Don Williams of Pintlala Baptist Church assisted church members in moving past security officers who frisked them one-by-one before allowing them to line up along the winding driveway. Not all the church members on hand were able to get inside the gate to shake hands with the president. Williams said time was running short and the security officers simply cut off the number as the motorcade drew near. For those who did get inside, excitement was high. Butch Moseley, who sported an Auburn Tiger football sweatshirt, said the president ``shook my hand and looked at my shirt and said, `Go, Tigers!.'''

DOC.HEAD: Body Recovered From Demolition Site
DOC.TEXT: Rescue crews on Monday recovered the body of a demolition worker from the rubble of a collapsed seven-story parking garage. One wing of the downtown structure collapsed Sunday while being demolished and worker Basilio Barrios, 36, of suburban Silver Spring, Md., was pinned beneath at least 10 tons of concrete, fire officials said. Authorities said two other workers escaped on their own and a third was freed a short time later by firefighters. The workers said they were doing routine demolition work on the second floor of the garage when the structure collapsed without warning. The building originally had nine stories, but two had already been removed. A police dog was brought in to help in the search for the victim. The collapse was being investigated by inspectors from the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Declares New Year's Amnesty
With AM-Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel, who spent more than five years in jail for his political beliefs, on Monday declared a broad New Year's amnesty and reduced sentences for prison inmates. It was not immediately clear how many prisoners would be freed under the amnesty or how many would benefit from sentence reductions. Havel declared the amnesty three days after he was elected president, capping a peaceful revolution that ended 41 years of Communist rule in this country. The New Year's day decree applies to all prisoners with the exception of those indicted for ``abuse of authority of public official,'' the official CTK news agency said. That charge has already been levied against former Prague Communist Party boss Miroslav Stepan, considered responsible for violent police handling of a peaceful student demonstration on Nov. 17. Stepan was detained Dec. 23 and faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted. Stepan and ex-Communist Party chief Milos Jakes have been expelled from the party for ``serious political mistakes,'' but Jakes so far has not been charged. Havel, in his New Year's address, said he was declaring the amnesty and reduction of sentences for humanitarian reasons. ``There are many prisoners in our country ... who must live in jails that do not ... awaken the better part of what is in every human being, and which humiliate people, destroy them physically and spiritually,'' Havel said in the nationally televised address hours before the amnesty was declared. ``At the same time I appeal to the prisoners to understand that 40 years of improper investigations, trials and jailing cannot be eliminated overnight,'' he said. Inmates of at least 18 prisons staged hunger strikes last month, protesting inadequate conditions. Havel himself spent more than five years in jail for his political convictions and is a known critic of the Czechoslovak judicial system. His decree reduces sentences for intentional acts by one third and sentences for criminal acts out of negligence by one half. Before he stepped down Dec. 10, former President Gustav Husak freed all those who opposition leaders considered political prisoners. However, opposition sources say at least six people are in jail on charges of espionage, sentenced in secret trials on dubious evidence. Such sentences will be re-examined by the prosecutor general, according to the text of the amnesty. Cases of terrorism, murder, rape and sexual abuse, are excluded from the amnesty, but all of these sentences are reduced by one year. The amnesty wipes out all misdemeanor charges as well as suspended sentences including financial fines unless they stem from a criminal act. Havel asked the prosecutor general to re-examine sentences handed down to pregnant women, mothers of children under 15 years of age, old and handicapped people. In a separate statement, Havel appointed Pavol Sitar the new prosecutor general.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Vets Feel Pain Of Vietnam Movie
DOC.TEXT: Howard Fogelman was shot seven times in Vietnam, losing all of his teeth and much of his confidence. He now lives in the nation's first homeless shelter for veterans. Sunday, Fogelman and 13 fellow residents felt the memories flooding back as they watched ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' a new film about a wounded veteran's struggle to cope. The vets praised the Oliver Stone movie as they emerged from a showing of the film, saying they identified with its portrayal of the isolation felt by veterans returning from the war. But unlike real-life vet Ron Kovic (played by Tom Cruise), who leads anti-war demonstrators and finally feels at home by 1975, Fogelman and his colleagues are still waging their own war for dignity in America. They feel they are losing. At their shelter, the veterans have curfews and other rules they say are better suited for children than former U.S. servicemen, some of whom have emotional wounds even though bullet wounds have mostly healed. Fogelman has a large dent in his face where a bullet entered, and no teeth as a result of the shooting. His last set of false teeth wore out two years ago and he says bureaucratic red tape has blocked him from replacing them. Without teeth, he has remained jobless and homeless. ``It has a lot to do with your confidence,'' he said. ``You don't want to talk.'' Drugs prescribed during his recovery from the facial wound, he said, led to a drug habit at home. He's now in a methadone program. And he suffers from post-traumatic stress, which for him means ``you could just be sitting and you see images coming on the bus or the train.'' He returned home in 1967, he said, to ``a completely different country.'' ``It seemed they were protesting everything, especially the war. It was pretty bad coming home. I'm not bitter now. In this country you've got to do for yourself,'' Fogelman said. Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said he felt angry after watching the movie and hearing Kovic say he felt he was home again. ``I don't think these guys feel they're back home yet. They still have not reconnected,'' he said. ``It's an outrage that there's not enough services and resources for the homeless veterans,'' Siegel said. ``That ending is 1976 and it's now 14 years later. We're beginning the '90s and you've got hundreds of thousands of people who are homeless and hundreds of homeless vets, perhaps thousands, and its not only in New York City but in cities across the country.'' The group included two vets, Ben Colon, 36, and Earl Beddoe, 41, who have been on a liquid diet since Dec. 17 as a form of protest for better conditions at their shelter run by the Salvation Army in Queens. ``I believe we gave the best years of our lives. Veterans should never be homeless,'' said Colon, who walks with a cane because of a war injury. ``We need Congress to remember our wounds are not healed yet.'' The veterans are asking for a say in how the shelter where 400 veterans stay is operated. They say they are treated without compassion by the staff, and note that only two of 80 on salary are homeless veterans. They are asking for job training and homes. ``It's the quest for dignity,'' said veteran Kevin Brown, 29, ``Not that the country owes us anything. But the country shouldn't forget, that's all.''

DOC.HEAD: Junta Leader Urges Rebels to Agree to Third Round of Talks
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military leader called on southern rebels Monday to agree to a third round of peace talks toward ending almost seven years of civil war. Adressing a rally marking the 34th anniversary of Sudan's independence attended by an estimated 150,000 people, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir said he hopes 1990 will be a year of peace. ``I call anew on the (rebel) movement to sit at the negotiating table for a third time to reach a peace forula accepted by all,'' el-Bashir told the crowd in Omdurman, Khartoum's twin city across the Nile River. ``The revolution is determined to make this year a year of peace in Sudan and to make the last decade in the century an era of reform and development by uniting the national efforts.'' Rebel leader John Garang said on clandestine rebel radio that his forces would continue to resist Sudan's ``dictatorial, oppressive and repressive'' military government. Representatives of el-Beshir, who led a coup that overthrew Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi's civilian government on June 30, have held two rounds of talks with the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. The latter one was in Nairobi in November, mediated by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter. Rebel leaders and Carter said the November talks collapsed because of conflicting points of view between the two sides and that no date was mentioned for resuming them. But spokesmen for the government have said that while some issues were disputed, positions acceptable to both sides were found for others. The government officials said the two sides agreed to meet again. On a recent tour of southern Africa, officials of the rebel movement urged the government to repeal Islamic law, lift the state of emergency, announce a cease-fire and abrogate military pacts with other countries. Garang, in his radio broadcast that was monitored in Kenya, also accused el-Bashir of insincerity in peace talks. ``Our experience in the talks ... confirmed that the junta does not have any program for peace and at the same time has rejected our proposals to form a broad-based government,'' said Garang. Garang, a former army colonel who formed the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army in 1983, said his forces would ``continue resisting the junta since it is imposing itself and its dictatorial policy on our masses.'' In his comments marking the 34th anniversary of Sudan's independence as well as the new year, Garang called on all opposition movements in Sudan to unite ``in their struggle against this dictatorial, oppressive and repressive regime.'' The rebels have been fighting Sudan's Moslem-dominated government for greater autonomy and economic reforms for the country's predominantly Christian and African south. The rebels said no date was mentioned for resuming the negotiations. However, government representatives said the talks ended with both sides agreeing to meet again.

DOC.HEAD: New Year Brings Higher Payroll Taxes, Bigger Social Security Checks
DOC.TEXT: The new year is bringing higher payroll taxes for workers and bigger checks for retirees as a long-scheduled Social Security tax increase kicks in and a cost-of-living adjustment boosts retirement benefits. The payroll tax is rising to 7.65 percent from 7.51 percent in 1989, meaning employees will pay $765 to Social Security for each $10,000 of earnings subject to the tax, $14 more than last year. Employers pay an equal amount for each worker. The increase has been in the cards since 1977, when Congress approved a plan to help keep the giant retirement program on sound financial footing that included the tax jump in 1990. Congress subsequently enacted a bailout package in 1983 that boosted the payroll tax from 7.15 percent to 7.51 percent in 1988, without changing the 7.65 rate that already was planned for 1990. The new year also means workers will start paying Social Security taxes on a bigger share of their earnings. The payroll tax applies to income of up to $51,300 in 1990, an increase from $48,000 in 1989. The combined effects of the increased tax rate and the higher taxable wage base mean the maximum amount of Social Security taxes deducted will jump by $320 to $3,924 for a worker who earns $51,300 or more. Social Security taxes also are going up for the self-employed, who will pay 15.30 percent in 1990 _ the combined employee-employer tax rate. The tax rate on the self-employed technically was 15.02 percent in 1989, but they got a 2 percent tax credit that automatically reduced the amount paid to 13.02 percent. In 1990, they lose the tax credit, but for the first time they will be able to deduct half their Social Security taxes as a business expense. The same $51,300 wage base applies. The wage base has gone up every year since 1971, with the latest increase affecting about 10.4 million workers and self-employed individuals who have earnings over last year's maximum. While 130 million workers and self-employed people will be paying more into Social Security in 1990, 38.9 million Social Security beneficiaries will start drawing bigger monthly benefit checks. Checks delivered on Jan. 3 will include a 4.7 percent benefit increase, the biggest boost in 7{ years. The cost-of-living adjustment is designed to offset the effects of inflation in the past year. The increase promises an extra $25 a month for the average retired worker, who in 1989 received $541 a month. The maximum monthly benefit for a worker retiring at age 65 in 1990 will be $975, up $76 from the comparable figure for 1989. The 4.7 percent benefit increase also applies to 4.5 million recipients of Supplemental Security Income, which provides a minimum income floor for poor people who are aged, blind or disabled. Maximum SSI benefits will rise to $386 for an individual and $579 for a couple in 1990, up from $368 and $553, respectively, in 1989. Since 1975, Social Security benefits have risen automatically each year along with advances in the Consumer Price Index, except for six months in 1983 that were skipped to help Social Security avert a financial crisis. In earlier years, benefits were increased sporadically by Congress, often in election years. The 1990 increase in the payroll tax rate will be the 21st. The payroll tax was 1 percent of income up to $3,000 when Social Security started in 1937. It stayed there until 1950 and has risen gradually since then. In addition to financing Social Security retirement benefits, the payroll tax also finances survivors and disability coverage and most of Medicare. The Social Security Administration maintains that the tax increase is needed to help the government build up the reserves that will be needed to help pay retirement benefits early in the next century. Social Security's trust funds grew by $59 billion in fiscal 1989 to $169 billion, and are projected to peak at $11.8 trillion in 2030, when the reserves will be drawn down as the baby boom generation retires. The higher taxes being levied now to pay Social Security benefits later don't sit well with everyone, including the National Federation of Independent Business, which says the 1990 tax increase should be repealed. ``The money siphoned away by this tax increase could be used for business growth and job creation,'' said NFIB president John Sloan. ``Instead it will go to the trust fund where it can only tempt politicians looking for an easy way to reduce the deficit or fund another pet project.'' The federation admits Congress is unlikely to roll back the tax, but is vowing to make it an issue on Capitol Hill.

DOC.HEAD: Police Hope More Officers, Citizen Involvement Will Slow Murder Rate
DOC.TEXT: After two years of soaring homicide statistics, District of Columbia police hope a combination of more officers and increased community involvement will curb the carnage in the nation's capital. ``We're sort of optimistic, and we think we have the key ingredients to turn this thing around,'' said police spokesman Lt. Reginald Smith. ``We're beginning to realize more community support, and we need a lot of that if we are going to avoid setting another murder record.'' Washington became known as the murder capital of America after two consecutive years of record-setting homicides. The city of 650,000 ended 1989 with an unofficial total of 438 killings, a record that topped the previous high of 369 recorded in 1988. Police have blamed drugs, particularly crack cocaine, for more than 60 percent of these deaths. ``We still see drugs as a big problem, but people in the community are beginning to be fed up and are patrolling their neighborhoods, serving as the eyes and ears we need,'' Smith said in a recent interview. ``We can't be everywhere, and we need these people to stand up.'' Police Chief Isaac Fulwood, upon taking office last August, immediately called upon citizens to get involved by alerting police to the whereabouts of murder suspects or when they witness a crime. While Smith said community patrols are beginning to work, police are also pinning their hopes on the 1,000 extra officers Congress and the city have agreed to provide. ``When we get those officers out on the street, no doubt they will have an impact,'' Smith said. ``We will increase our presence in neighborhoods where we are already active and improve coverage elsewhere.'' The city has an authorized strength of 4,055 officers, but the new hires will increase the police force to almost 5,100 officers. Smith said about 250 new hires are enrolled in the department's six-month training program, while a nationwide recruiting drive is being conducted to find the rest. The first new officers should hit the streets by early spring, Smith said. The federal government is footing the bill for 700 new officers _ and will pay their salaries and benefits for the next five years _ while the city has included money in its budget to hire 300 extra police. The city also will attempt to rehire retired officers to handle desk work in an effort to get younger officers out into the community. But police have already learned that more arrests won't solve the crime problem. More than 46,000 people have been arrested in an anti-drug sweep that began in 1987, but drug sales continue. The same has been true for killings. ``We're not going to be naive and say this thing is going to go away overnight,'' Smith said. ``It will take time to turn this around, and really, some sort of fundamental change in attitude ... where there is a respect for life.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: ``Outstate Michigan'' and ``political strongman'' won thumbs down honors as annoying phrases to avoid for the new year. The 1990 Dishonor List of Words includes more than 60 phrases and words compiled throughout 1989, said researchers at Lake Superior State University. ``Outstate Michigan'' got on the nerves of many state residents. ``This seemingly innocuous word grates on my sensibilities like fingernails across a blackboard ... the implication being that Detroit is Michigan and the rest of the Michigan land mass is out of the state,'' wrote Yvonne Carlson of Ludington. ``Political strongman'' was irritating to Bill Ziegler of Troy. ``This should be nipped in the bud before some university develops a new degree combining political science with physical education and weight training,'' Ziegler said. Other phrases that made the list included: _Ethics Bill. ``Congressional expression for `pay raise,''' wrote Jerry Jones of Cincinnati. _Drug Czar. ``How about anti-drug czar,'' wrote Ruth Hood of Warren. _Filmed Before a Live Studio Audience. ``The alternative is a bit grisly,'' Hood also wrote. _Rush Hour. ``Why rush? The traffic is barely moving,'' wrote Dave Summers of Holly. _All Except. ``Entirety can't have a minus,'' wrote Ben Szczesny of Muskegon. _Minor Emergency Clinic. ``Either something is an emergency, or it isn't,'' wrote Carol McLendon of Fort Worth, Texas.

Restoration of the state Capitol is going on nicely, although there's evidence the father of Michigan may be overshadowing the father of our country. An X-ray of a 6-foot-by-9-foot painting of Lewis Cass showed another layer under the Cass painting. ``There is a whitish area around Cass' head,'' said Maria Quinlan Leiby, curator of collections at the Michigan Historical Museum. ``(It) tends to look like the white hair of George Washington.'' That was the first clue. Then researchers found that a portrait of Washington disappeared after World War II from the Capitol's inventory of artwork. A discrepancy in the portrait of Cass was first spotted a year ago by William Seale, a Virginia historian who has written a book on state capitols and is a specialist in Victorian furnishings. Cass governed the Michigan territory from 1813-31 and is credited with preparing Michigan for statehood. He later became a senator and was the Democratic candidate for president in 1848. ``Here is Lewis Cass in the setting of George Washington,'' Seale said after viewing the portrait. He said he recognized the background as being from the White House, as well as noticing Cass' old-fashioned pose. The X-ray exam was a routine part of the Capitol restoration, and the painting was sent in July to the Detroit Institute of Arts for cleaning and repairs. ``There has definitely been a change in the design around the head, as there is a buildup of lead-white paint,'' said Alfred Ackerman, a laboratory painting conservator. ``There also appears to be more hair around the head, as well as possible changes in the location of the eyes and nose.'' Leiby doesn't think the work was done over a portrait of Washington, preferring to think the overpainting was done to improve a bad likeness of Cass. She said Cass' dress and what Washington wore also don't jibe. The work is unsigned, and both artists who are listed by the state to have done Cass portraits are dead. The art institute is to return the portrait this month to the Senate, mystery unsolved.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Rally Against Communism, Food Shortages
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Soviet citizens rallied over the weekend to call for the disbanding of the Communist Party and to complain about worsening shortages of food and vodka, activists and media reported Monday. In the Azerbaijani capital of Baku, an activist said 3,000 to 4,000 people demonstrated Sunday to demand an end to the Communist Party, which has reigned over the Soviet Union since 1917, and until Friday was the only legal political party in the vast nation. Only Lithuania has legalized alternative political parties. The tiny Baltic republic registered the first non-Communist party on Friday. In Sverdlovsk in central Russia, citizens who have suffered extreme shortages of food and consumer goods in silence finally demanded action _ and got it, according to the newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna. Communist Party officials dissolved an unhappy`crowd by flooding local stores with the missing vodka, prompting the newspaper to wonder where it had been all along. The anti-Communist rally in Azerbaijan was spawned by the downfall of the Communist Party in Romania and the execution of its leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, according to local activist Aidy Amirbekov. Soviet media thoroughly covered the revolution in Romania, and the national television news editorialized in its coverage that Ceausescu had diverted food and other resources from his people so he could live in style. The Sverdlovsk demonstration arose when a crowd of citizens, upset because there was no vodka to be found in the stores even with their new vodka ration coupons, gathered downtown and halted city transport Friday, Rabochaya Tribuna said. Regional Communist Party officials went out to soothe them, and simultaneously flooded the local stores with supplies of vodka. Much of the crowd dissolved when the would-be shoppers rushed off to buy the vodka, the newspaper said. But some remained behind to complain, because Sverdlovsk residents have been unable to turn their ration coupons into meat, sugar, butter and other food products, Rabochaya Tribuna said. Rationing varies from city to city in the Soviet Union. In Moscow, only sugar is rationed but many items have become impossible to find. Sverdlovsk officials claimed the vodka shortage resulted from the fact that half the city's monthly supply had already been sold when the ration coupons were introduced in mid-December. But the newspaper said events proved the vodka was not sold out. ``When people become indignant over standing in line for hours with thousands of others, vodka immediately appeared on the shelves of many stores,'' the newspaper concluded, leaving readers to wonder where it had been hiding. Soviet newspapers often repeat citizen complaints that ``bureaucrats'' are sabotaging reforms by stealing and hiding hard-to-find items. They rarely produce any evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Gabor Jeered by Spectators Irate by the Cop-Slapper's Appearance
With AM-New Year's Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Feisty Zsa Zsa Gabor, whose police-slapping trial earned her negative publicity and jail time, was soundly booed by spectators Monday when she rode her horse in the Tournament of Roses Parade. ``Go to jail, you floozy,'' some in the crowd screamed when she rode by on her Tennessee walking horse, Silver Fox. Miss Gabor was convicted and sentenced to jail for slapping a Beverly Hills policeman who stopped her Rolls-Royce. ``My mother and my sister Eva didn't want me to ride, but what the hell,'' Miss Gabor said. ``A couple of people will hate me, but I love America. I'm proud to be an American citizen.'' Her face was flushed and she appeared startled by the audience reaction to her appearance in the parade. The 72-year-old Hungarian-born actress had predicted that she'd be greeted with love and enthusiasm. ``They'll love me, you'll be surprised,'' Miss Gabor said Sunday. ``I got 10,000 cards from people who said I was right.'' Miss Gabor did concede, however, that the negative publicity of the trial caused her to have ``third and fourth thoughts'' about riding with the Belles and Beaus of the 1800s equestrian unit. ``I was afraid someone might boo (and scare) my horse. He's untouchable. If anyone boos, I'd boo back,'' Miss Gabor said. But no one saw her boo back. Miss Gabor was convicted last year of battery on a peace officer, driving without a valid license and driving with an open container of alcohol in her Rolls-Royce. Miss Gabor, who is appealing the conviction, said she slapped the officer because he roughed her up during a traffic stop. She was sentenced to three days in jail, log 120 hours of community service and pay a $12,837 fine.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Morgan Freeman says despite his formal theatrical education, he relies on his instincts in front of the camera. He took acting classes at the start of his career and recently read writings by acting teacher Constantin Stanislavsky, ``but that business of peeling away layers of skin was too murky and deep for me,'' Freeman said in an interview published in the Jan. 8 edition of Time magazine. ``I haven't found that I've had to do that in any intellectual sense. What I do, I do intuitively. It just comes easy for me,'' he said. Freeman is on screen in two major roles, the gravedigger who becomes a sergeant major in ``Glory,'' and the chauffeur in ``Driving Miss Daisy.''

A New Year's Eve peace gathering drew Ron Kovic, whose story is told in the film ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' Kovic, a disabled Vietnam veteran known for his anti-war activism, was in Santa Monica to help local peace advocate Jerry Rubin break a protest fast with ice cream. Rubin's Alliance for Survival group sponsors the annual event at the Church in Ocean Park and he fasts several times a year to protest such issues as TV violence, environmental destruction and U.S. involvement in Central America. ``Ron inspired me to get more active in the peace movement, so we're glad he could come and be with us,'' said Rubin, no relation to the Yippie leader. ``His movie is truly positive and shows what good can happen from a single source.'' Kovic and filmmaker Oliver Stone created the film that stars Tom Cruise. After the fast-breaking ceremony, Rubin tossed a large globe into a crowd of about 300 people. ``It gives everyone a chance to hug the planet Earth,'' he said.

The Dalai Lama, whose Tibetan homeland is ruled by China, said in a New Year's Day message he hoped the democracy sweeping across Eastern Europe will spread to Beijing. ``Rather than resist and go against such developments, I urge the Chinese leadership to accept the reality of existing situations and the legitimate desires of the people,'' the Tibetan spiritual and temporal leader said in a statement issued Monday by his New Delhi office. The Dalai Lama, whose non-violent campaign for Tibetan freedom won his the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize, has lived in exile in India since fleeing Tibet in 1959.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Taps, Mail Intercepts Used to Spy on Romanians
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Copies of Securitate files show with chilling clarity how a paranoid state spied on its citizens with telephone taps, mail intercepts, photographic surveillance and paid informants. The copies, obtained by The Associated Press, record 12 years in the life of Doru Pavaloaie, 48, an economist for a bus company who was denounced by a schoolmate because he wanted to leave the country. The documents detail a pervasive system of internal espionage by the security agents of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was ousted and executed by the December revolution that ended 24 years of his rule. Pavaloaie's file began on July 13, 1977, after his chance encounter on the streets with an old classmate, a man with whom he felt comfortable talking about his wish to move abroad, the lack of freedom in Romania and his demand that ``Ceausescu must give us food.'' The schoolmate, however, was a paid informant codenamed Geamparu who denounced Pavaloaie in a document that also made allegations about the premarital sexual activity of Pavaloaie's first wife and referred to the wealth of her parents and her relatives in West Germany. Geamparu identifies himself in the document as a ``former school colleague'' of Pavaloaie. ``Doru Pavaloaie does not have a job and lives like a parasite. Since the very beginning of the marriage both of them have wanted to leave the country and go to Germany to his wife's relatives,'' he wrote at a safehouse known only by the codename Rosa. Pavaloaie, in a telephone interview from his home in Focsani, 120 miles north of Bucharest, said he later began to suspect his old friend was an informer. ``I suspected him because the security services`during interrogations used some of my words when I talked with Geamparu,'' said Pavaloaie. Early on the morning of Dec. 22, just hours after Ceausescu was overthrown, Pavaloaie was among those who occupied the security forces headquarters in Focsani. Beneath the headquarters, the revolutionaries found an underground bunker with electronic eavesdropping devices, arms and ammunition, and boxes of security files stacked nearly to the ceiling. Pavaloaie said there were files on roughly half the adult male population of the city of 100,000 people. One of them was on Pavaloaie himself, and he took it home to have the documents photographed by free-lance journalist Livia Axente, who traveled to Bucharest to make the copies available to The AP Monday at Pavaloaie's request. ``I wanted to give my name to American journalists in case something happens to me,'' Pavaloaie said. He said he was frightened because army officers came to his house on Sunday, told him he could make copies if he wanted to, but that he had to return the file to the security headquarters. Inside his file, which contained three ledgers as thick as a fist, he found reports from eight informers, including Geamparu, the record of telephone taps, copies of intercepted letters addressed to him, and photographs of himself taken clandestinely. Over the years, Pavaloaie said he began to believe he was under surveillance. ``I felt something was happening with my phone lines and when I walked down the street I felt like somebody was watching me. But I couldn't imagine it was really happening,'' he said. Copies of his file include documents from the Interior Ministry's Department of State Security seeking authorization for telephone taps. One of those, approved by a Col. P. Stoica, covered the period May 23, 1979, to Nov. 23, 1979. It said state security wanted to know the names and phone numbers of the people he contacted and if ``there are any discussions with characters hostile to (Communist) Party policy or our state policy.'' It also sought to find ``the intentions of the target to illegally leave the country.'' Pavaloaie has been married to his second wife for a year and a half, and they had a 5-month-old boy. He said eight months ago he applied to emigrate to Israel with his Jewish wife, who has relatives in Israel. He noted that it was the first time he had ever officially asked to leave Romania, a desire he previously had confided only to close friends. He said Geamparu was one of those friends, a man he had known since his schooldays and who made a living singing at parties and weddings, and listening to the drunken talk of the partygoers. Inside his file, Pavaloaie said he found a document that identified Geamparu by his real name. But he said the document was not copied in the rush to photograph them for American journalists before being returned to security headquarters. The copies clearly showed the letterheads of the Department of State Security or the local security forces. The photographs of the ledgers showed them clearly marked ``Socialist Republic of Romania, Internal Affairs Ministry, Information File for Doru Pavaloaie'' with the number of the file, the volume number and the kind of information it contained. The files outline in detail how the web of surveillance spread from the original target to all his friends and acquaintances. They show the paranoia of a state that felt a need to listen to private telephone calls, read the mail of its citizens, follow then, photograph them, investigate them, interrogate them and recruit their friends as informers. The story of Pavaloaie also points to the twists in revolutionary Romania. Axente said Geamparu is a man who ``really helped'' the revolution, a man who used the amplifier he uses to sing at parties to rally the people on Dec. 22. So far, said Axente, nobody has confronted Geamparu about his past as an informer.
