He said that people are too afraid, too uncertain about the political climate to denounce Geamparu, especially after the army ordered the return of the file. The copies given to the AP included, among other things, transcripts from telephone monitoring, Geamparu's denouncing of Pavaloaie, photocopies of intercepted letters and documents seeking authorization to tap his phone. The dates on the documents stretch from 1977 up to the present. Pavaloaie said he wanted to make the documents public as a way both to protect himself and to fight against the system that had so brutally violated his privacy. ``I saw all those young children killed by Ceausescu. They were only children and we are older men and we must fight to final victory,'' Pavaloaie said.

DOC.HEAD: Price Increases Take Effect With New Year in Radical Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th pvs, `The far-reaching...' to UPDATE with reax from citizen.
DOC.TEXT: Bus fares and gasoline doubled and electricity quadrupled in price Monday under a radical plan by the non-Communist government to transform Poland's centrally planned economy to capitalism. Poles' fears of looming price increases were confirmed Monday, and Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz acknowledged hardships in coming months but stressed the increases were needed to halt Poland's 900 percent inflation to end its economic decline. ``There are no solutions devoid of risk,'' the official news agency PAP quoted him as saying. ``Above all, I would like to stress that despite the dangers and challenges, we stand before a unique chance and it depends on us how we take advantage of it.'' The far-reaching plan is intended to supplant the centrally directed economy run by the Communists during their four-decade rule. But there is concern that the economic shock will be too much for Poles, who earn an average monthly wage of 350,000 zlotys ($37). ``We're never going to be able to make it. People aren't going to be able to pay these prices,'' said one cabbie at a Warsaw gas station, speaking on condition of anonymity. The price increases come the same day as an earlier announced 38 percent devaluation in the currency to the dollar took effect. The devaluation was intended to close the gap between the official rate and black market rate. The government also plans to make the zloty convertible to other currencies. The price of coal, a major source of heat in Polish homes, officially increased by 600 percent, the cost of electricity by 400 percent and the price of heating gas by 400 percent. Rail and intercity bus passengers found that the price of tickets had gone up an average of 250 percent, while the price of municipal bus tickets doubled. Most gas stations were shut for the New Year's holiday, but drivers who needed to fill their tanks learned that the price of regular gasoline had doubled from 1,200 zlotys a liter (48 cents a gallon) to 2,400 zlotys a liter (96 cents a gallon). The price raises form part of a radical economic program backed by the Solidarity-led government that was passed by Parliament last week. Included in the program is a law regulating salary increases. Balcerowicz, whose plan is supported by the World Bank, the European Economic Community and major Western governments, told PAP that the difficult times coming were unavoidable but delays in applying the plan would hurt Poles even further in the long run. ``In the next few months we expect limitations on income, but without this it is impossible to check inflation,'' Balcerowicz said. Until now, wages have been pegged to inflation, but enterprises will have less money to pay workers under reduced state subsidies. Balcerowicz said that bankruptcies would occur as a result of the new policies, but that the move to limit wage increases might reduce the scale of closures. In August, Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki became prime minister, the first non-Communist head of a government in Eastern Europe. Since then, democratic reforms have swept the East bloc, and non-Communists have been installed as presidents in Czechoslovakia and East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Three Baltic States Start Economic Independence Program
DOC.TEXT: The Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania started their much-debated economic independence programs Monday, taking control of factories and other elements of their economies from bureaucrats in Moscow. Estonia underscored the potential of the reform by kicking off a contest to design its new currency, the krona. The newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna said the krona will be introduced next year and planners tentatively expect it to be fixed to the ruble at a one-to-one rate for interregional trade. But they plan for the krona to float against the ruble for tourist purposes, the newspaper said. Details of the economic independence plans were still being hammered out at the last minute, as officials of the republics and the national government in Moscow argued which powers would be decentralized. The Baltics, with their more recent experience with capitalism than the rest of the Soviet Union, favor much more drastic economic reforms than Moscow, including legalization of private property. The three republics were independent nations between the two world wars, until they were annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940.

DOC.HEAD: New Powers to Outlaw Religious Discrimination Take Effect
DOC.TEXT: New powers to outlaw religious discrimination in Northern Ireland came into force Monday. Unemployment among the Catholic minority in Northern Ireland is twice as high as for the Protestant majority. Under the new laws, a Fair Employment Commission will investigate and monitor the actions of employers and force them to adopt fair employment practices. Employers must register the religious make-up of their workforce with the commission and where it is out of balance with the population in the area, they will be ordered to take action to redress the imbalance. Where voluntary action towards equality fails, the commission can back its orders with a variety of actions supervised by a Fair Employment Tribunal. Anyone who is the victim of religious discrimination can be awarded up to $48,000. Employers who discriminate face sanctions that include being barred from government contracts, grants or loans.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Not Only Visitors to Florida's Balmy Shores
DOC.TEXT: Stinging Portuguese men-of-war are rubbing tourists the wrong way on the beaches of southeastern Florida. Hundreds of beachgoers have been stung by the pink-and-blue jellyfish-like creatures in recent days from Palm Beach south to Miami Beach and Key Biscayne. ``I had 20 people stung right in front of me,'' Miami Beach lifeguard Mike Hoover said Sunday. ``We're getting invaded here,'' said Hollywood lifeguard Louis DeSimone. Bruce Koski of the Fort Lauderdale Beach Patrol said the stings, which sometimes are compared to an electric shock, were to be expected. ``It's the time of year for the man-of-war, and they have a very painful sting,'' he said. The stings are treated on the beach with salves. People are stung when they unknowingly step on men-of-war tentacles while walking along the shore or when they brush against them while swimming. On Sunday alone, 350 bathers at Hollywood, 330 in Fort Lauderdale and nearly 300 on Palm Beach-area beaches reported stings. Seasonal southeasterly winds, the same that bring balmy breezes in from tropical seas to the south, are to blame, causing congregations of jellyfish along lee shores. The balloon-like body of a man-of-war floats on the surface and is easy to see but the tentacles, sometimes 25 or 30 feet long, waft in the current and are difficult to avoid. When caught in the surf, the creatures are often broken apart, but their toxins remain active for hours even after being washed up on the sand.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Leaders Exchange New Year's Hopes for Peace
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday hailed the superpowers' moves to thaw the Cold War and exchanged hopes that they can work even closer to ensure a century of peace. In a New Year's message to the Soviet people, Bush said, ``There are no maps to lead us where we are going, to this new world of our own making. ``As the world looks back to nine decades of war, of strife, of suspicion, let us also look forward _ to a new century, and a new millennium, of peace, freedom and prosperity,'' Bush said. In a corresponding message to the United States, Gorbachev said he and Bush have agreed ``to get away from the Cold War and to abandon the Cold War instruments as well, so that 1990 and subsequent years could open up a period of genuine cooperation before us.'' The Soviet leader proposed further cooperation in the 1990s to rid ``the world of fears and mistrust, of unnecessary weapons, of outdated political concepts and military doctrines, and artificial barriers between people and states. ``The year 1990 could become a genuine turning point in the efforts to limit and reduce arms. We, on our part, shall do everything for that.'' Soviet television broadcast Gorbachev's greetings to the American people at 7 p.m. Moscow time and followed it with Bush's greetings to the Soviets. Both greetings, a New Year's tradition began by Gorbachev and former President Reagan, were broadcast at 11 a.m. EST on Cable News Network. Bush reiterated that the United States, as well as NATO allies, ``seeks no advantage from the extraordinary changes under way'' in Eastern Europe. ``We will work together to reduce barriers to trade, investment and the free movement of goods and ideas. In these ways, and as your economic reforms take place, the entry of the Soviet Union into the global market can be advanced,'' said Bush, who is vacationing in Texas but who taped the message in Washington before he left. Neither of the two leaders, who met in December in Malta, directly criticized the other, but Gorbachev referred to ``hesitations, wait-and-see attitudes, doubts and suspicions'' toward cooperation. ``The entire world proceeds ahead. It wants happiness, freedom and prosperity. And it would be naive, senseless and dangerous to try to thwart this aspiration for a better future.'' Bush referred to ``a respect for human rights and the sharing of democratic values'' and praised Andrei D. Sakharov, the human rights activist who died last month during a campaign to end Communist supremacy in the Soviet Union. ``Your own Leo Tolstoy said that if our hearts are empty, no law or political reform can fill them,'' Bush said. ``These values ... belong to all men and women, through all time, and in all places.''

DOC.HEAD: Sobered by Troubles & Tragedy, East Germans Celebrate New Year
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germans began the New Year on Monday with the task of cleaning streets littered by fireworks and broken glass and repairing an economy sapped by four decades of Communist mismanagement. The first year of the 1990s will see the first free elections in East Germany's 40-year history, but it will also determine whether it remains independent and sovereign or is merged with the wealthy West German state. ``This is going to be a very full and important year,'' said Baerbel Richter, who strolled through the debris-strewn streets of East Berlin with her 5-year-old grandson, Franciskus. ``We have to be careful how we go about it.'' Freedom to travel has whetted some East Germans' appetites for the more comfortable lifestyles taken for granted in the West, while others have resolved to protect the separate statehood of East Germany against what they see as an attempt by Bonn to buy them out. Debts and declining productivity may worsen if an exodus to the West continues to drain East Germany of its skilled workers and hope for the future. At least 320,000 East Germans relocated to West Germany in 1989, undermining the economy of the already labor-short socialist state of more than 16 million people. Reforms likely to devalue East Germany's currency while boosting the price of many basic food and consumer items are under consideration as the interim government moves cautiously to introduce market principles into the planned economy. In his New Year's message, Premier Hans Modrow appealed for broader financial support from West Germany, but continued to resist formal unification that could subjugate his nation to its capitalist neighbor. ``The larger our economic problems, the worse the climate will be for the elections,'' Modrow warned. East Germany's Communist Party will compete with new citizens' movements and political parties in the May 6 balloting for parliamentary seats and a role in the national government. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel planned a trip to East Germany on Tuesday, his first official visit to a foreign country since being named head of state Friday. In contrast with the unbridled overnight revelry, the East German capital was nearly deserted during the short daylight on Monay that was made drearier by a snowfall scattered by sharp gusts of wind. The ADN news agency reported that 5.2 million Germans crossed the inter-German border over the holiday weekend, including 3.7 million between the two sides of divided Berlin. Crumpled paper streamers, charred sparklers and fireworks casings paved the streets and sidewalks of central East Berlin, where 500,000 had gathered the night before to ring in the new year. At least 135 people were injured and one killed during the raucous celebration when a tower of scaffolding near the Brandenburg Gate fell under the weight of revelers seeking higher vantage points from which to survey the scene along the Berlin Wall. Police from both East Berlin and West Berlin reported 77 people were taken to hospitals and dozens of others were treated at the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Parade-Goers Welcome Floats and Warm Weather
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to update with Glenn also greeted by boos, midnight babies, picking up at 3rd graf pvs. INSERTS 1 graf after 11th, `A couple...' to add detail on Glenn. ADDS 2 grafs at end with swimmers.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5, BX1, LA2, 3; LaserColor LA1
DOC.TEXT: The '90s rolled in Monday to a welcome of parades, football games, sales, skiing and, in a few cases, hangovers from the wretched excesses of New Year's Eve. Zsa Zsa Gabor, on horseback, got booed, as did Sen. John Glenn. Philadelphia's Mummers had cold feet and stayed home. The birth of twin girls ushered in the new decade in Boston at Brigham and Women's Hospital. ``The nurses told me they were born right straight up at midnight,'' hospital spokeswoman Louise Homer said Monday. Jennifer and Jessica Rios, daughters of Karen Pizarro, were in neonatal intensive care Monday and ``doing fine,'' Homer said. President Bush invited the people of the Soviet Union in a New Year's video message to ``look forward to a new century, and a new millennium, of peace, freedom and prosperity.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in his message to the United States: ``The 1990s may become a decade when freedom, democracy and equality will begin to be established on a global scale and in an increasingly irreversible way.'' An estimated 1 million people lined curbs and sidewalks in Pasadena, Calif., to watch the 101st Tournament of Roses Parade on a picture-perfect, sunny, balmy day. ``It's a real circus,'' said Ferris Reid of Aurora, Ill., of the crowds tht waited overnight. ``But I don't think I'm crazy being here all night. Being crazy was staying back in Illinois in the winter.'' ``It was 70 below zero with the wind chill when I left Iowa,'' said Elise Wise, 80, of Newton, Iowa. It was near 50 degrees at parade time. Sixty floats, 22 bands and 275 equestrians were led by grand marshal Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, the first U.S. astronaut to orbit the Earth. In addition to Mickey Mouse and Elvis _ the flowery head of the King of Rock 'n' Roll adorned Mississippi's float _ the attractions at the Rose Parade included Zsa Zsa riding her Tennessee walking horse. The appearance of the convicted police-slapper angered many spectators, who booed loudly as she rode by, some screaming, ``Go to jail, you floozy.'' ``A couple of people will hate me, but I love America. I'm proud to be an American citizen,'' she said. Occasional boos also greeted Glenn, one of five U.S. senators who received a total of $1.3 million from Charles H. Keating Jr. and met with regulators on behalf of his Lincoln Savings and Loan, whose failure is expected to cost taxpayers more than $2 billion. The Rose parade spectators also booed a brief demonstration by AIDS activists who carried a banner reading ``Emergency. Stop the parade. 70,000 Dead of AIDS.'' The group sat in the road, briefly halting the parade. In Philadelphia, the annual New Year's Day Mummers Parade was postponed until Jan. 6 because of gusting wind and a threat of snow. There was more than a threat of snow a little farther north. Revelers from Illinois, Wisconsin and Minnesota filled ski resorts on Michigan's Upper Peninsula, taking advantage of the 150-plus inches of snow that has fallen so far this season. Elsewhere in Michigan, Detroit police said many residents apparently heeded pleas to abandon the traditional midnight blast of gunfire to ring in the new year. No injuries were reported. ``It was nice and quiet,'' said Officer John Leavens. ``I don't know what it is, I'm just glad to see it.'' Traditions die harder elsewhere. In Chicago, the blare of New Year's Eve party horns and bark of champagne corks were punctuated by shots fired into the air. Police shot and killed a man shortly after midnight after he pointed a gun in their direction. ``It's like combat,'' said Capt. James Phelan. ``It really sounds like a battle zone, with shots being fired all over the place.'' In Los Angeles, gunfire could be heard from all compass points downtown after the stroke of midnight. ``We're used to it. It sounds like a shooting gallery,'' said Sgt. T. Brown. ``The dopes won't learn unless they get hit themselves.'' Falling bullets have struck dozens of people in recent years, as well as causing damage to cars and property. City police routinely ground their squadron of helicopters during the height of the shooting. And someone always has to be different. People attending one Chicago nightclub chose not recognize the birth of a new decade. Hundreds waited in lines half a block long to get into Berlin nightclub's ``Anti-New Year's'' bash. Doormen put black tape over patrons' watches and DJs played music through midnight with no acknowledgement of the New Year. And members of the L Street Brownies, a South Boston sports club, held the 86th observance of their New Year's ritual _ a dip into the frigid water of Boston Harbor. ``The yuppies go to Florida for the winter. We stay here for the crystal clear waters of Boston Harbor,'' said member Peter Jurzynski, 38. ``It's good for New Year's hangovers as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Senior Journalists Quit Jerusalem Post in Dispute With Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Senior journalists at the Jerusalem Post resigned Monday after a long-simmering dispute with the publisher. Ten editors and reporters, including the managing editor, David Landau, sent their letters of resignation to Canadian owner David Radler. Their resignations came one week after the departure of the top editor, Erwin Frenkel. Frenkel said he quit because his editorial authority had been undermined by the publisher, Yehuda Levy. The paper's editorial staff filed notice of a labor dispute Thursday, which will allow them to take action, including a strike or work slowdown, after a two-week waiting period. They are demanding Levy's removal. The Post is Israel's only English-language daily. It also publishes a weekly international edition. In their letter to Radler, the journalists said they had no choice but to resign because of ``an ever-increasing erosion of editorial independence accompanied by an assault on the editorial line which the paper has embodied since its establishment in 1932.'' Levy denied accusations by some of the paper's journalists that he is moving the Post in a right-wing direction. ``I have not tried or attempted to change the line of the paper, and I don't think I have shown any indication to do so in the future. ... So if anyone claims this is the reason for the crisis, he is lying, knowing that he is lying,'' Levy said. Levy was appointed president and publisher in July by Radler, chairman of the board of Hollinger Inc., a Canadian newspaper group. Hollinger Inc. bought a controlling interest in the Post in April. The wave of resignations began Nov. 30 with the departure of the head editor, Ari Rath, after persistent disagreements with Levy. The editorial staff wants Radler to fire Levy and ask Frenkel to withdraw his resignation once Levy is replaced.

DOC.HEAD: Two People Killed in New Year Celebrations
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Lebanese greeted the New Year on Monday in the traditional fashion of firing machine guns and tossing grenades, and police said two people were killed and 10 were wounded. Rival Shiite Moslem militias, meanwhile, battled for a 10th day for control of south Lebanon's al-Tuffah region. Police said eight people were killed and 13 wounded in the clashes Sunday and Monday. In Beirut, most of the New Year casualties occurred in the Christian sector. The victims were mostly hit by stray bullets and grenade shrapnel. Others were hurt in car crashes as panicky motorists bumped into each other as a result of the shooting. At least 40 house robberies were reported during the dusk-to-dawn celebrations and fireworks started several house fires in the Moslem and Christian sectors. Police estimated the damage at $40,000. Shooting guns, supposedly in the air, has been a common way of expressing joy and grief in Lebanon since the 1975 outbreak of the civil war between Christians and Moslems. The fighting in south Lebanon pitted fighters of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, against the pro-Syrian Amal, Arabic for hope. They used artillery and tank fire. The clashes raised the overall toll to 59 dead and 216 wounded since the fighting for control of the region erupted Dec. 23. The two factions have been vying for mastery of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect, for more than two years. By police count, the overall toll in the intermittent power struggle since May 1987 stands at 630 killed and 1,795 wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Denounces Communist Legacy, Invites Pope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf with 1 graf to UPDATE with announcement of amnesty, details.
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel on Monday denounced the grim economic and ecological wounds left by 41 years of Communist rule and pledged to lead his country to free elections. In a televised New Year's speech, the new non-Communist leader said he wanted the Dalai Lama and Pope John Paul II to visit Czechoslovakia and called for full diplomatic ties with the Vatican and Israel. He also declared a broad amnesty and reduced sentences for all inmates except those imprisoned for murder or sex crimes, or for officials who ``abused public authority.'' Also Monday, Communist Premier Marian Calfa said the government intends to adopt free-market principles and increase ties with Western Europe, the official CTK news agency reported. ``We shall consistently part with the system of management that prevailed in our country for many years. Our strategic goal is to prepare the transition to a market economy,'' CTK quoted him as saying. The speech by Havel, a playwright and human rights activist who was jailed for five years by the former hard-line Communist leadership, was the first since Parliament on Friday elected him president to culminate Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution. ``Out of gifted and sovereign people, the (Communist) regime made us little screws in a monstrously big, rattling and stinking machine. We have become morally sick,'' said Havel. ``Our country does not flourish ... we have the worst environment in Europe,'' he said. Before World War II, Czechoslovakia was an economic power in Europe, but it slid into stagnation under Communist rule. Pollution from the heavy industrial plants fostered by the Communists ravaged the environment. ``We have to accept this legacy as something we have inflicted upon ourselves,'' he said, using vivid language that contrasted with the bland style of his predecessors. Havel said ``rivers of blood'' have flowed through many East bloc countries over the past four decades, including Romania in the past two weeks, as their citizens struggled against Communism. ``These great sacrifices are a tragic backdrop of the present freedom or gradual freeing of nations of the Soviet bloc, that is a backdrop of our newly gained freedom too,'' Havel said in his 28-minute speech. He emphasized the need to bring his country to free elections and renew Czechoslovakia's prestige abroad. ``My first task is to use all my authority and influence'' so that Czechoslovakia can have ``free elections soon and in a dignified way,'' he said. Free elections for the nation's 35O-seat Parliament are tentatively scheduled for June, although no date has been announced. ``I would be happy if, even for just one day, Pope John Paul II and the Tibetan Dalai Lama visited our country, before the elections,'' Havel said. ``And if, still before the elections, we managed to establish diplomatic ties with the Vatican and Israel.'' As recently as two years ago, the Polish-born pope lamented the ``sorry state'' of the Roman Catholic church in Czechoslovakia. Five Czechoslovak dioceses lack bishops, despite two years of negotiations between the Vatican and the ousted leadership, which sought to limit the church's role in society. However, the new government has pledged religious freedom. Havel's first gesture after his selection Friday was to attend a thanksgiving Mass. About 65 percent of Czechoslovakia's 15.6 million people are Roman Catholics. The newly chosen president also said he would like to establish diplomatic ties with the Vatican and with Israel. All Warsaw Pact nations except Romania cut ties with Israel after the 1967 Middle East War. Hungary, also in the grip of democratic change, was the first to renew full ties in September, and the Soviet Union and Poland renewed low-level ties in the last three years. Last month, Poland and Czechoslovakia said full ties with the Jewish state would be renewed in 1990. ``I want to contribute to peace also by my visit tomorrow to our two related neighbors, that is the German Democratic Republic and the Federal Republic of Germany,'' Havel said. Havel travels to both German states Tuesday in his first trip abroad in two decades. The playwright, whose works were banned in his native country until recent weeks, won several international awards but declined to attend such services, fearing that Communist authorities would not allow him back to his homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Steal Cyanide, Palladium From Electronics Company
DOC.TEXT: Police issued a nationwide public health warning Monday after a supply of highly toxic gold cyanide was stolen from a vault at an electronics company. About 2.2 pounds of the lethal chemical vanished from a Philips factory in Eindhoven along with 1,320 pounds of less dangerous palladium, apparently in a pre-dawn burglary Monday, according to police spokesman Arie van der Tooren. A police announcement broadcast by Dutch Television warned that ``inexpert use'' of especially the cyanide is ``extremely harmful'' to public health. The two chemicals, which are worth at least $450,000, are used in the manufacture of electric resistors, Van der Tooren said. He speculated that the thieves may have stolen the cyanide in order to extract gold in a process that would release toxic acid.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Leaped at Princess Diana Charged With Assaulting Runner
DOC.TEXT: A man who lunged at Princess Diana eight months ago was charged Monday with indecently assaulting Britain's top woman marathon runner, police and relatives said. Veronique Marot, women's winner of the 1989 London Marathon and the British record-holder, was warming up for the Morpeth to Newcastle road race in Northumbria in northeast England when a man in a track suit bearing a runner's number suddenly approached her. ``He simply leaped out and grabbed me from the front and wouldn't let go of my arms,'' she said. ``I got a real shock. He held on tight. Then he tried to fondle me.'' Police said Monday night a man was arrested and would appear before magistrates at nearby Bedlington on Tuesday. They refused to identify him. But Hetty Adcock identified the man as her son, Ted Adcock, who lives with her. ``The police rang to tell me they'd arrested him at the race. It's all very upsetting,'' said Mrs. Adcock, 86. Adcock, 57, made headlines in April when he leaped from a crowd at Princess Diana as she was talking to members of a crowd in Northumberland. He later said he meant her no harm _ he only wanted to give her a hug. In August 1988, Adcock was ejected from the Gateshead sports stadium after embracing U.S. sprinter Florence Griffith-Joyner. He was not charged in connection with that incident or the one involving the princess. Marot, 34, shrugged off Monday's incident and went on to win the 14-mile race.

DOC.HEAD: Conditions Becoming Ripe for Direct Talks With Rebels
DOC.TEXT: African leaders trying to mediate peace talks between the Mozambican government and guerrillas say conditions are becoming ripe for direct talks, Mozambique's foreign minister said Monday. Foreign Minister Pascoal Mocumbi said on Radio Maputo that President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe had made progress in their efforts, and the Mozambican government is prepared to talk to members of the Mozambican National Resistance. Pascoal said the mediators told the Mozambican government ``that the conditions are becoming ripe for a direct dialogue'' between the Mozambican government and Renamo, the guerrilla group. The Kenyan and Zimbabwean leaders have been facilitating talks between Mozambican churchmen and guerrilla representatives. The Mozambican National Resistance began fighting the government forces in 1977. White-run Rhodesia first supported them, then South Africa. The South African government has said it no longer supports the guerrillas, but Mocumbi said ``within South Africa, some forces, even if they are not supported by the government, continue to seek to use the Renamo bandits as an instrument.'' He said there had been a reduction in the amount of aid reaching the guerrillas from across the border, but some assistance continued. The war has claimed an estimated 600,000 lives, displaced more than 1 million people and left about half the population in need of food aid.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Dead Sea Scrolls Expert Dead at Age 98
DOC.TEXT: Solomon Birnbaum, a Jewish scholar credited with establishing the authenticity and age of the Dead Sea Scrolls, has died. He was 98. Birnbaum, a native Austrian who was an expert in ancient Jewish languages, wrote two books on Hebrew and Yiddish and dozens of articles and research papers in an academic career that spanned most of this century. The scrolls, discovered in caves near the Dead Sea beginning in 1947, include the oldest known manuscripts of the Bible. Birnbaum analyzed the grammar and script to date them from the third century B.C. to A.D. 68, the same period later established by carbon-dating techniques. ``Some of his main discoveries, in academic terms, were path-breaking ... remarkable analyses of manuscript material,'' said his son Eleazar, a professor of Middle East and Islamic studies at the University of Toronto. His father's work allowed researchers to read and evaluate many documents, he said. Birnbaum was born in Vienna. The University of Hamburg, West Germany, created a teaching position for him in the field of Jewish studies in 1922. He fled to England in 1933 when Hitler came to power and taught at the University of London until his retirement in 1957. Birnbaum continued his research, and moved to Canada in 1970. He died Thursday in Toronto and funeral services were held Friday, his son said.
