DOC.HEAD: Tentative Accord Reached in Nine-Month Pittston Coal Strike
DOC.TEXT: Officials announced tentative agreement Monday to end a violence-plagued, 9-month-old strike against the Pittston Co. by 1,700 coal miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. ``We can continue to try to scratch each other's eyes out or we can accept a relationship where we can grow together,'' United Mine Workers President Richard Trumka told a news conference in the office of Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. Trumka said it is unclear when miners will return to work, but he said the agreement would be placed before the rank and file for ratification within eight to 10 days. Terms were not disclosed immediately. Both sides called it ``a victory for collective bargaining'' but said they want striking miners to hear the specifics first from union leaders. In Montgomery, Ala., President Bush issued a statement that he is ``delighted'' with the settlement. Bush, on his way back from a fishing trip, said, ``I want to wish the families and communities of the mine workers a very happy New Year as they look forward to the benefits of a new contract.'' Marathon bargaining between the UMW and the nation's largest coal exporter included a 96-hour session just before Christmas. Former Labor Secretary W.J. Usery, who served as mediator and vowed to find a solution over the holidays, termed the dispute the toughest of his career. ``At 10:30 last night we had a handshake,'' he said. The strike was marked by mammoth labor rallies, vandalism and rock-throwing confrontations between strikers and other company employees. The union is currently facing fines totaling $63.5 million for violating court orders limiting picketing and other strike activities. ``We hope that we can resolve all the outstanding litigation and charges,'' Usery said. Mrs. Dole said one of the most difficult issues was the long-term security of pension and health care benefits for miners and their families. Coal workers said the strike was prompted primarily by Pittston's move to end its contributions to the UMW's industry-wide retirement fund. Mrs. Dole promised to appoint a commission ``which will review all aspects of the pension and health care issue and make recommendations to me for dealing with it.'' She and the negotiators said the commission was prompted by the need for a broad, industry-wide means of bolstering the pension fund. She said the panel would report back to her in six months but its recommendations would not change Monday's agreement. ``The funds issue has been settled between Pittston and the United Mine Workers,'' Trumka declared. He said the provisions would stay in effect ``for the life of the agreement.'' ``I think the members will be extremely happy with the agreement that is presented to them,'' Trumka said. Usery said the negotiators ``came to what I really belive is a ... reasonable solution to both sides. It is fair. It is honorable. We hope and pray that it won't just be another Band-Aid, but it will be something permanent.'' ``We just couldn't be happier to stand before you today,'' Pittston Co. Chairman Paul Douglas said. ``We think we've met the essential objections of all those concerned.'' The strike began April 5. As the bitterness grew, 46,000 mine workers in 10 states walked off their jobs in sympathy at one point. Pittston's coal subsidiary, Pittston Coal Group Inc., had said it could not afford to continue payments into the fund, which covers 130,000 pensioners who retired between 1947 and 1976. The company, 560 of whose retirees are covered by the fund, objected to making contributions to the pensions of thousands of employees of other companies. The UMW had said that other companies would attempt to escape from the fund if Pittston were allowed to do so. Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., said in a statement, ``I'm delighted the strike has been settled. Let me say that there is no threat to the pensions of the 125,000 retirees across the country.'' Usery was named mediator by Mrs. Dole in October after she visited striking workers in the coal fields of southern Virginia. Strikers occupied a Pittston processing plant in Carbo, Va., for several days in September and mines were blocked elsewhere. More than 2,000 strikers were arrested in the first three months of the walkout, many for sit-down demonstrations and some for rock throwing. Three union officials were jailed. Wildcat strikers from other states joined bumper-to-bumper convoys to slow Pittston coal shipments. As the strike went on, Pittston hired replacement workers, but production was well below pre-strike levels. The company said its coal operations lost $3.6 million in the second quarter of 1989 and $9.8 million in the third quarter, compared with profits of $9 million and $7.4 million in the respective quarters of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Decade Opens With Peaceful Weather, After Month Of Records
DOC.TEXT: Light snow was scattered over the northeastern quarter of the nation Monday and rain and snow moved into the central Pacific Coast. The coming of the New Year ended a December that included numerous records for temperatures and precipitation, the National Weather Service said. Light snow or snow showers spread over the Great Lakes, the upper Ohio Valley and the northern Atlantic Coast region. In West Virginia, 6 inches of snow fell late Sunday into Monday morning at Valley Head. A cold front spread rain and drizzle across the central Pacific Coast and snow to some of the higher elevations of the West. Three to 6 inches of snow was possible in California's Sierra Nevada north of Yosemite National Park. A few light showers dampened the lower Rio Grande valley of Texas during the afternoon. Heavy rain fell late Sunday and into early Monday over the Southeast. Heaviest rainfall totals for the 24 hours up to 7 a.m. EST were 3.64 inches at Mary Esther, Fla.; 3.11 inches at Valparaiso, Fla.; 2.78 inches at Albany, Ga., and 2.67 inches at Dothan, Ala. Temperatures dipped into the single digits and below zero early Monday in the north-central region. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 10 degrees below zero at Warroad, Minn. Temperatures remained below freezing during the afternoon in the upper Mississippi Valley and the Great Lakes region. More than 20 cities reported their coldest December on record, using the mean temperature for the month: Akron, Ohio, 18.2; Atlantic City, N.J., 24.7; Brownsville, Texas, 51.8, second coldest month on record; Charleston, W.Va., 26.0; Cincinnati, 21.6; Concord, N.H., 11.9; Dayton, Ohio, 19.0; Elkins, W.Va., 18.4; Flint, Mich., 16.1; Harrisburg, Pa., 22.6; Hartford, Conn., 18.1; Mansfield, Ohio, 17.0; Pittsburgh, Pa., 19.4; Providence, R.I., 21.8; Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., 7.3; Scranton, Pa., 18.6; Syracuse, N.Y., 14.7; Toledo, Ohio, 16.8; Williamsport, Pa., 19.8; Wilmington, Del., 25.0; Worcester, Mass., 15.1; and Youngstown, Ohio, 18.2. In three cities, December mean reading toppled records on the books since 1876: Buffalo, N.Y., at 17.4, compared to 19.5 in 1876; Nashville, Tenn., at 29.5, compared to 30.4 in 1876; and Rochester, N.Y., at 17.1, compared to 18.5 in 1876. It was the snowiest December on record at Atlantic City, N.J., which got 9.2 inches of snow. It was the third snowiest December at Charleston, W.Va., with 14.1 inches, and at Elkins, W.Va., with 32.2 inches. While Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., was having its coldest December on record, it also had its sunniest December with sunshine 45 percent of the daylight hours. Its average for December is just 27 percent. Pocatello, Idaho, had its driest December on record with just 0.07 of an inch of precipitation. In California, both San Francisco and Sacramento tied their records for December at zero precipitation, the same as in 1876. The year 1989 was the wettest on record for Baton Rouge, La., with 88.32 inches of precipitation, and for Huntsville, Ala., which got 73.57 inches.

DOC.HEAD: Military Government Releases 36 Political Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military government said Monday that it had released 36 political prisoners. Information Minister Ali Mohamed Shummo said in a statement to the official Sudan News Agency that the 36 ``are welcome to join the march of the revolution.'' The release Sunday coincided with Sudan's 34th independence anniversary but included no prominent figures. Former Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi, head of the leading opposition party, and Ibrahim Nugud, secretary-general of the Communist Party, remain in detention. Hassan Turbabi, Secretary-General of the fundmentalist National Islamic Front, and Mohamed Osman el-Mirghani of the Democratic Unionist Party were released last year but remain under house arrest. Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, who toppled el-Mahdi's civilian government in a June 30 coup, dissolved all political parties, Parliament and other constitutional institutions and declared a state of emergency.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Parliament Gives Premier Big Vote of Confidence
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Mudar Badran won a vote of confidence in the kingdom's revitalized Parliament on Monday after telling the lawmakers he will end Jordan's 22 years of martial law within six months. Badran also promised to repeal the 1953 law banning communism, to reconsider the 1957 law banning political parties and to review the cases of political prisoners for a possible amnesty. ``The government is committed to fulfilling the constitution in its spirit and its letter and intends to abolish martial law within a period of four to six months,'' Badran said in his two-hour speech. More 1,000 people packed the public gallery and cheered as Badran spoke, and women wailed in joy in a traditiional Arabic celebration afterward. The vote followed more than two days of debate in the new, 80-member Parliament, which is determined to pry further reforms from the Cabinet. Badran was named prime minister Dec. 4. His Cabinet was appointed two days later. At King Hussein's insistence, the November elections were the freest held here since the early days of independence in the mid-1950s. Only nine deputies voted against the government on Monday, and six others abstained. Such a vote is required for all new cabinets. Badran had already removed most powers from military courts, which have considered everything from homicides to political crimes to price-gouging on vegetables since martial law was declared during the 1967 war with Israel. In that conflict, Jordan lost the West Bank, which held half the seats in the old parliament. Hussein's renunciation of sovereignty over the territory last year in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization paved the way for election of a revigorated and expanded parliament. The prime minister, at times choking with emotion, lashed back at those who alleged corruption during his earlier terms as premier in the late 1970s and early 1980s, saying, ``I am proud of my honesty and my proper dealings.'' Badran said his previous governments prosecuted hundreds of people on corruption charges. He offered to give an account of his property and finances to Parliament to answer questions raised by deputies about the source of his wealth. The prime minister said he would lift immunity from prosecution from any minister or parliamentary deputy accused of corrution. He also insisted he was proud of his past as head of the General Intelligence Department, a background that has drawn fire from some deputies. ``If you look at other countries you will see there is nothing wrong with this. Bush is a CIA man,'' he said, referring to President Bush's former post as director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Deputies later said they would keep Badran under scrutiny. ``We will not hesitate to call the premier for a vote of no confidence if Mr. Badran does not fulfill all his promises to us,'' said Nawaf Khawaldeh, an independent Islamic activist. Badran won the votes of most Islamic activists after promising to ban alcohol in all public institutions and at government parties. He did not say Monday if that ban includes flights aboard the state-owned Royal Jordanian airline, as the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood demands. He also stopped short of agreeing to the Brotherhood's demand to ban liquor sales in all public places. He said Jordan will establish an academy for Islamic law. Forty-nine deputies rose to speak during the long debate and most demanded that the government accelerate a democratic trend that Hussein launched in April after four days of rioting over price rises. The government earlier reduced the General Intelligence Department power to interfere in passport and job permits and loosened controls on the press.

DOC.HEAD: Record Jewish Immigration in 1989, 1st '90 Arrivals by Direct Flight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs with arrival of Soviet immigrants on first direct flight. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli immigration agency reported Monday that 71,509 Jews emigrated from the Soviet Union in 1989, the highest number in two decades. Of the emigrants, 11,994 have settled in Israel, the most since the early 1970s, according to figures released by the Jewish Agency, a quasi-governmental organization funded by Jews overseas that handles the newcomers in Israel. The highest monthly emigration figure last year was registered in November when 11,170 Soviet Jews have left the country, the figures showed. Of these, 1,828 came to Israel. In December 1989, 3,500 Jews came to Israel out of 8,540 who left the Soviet Union. In 1988, only 2,173 settled in Israel. In 1987, the figure was 2,069. Israeli officials predict that 30,000 to 50,000 Soviet Jews will arrive in 1990 because of liberalized emigration laws and new U.S. immigration restrictions. The first 125 Soviet immigrants this year arrived Monday on a direct flight from Moscow aboard Israel's El Al airline, making them the first Soviet Jews to immigrate directly to Israel from the Soviet Union. The immigrants had waited for 10 days to come to Israel via Romania. They received permission Sunday to join the return flight that brought Israel's Habima national theater to the Soviet Union. Israel and the Soviet Union signed an agreement last month to begin direct flights between the two countries. El Al president Rafi Har-lev greeted the 125 immigrants at the airport and said he hoped regularly scheduled flights will begin soon. As many as 300,000 Soviet immigrants are expected in Israel in the next three years. The cost of settling the immigrants is estimated at $3 billion, with U.S. and other Jews abroad expected to contribute $500 million of that.

DOC.HEAD: Police Stand Guard at NAACP New Year's Day Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``The NAACP ..., to restore full name of Hoosier United Methodist Church.
DOC.TEXT: With police standing guard outside, about 200 people attending an NAACP church program Monday offered prayer, song and humor in the face of threats issued on the heels of a recent series of mail bombs. The New Year's Day program at a southwest Atlanta church began after a search by agents from the FBI, Georgia Bureau of Investigation and Atlanta police, including bomb-sniffing dogs. No explosives were found. The annual NAACP program commemorating the Emancipation Proclamation was one of several held across the nation, but attracted special attention because Atlanta is the center of an investigation of bombings that last month killed a federal judge and an attorney. The FBI refused Monday to comment on the progress of the investigation. A letter to an Atlanta television station, disclosed last Thursday, claimed responsibility for the bombs and threatened to kill two NAACP members. Narvis Grier, the former longtime executive secretary of the Atlanta NAACP, said threats of violence always have been a part of the organization's history. ``The NAACP is the oldest, the largest, the most hated and the most respected civil rights organization,'' she told the gathering at Hoosier United Methodist Church. The Rev. Richard Wynn, pastor of Hoosier, said some people who might normally attend ``Emancipation Day'' events called him Monday morning to say they would not be coming this year because of the threats. The crowd in attendance, though wildly enthusiastic in their response to the program, did not fill the church. ``In light of what has happened, it was an appropriate turnout,'' Wynn said after the program. Killed in last month's bombings were 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance and Robert Robinson of Savannah, a black lawyer who worked with the NAACP. Two other bombs _ one to a federal courthouse in Atlanta and one to an NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla. _ were intercepted before they could explode. The Atlanta police sent four patrol cars with officers to stand guard outside the church during the 3{-hour service, which included a sermon, hymns by the Wheat Street Baptist Church Choir and speeches, most of which made reference to the bombings. Dr. Otis W. Smith, president of the Atlanta NAACP chapter, said Monday morning's search was done as a precaution rather than in response to a specific threat. ``They assured us everything was all right before we came in,'' Smith said. From the pulpit, Wynn asked for prayers for the ``sick minds and twisted spirit'' responsible for the recent violence. He and other speakers vowed there would be no intimidation. Monday's program marked the anniversary of the date in 1863 when the Emancipation Proclamation took effect. President Abraham Lincoln issued the proclamation the previous year to free slaves in states then at war with the Union.

DOC.HEAD: Papers Report Ceausescus' Last Moments Before Capture
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter pilot who whisked Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife from the roof of Commmunist Party headquarters said he had a gun pointed at his head throughout the ordeal by one of the late dictator's personal bodyguards. Romanian pilot Vasile Malutan, 46, recalled in the New Year's edition of Romania Libera how he was ordered to fly to the party's Central Committee building and pick up the Ceausescus on Dec. 22 after they were booed on a balcony by tens of thousands of people assembled below in Palace Square. ``It was an impossible mission because it isn't`normal for helicopters to fly over crowds of millionsl'' the daily quoted Malutan as saying. The paper didn't account for Malutan's exaggeration of the number of demonstrators. ``The dictator and his wife came with four people, including Maria Manescu and Emil Bobu,'' the pilot said, adding that other party leaders were left behind. Bobu was a high-ranking Politburo member. Maria Manescu was the wife of Manea Manescu, a senior party official and one of Ceausescu's closest aides. Malutan said the co-pilot had to sit on Ceausescu's knees, apparently from lack of space in the cramped cockpit, and the aircraft made for Snagov, a village north of Bucharest where the Ceausescus had a summer residence. Two security officers were also on board, Malutan told the paper. Mrs. Manescu and Bobu, reportedly the No. 3 in the party hierarchy, were asked to leave the helicopter at Snagov. ``Mrs. Manescu kissed both of Ceausecu's hands'' before getting off, the pilot was quoted as saying. Bobu was later reported arrested. Mrs. Manescu's fate is unknown. Malutan said he flew high so radar could trace the helicopter and that he had a gun aimed at him during the flight by a security guard, the daily reported. It also quoted him as saying Ceausescu ordered him not to contact ground control. From Snagov the helicopter left for a military airport in Titu, 18 miles northwest of Bucharest, after Ceausescu and his wife Elena apparently decided to flee the country. But as they approached the airport, Malutan said he told Ceausescu they possibly had been tracked by radar, according to the daily. Ceausescu, apparently fearful of falling into rebel army hands, ordered Malutan to land away from airfield, and his bodyguards hijacked a private car and its driver, the pilot was quoted as saying. The French daily Liberation quoted Nicolae Petrisor, an employee at a merchandise distribution center in Tirgoviste, west of the capital, as saying in an interview Saturday that the Ceausescus forced him to drive them around the surrounding area for hours seeking a safe hiding place. The dictator, in the front seat of Petrisor's black Dacia car, was often in tears, Petrisor was quoted as saying. The Ceausescus were finally apprehended by workers at a factory near Tirgoviste and were handed over to the army, the paper said. The Ceausescus were reported executed by firing squad three days later, on Christmas Day, following a summary trial that holiday morning.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys Two Houses, Forces Evacuation
DOC.TEXT: An intense predawn fire that began in an automobile repair shop damaged three houses, forced the evacuation of 75 to 100 people and cut power to a neighborhood Monday before it was`brought under control. Flames shot 150 feet into the air and pumper trucks had to use hydrants blocks away from the working-class neighborhood near downtown because its water mains could not carry enough water to the blaze, fire officials said. Fire Capt. Mike Vanderwall was treated at a hospital and released after he was injured in a fall while fighting the blaze, said Capt. Terry Tullier, a city fire department spokesman. No other injuries were reported. ``The fire was so intense that we had to move two of our fire engines. The fire engines were smoking from the heat and it had cracked the glass. So we evacuated houses across the street,'' Tullier said. Flames spread from the Napoleon Auto Repair and Paint Shop to gut two nearby houses. A third residence was damaged and a parked car crushed when a shop wall collapsed. The 75 to 100 evacuees were allowed back in their homes after the fire was brought under control about 7 a.m. About 120 firefighters fought the blaze, Tullier said. The cause of the fire was under investigation. Several utility poles were burned, knocking out power in the area. Natural gas service was halted because several gas meters were burned and the gas had been feeding the fire, Tullier said. Fire Chief William McCrossen said the fire damaged one-half to three-quarters of the block, which is on the eastern edge of downtown near the intersection of Elysian Fields and Claiborne avenues.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Richards Formally Files for Governor of Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT that convention was in 1988, sted last year.
DOC.TEXT: State Treasurer Ann Richards filed with the Democratic Party on Monday, making official her bid for governor and calling it ``a great way to begin the new year.'' ``I woke up this morning and had some blackeyed peas for luck, then came downtown to file. There's a certain significance to beginning the new year this way,'' Ms. Richards said. ``My resolutions are to stay cool and win the election,'' she said. Ms. Richards was keynote speaker at the 1988 Democratic National Convention in Atlanta, when she attacked Republican policies saying, ``That dog won't hunt.'' Her declaration that then-Vice President George Bush was born with a silver foot in his mouth prompted Bush to send her a silver foot pin, which she wore when the president addressed the Texas Legislature early in 1989. Her quips and one-liners set the tone for the nomination of Massachusetts Gov. Michael Duikakis as Democratic presidential nominee. She currently has her autobiography on the market nationally. She announced last June her plans to run for governor ``because I believe that it is time and because of all the things I've stood for all of my life.'' She faces a spirited battle with Attorney General Jim Mattox for the Democratic nomination, and former Gov. Mark White also is in the race. On the Republican side, where incumbent Gov. Bill Clements is not running, candidates include Railroad Commission Chairman Kent Hance, who made unsuccessful runs for the U.S. Senate in 1986 and governor in 1988; oilman Clayton Williams; Houston businessman Jack Rains; Dallas lawyer Tom Luce; and Fort Worth minister W.T. Otwell. Ms. Richards, who would be Texas' second woman governor in 55 years, said the economy, long in a downslide due to oil and real estate busts, needs new leadership. ``People are looking for leaders who hold themselves to the highest ethical standards. They're looking for leaders who have a proven track record of sound fiscal management. And I'm proud to say that's what I offer the people of Texas in 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Barge Hits Bridge, Spills Gasoline into River
LaserPhoto PG1
DOC.TEXT: A barge loaded with 100,000 gallons of gasoline hit a bridge and ruptured Monday, spilling about 10,000 gallons into the ice-choked Monongahela River. The barge was one of at least 50 to break loose from moorings along a 40-mile stretch of the river from Brownsville north to Pittsburgh. The leaking barge, owned by Gutman Oil Co. in Charleroi, broke loose about 8:30 a.m., hit the Monongahela Bridge and ruptured about 15 miles south of Pittsburgh. Emergency crews tied the barge to shore and planned to pump the gasoline into an empty tanker. Only one compartment of the barge was ruptured, so there was little danger of all 100,000 gallons spilling into the river. Meanwhile, rising water on the river from a weekend thaw forced about 200 people to temporarily evacuate their homes Monday near Maxwell, about 30 miles south of Pittsburgh. Another gasoline barge was hung up in Charleroi near Monongahela, but state environmental officials said the river was so high that crews could not get near the barge to determine if it was leaking. Local health officials and water companies were notified of the spill, estimated at 10,000 gallons, but no contamination of water supplies was reported, said Betsy Mallison, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Resources. Pittsburgh's water supply was not in danger from the spill because it draws water from the Allegheny River. Several miles south of Monday's spill, about 25 coal barges broke loose and piled up at a dam. An additional dozen barges broke loose in Pittsburgh and floated into the Ohio River. Three of those barges were stuck under a bridge in downtown Pittsburgh, forcing state Department of Transportation crews to close the span to traffic. ``We're afraid that ice and debris will pile up behind the barges, damming up the channel,'' said Dick Skrinjar, a state transportation spokesman. State police reported that a barge sank somewhere between Dunlevy, south of Charleroi, and New Eagle, just north of Monongahela, but officials had no details.

DOC.HEAD: Gweneth Feynman, Landscape Designer, Wife of Late Nobel Physicist
DOC.TEXT: Gweneth Margaret Howarth Feynman, a freelance landscape artist, world traveler and widow of Nobel Peace Prize winning physicist Richard Feynman, has died of cancer, a relative said Monday. She would have been 56 on Thursday. Mrs. Feynman died Sunday at UCLA Medical Center, said Frances Lewin, a cousin. Her final illness began while she was on a trip to Egypt. Before that trip, she had been to Antarctica and visited every continent, said Ms. Lewin. Her freelance landscaping business was an outgrowth of her enthusiastic home gardening, Ms. Lewin said. She was born in Ripponden, England, and came to the United States in 1959. She lived in Altadena for the past two decades. Her husband, a physicist who taught at Cal Tech, died in February, 1988. Mrs. Feynman is survived by a son, a daughter and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: 21 Shot, Wounded After Protesting Missing Child Case
DOC.TEXT: Police shot into a crowd of residents that stormed the police station because of officials' refusal to search for a 9-year-old girl missing on New Year's Eve and wounded 21 people, according to a radio report. Residents later found the body of the girl, who reportedly had been raped and strangled, near train tracks on the outskirts of this farming community 310 miles south of the capital Buenos Aires. None of the 21 was seriously injured, Radio Tres Arroyos said in its report. Police said they resorted to firing rubber bullets and small-caliber handguns to disperse the crowd that stormed the station. Radio Tres Arroyos said the incident began Sunday when Nair Mustafa left home in the afternoon to go to a club pool. When she did not return home, her parents checked with the club, then asked police to search. According to the mother, police refused ``because all of them were celebrating New Year's,'' Radio Tres Arroyos told listeners in this wheat belt city of 60,000. Many residents stopped their own celebrations to comb the city until the body of the child was found near the railroad tracks. According to the radio report, she had been raped and strangled. Angered, several hundred residents converged on the main police station shortly after midnight, hurling verbal abuse and setting fire to two patrol cars. Police shot and wounded five. Hours later, in full daylight, about 5,000 residents gathered outside police headquarters and city hall. During melees in which residents threw rocks on both buildings as well as a few firebombs, 16 others were shot and wounded. Police eventually dispersed the crowds with tear gas. By evening, police from nearby Bahia Blanca and Mar del Plata said calm had been restored. Miguel Mussa, director of security for Buenos Aires Province, said police at the station in question had been removed, but he did not indicate whether they had been dismissed or whether any sanctions would be applied.

DOC.HEAD: President Herzog Intervenes in Israel's Government Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with new material and editing, UPDATING with President Herzog suggests compromise, Palestinian killed. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Chaim Herzog stepped into the government crisis on Monday and suggested a compromise that may help prevent the collapse of the Cabinet coalition of the Likud and Labor parties. Both sides sought an end to the crisis set off when Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, head of Likud, fired Science Minister Ezer Weizman of the center-left Labor Party because of Weizman's supposed contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israel regards the PLO as a terrorist organization and refuses to negotiate with it. Herzog told Shamir in a private meeting that accusations of this sort called for a ``proper legal inquiry'' to examine the facts, political sources said. Israel television said Herzog suggested Weizman be allowed to remain science minister until the inquiry is completed, but Labor Party leader and Vice Premier Shimon Peres quickly rejected this, saying the damage had already been done. The presidency is a mainly ceremonial position and it is unusual for Herzog to become involved in political affairs. A spokesman at Herzog's residence said they do not publicize information from private meetings. Leaders of both sides have said they do not want to see the government fall over the issue, but Rabbi Yitzhak Peretz of the Shas party, who is trying to mediate, said he saw no way to prevent the collapse. ``It's hard to say I see a way out,'' Peretz said on Israel radio. ``Yesterday I did, now I don't. I can only say I'm sorry because the price will be paid by the Israeli people and the government.'' Collapse of the year-old government could be the final blow to Israel's peace plan, which calls for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as a step toward autonomy for the territories. The army, meanwhile, confined 1.1 million Palestinians in the occupied lands to their homes to block violence on the 25th anniversary of the founding of Fatah, the mainstream faction of PLO chief Yasser Arafat. Despite the curfew throughout the Gaza Strip and in several large towns in the West Bank, Palestinians marked the day by waving posters of Arafat, honking car horns, or flying outlawed Palestinian flags. In A-Ram six miles north of Jerusalem, Allah Bader Ez Eddin al-Hatib, 17, was fatally shot in back when troops fired to disperse about 50 masked youths holding a parade, the army said. Police used tear gas and rubber bullets to break up a stone-throwing protest by about 150 Palestinians in Shufat village, within Jerusalem's boundaries, police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. Four Palestinians were reported shot or beaten in clashes with soldiers in the Gaza Strip, Arab reporters said. Some Labor and Likud leaders were trying to work out a compromise Monday to save the coaltion, an aide to Shamir said. Like other political sources, he spoke on condition of anonymity. After Shamir announced Weizman's firing on Sunday, Labor demanded that he rescind the dismissal, which takes effect Tuesday. Shamir has been under increasing pressure from Labor party officials and from his own Likud bloc to present Weizman with the evidence against him. Justice Minister Dan Meridor, of Likud, said on Israel TV he believed Weizman would resign once the facts were presented before him. Sources in the Labor Party said their backing for Weizman could change if shown the evidence against him, Israel radio said. However, Labor leaders were reported considering joining left-wing parties in a vote of no confidence Wednesday, which could bring down the so-called unity government. It was formed a year ago after inconclusive national elections. Peretz said on Israel radio that Shamir was refusing to agree to a compromise in which Weizman would lose his post as science minister but would remain as a minister-without-portfolio in the 26-member Cabinet. Both Shamir and Peres held meetings Monday with leaders of four religious parties in hopes of persuading the small parties to join a new ruling coalition to replace the Likud-Labor government. The religious parties have 12 seats in the 120-member Parliament, giving them clout in deciding whether the 39-seat Labor or 40-seat Likud could form a narrow coalition.

DOC.HEAD: `Lady Chatterley's Lover' as Radio Bedtime Story Sparks Row
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Britons started listening to ``Lady Chatterley's Lover'' as their bedtime story Monday night, complete with sexually explicit passages and four-letter words that have outraged anti-pornography campaigners. The British Broadcasting Corp. decided to go ahead with its 15-part radio adaptation of the unexpurgated version of D.H. Lawrence's novel despite efforts by the country's leading TV watchdog, Mary Whitehouse, to keep it off the air. In addition to broadcasting the first part of Lady Chatterley's romp down the primrose path with the gameskeeper, BBC Radio 4 preceded it with a nearly 2{-hour reconstruction of the 1960 trial at which Penguin Books was charged with obscenity for publishing the sexually-explicit version. Both programs started with warnings they contained words and descriptions of sexual acts some listeners might find offensive. It took 30 years from the first printing of ``Lady Chatterley's Lover'' in Florence, Italy, to the celebrated Penguin edition of 1960 and another 30 years before that version was judged fit to be heard on radio. The uncensored version was published in the United States in 1959. The Penguin trial gave the all-clear for the book's full publication in Britain and was regarded as one of the key events that led to a more permissive attitude to sexual morality in the 1960s. The choice of the original ``Lady Chatterley's Lover'' to launch the 42nd year of BBC Radio's ``A Book at Bedtime'' was one of its most daring. In a highly unusual move, the choice was approved by the BBC Board of Governors, who don't normally get involved in such program decisions. Listeners to ``A Book at Bedtime'' have heard a wide range of titles, from the classics to popular literature. Recent titles include the James Bond thriller ``On Her Majesty's Secret Service'' and John Le Carre's ``The Russia House,'' read by the author. The BBC says an average of 250,000 listeners tune into ``A Book at Bedtime.'' The audience is predominantly middle-class and over 50. Lawrence said after he wrote ``Lady Chatterley's Lover'' that he knew it would bring ``only abuse and hatred.'' The BBC said it is expecting fresh protests. ``Of course some people are going to be offended, but there isn't much I can do about that, except not broadcast the book,'' Michael Green, Controller of Radio 4, was quoted as telling The Sunday Telegraph. ``I think it is much too important an event in English literature to go on being overlooked. As for the offending words _ well, you can hear them on television most nights,'' he was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Miners Say Picket Lines Will Remain Manned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to say walk picket lines, sted man, INSERTS 2 grafs after 12th, ``We'll be ..., to UPDATE with miner getting call from Elizabeth Dole; pickup 13th graf: `In Kentucky ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Coal Strike
DOC.TEXT: Miners striking Pittston coal operations in West Virginia will continue to walk picket lines until union members decide whether to approve a new tentative contract agreement, a union official said Monday. The United Mine Workers and The Pittston Co., parent of Pittston Coal Group, announced the tentative agreement Monday after protracted bargaining sessions in Washington, D.C., over the holidays. The violence-plagued, 9-month-old strike idled 1,700 coal miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. At one point, it sparked sympathy walkouts by 46,000 miners in nearly a dozen states. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed, with both sides saying they wanted the miners to hear details from their leaders. UMW President Richard Trumka said specifics should go to the rank and file within eight to 10 days. ``I noticed they used the term `tentative' when they announced the agreement. The miners will stay on the picket line until notified otherwise,'' said Howard Green, a UMW international board member from Charleston-based District 17. Picket lines at Pittston's Logan County mines were not manned on New Year's Day. ``As far as (Tuesday picketing) goes, we're taking it as just another day,'' said Roger Nelson, UMW member from Boone County and coordinator of Camp Solidarity II in Logan County. Miners drifted in and out of the camp Monday while word of the tentative settlement circulated. The ``camp'' was set up in a vacant department store to give miners, their families and supporters a place to congregate, sleep and eat over the holidays. Larry Ward, president of UMW District 6 covering Ohio and West Virginia's Northern Panhandle, welcomed the tentative settlement and said it was worth the sacrifice. ``It's just a matter of whether you ... fight for the people who gave us this union or just throw them away like the companies do,'' Ward said. In Virginia, striking miners said they hoped they will be back on the job soon. ``We'll be receptive to it probably,'' said Jack Bartee, a 26-year veteran of the Virginia mines and one of a handful of striking miners at the so-called Camp Solidarity in Russell County. Minutes after learning of the tentative agreement, southwestern Virginia miner Freddie Wallace got a telephone call from Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, whom he met in October during her visit to the region. ``She told me she hoped this contract would mean a happy new year and I told her it would,'' said Wallace, 47, a third-generation coal miner. In Kentucky, striking miners were happy with the tentative agreement announcement, said Bobby Roy Justice of District 30. ``Everybody's just tickled that there's a contract.'' Logan County Pittston miner Everett Street, who served on the picket lines for eight months before the union moved him to Camp Solidarity II, said the strike couldn't be over soon enough. ``I'm not real happy. If you've been out of work nine months, you can't be real happy,'' Street said. He and others said they're waiting to hear the terms of the agreement before making a judgment. Street, Nelson and Local 1971 President Dave Collins predicted some friction between other company employees and the strikers if they return to work. ``Anytime you stand in front of a Mack truck coming down on you, nudging you, it can't be peachy when you get back,'' Street said. Street was referring to attempts by Pittston coal trucks to cross picket lines to reach the company's Elkay Mining Co. at Slab Fork. Collins said miners must remember that an agreement doesn't necessarily translate into employment. ``We can't tell the company what mines have to stay open,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Canal Has Panamanian Administrator for 1st Time in 75 Years
With AM-Panama Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Panamanian became the senior administrator of the Panama Canal on Monday for the first time in its 75-year history, a move taken under the 1977 treaties that gradually turn the waterway over to Panama. Economist Fernando Manfredo, the deputy administrator of the Panama Canal Commission for 10 years, became acting administrator and moved into his new office, canal spokeswoman Willie Frye said. The post of administrator has been held by Americans. The treaties require that it be filled by a Panamanian citizen after Jan. 1, 1990. The former Panama Canal Zone, the strip of land that runs along the 50-mile-long ditch, came under Panamanian control in 1979. The treaties transfer the canal itself to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999. Manfredo, 62, was named acting administrator because the United States rejected the candidate proposed by the government of deposed Gen. Manuel Noriega to head the canal administration. The Noriega regime opposed Manfredo. The new government of President Guillermo Endara, in power for a few days, was unable to name its own candidate by Monday's deadline. Endara said Monday he will give careful thought to the nomination, which must be approved by President Bush and the U.S. Senate. Congress is in recess until Jan. 20, giving Endara at least three weeks to decide. He has said he will consider nominating Manfredo. The Canal Commission, which operates the waterway, has two new acting deputy administrators, both Americans, Ms. Frye said. Raymond Laverty, chief executive for planning, will be acting deputy administrator of operations and Joseph Ward, chief executive for administration, was named acting deputy administrator for administration. Ms. Frye said organization of the commission, a U.S. government agency, will remain the same. She said morale among operations people had been low because of harassment by the government under Noriega, but had soared following the invasion of Panama by U.S. troops on Dec. 20. The backlog of ships waiting to transit the canal has been reduced to about 80. Eighty ships cleared the canal the past two days, about the normal number.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Says Cuba Will Remain Socialist
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro said Monday that nothing would divert Cuba from socialism, indicating his government would not be swayed by the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said. ``I am sure that we have all the political and moral factors to confront any type of problem and that nothing and no one will make our nation backtrack on the road of socialism,'' the official news agency quoted Castro as saying. The Cuban president spoke in a televised New Year's message, according to the dispatch, which was monitored in Mexico. He acknowledged that Cuba is facing ``difficult times'' and praised what he called the ``exemplary conduct'' of the population in coping with economic problems. In a Dec. 7 speech during funeral ceremonies for Cubans killed in Africa, Castro said the changes in East Europe would hurt his country, an apparent reference to its isolation and the economic aid it expects to lose.

DOC.HEAD: 20 U.S. Diplomats Ordered Expelled by Nicaragua Leave for Miami
DOC.TEXT: Twenty U.S. diplomats that President Daniel Ortega ordered expelled in retaliation for the search of its ambassador's residence in Panama by American forces left Nicaragua Monday night. The diplomats refused to speak with reporters before they and their families boarded a commercial flight to Miami. Nicaragua's Sandinista government gave the Americans 72 hours to leave the country and ordered the U.S. Embassy support staff in Managua slashed from 320 employees to 100 on Friday after U.S. troops raided Ambassador Antenor Ferrey's home in Panama City. U.S. officials said the troops were searching for weapons and ``courteously withdrew'' about four hours after they arrived when they learned it was a diplomatic residence. A U.S. army colonel in charge of the operation later apologized and returned rifles that had been confiscated, Ferrey said. President Bush, in Texas on vacation, also apologized for the incident but expressed wonder at the amount of arms found inside the residence. The U.S. State Department called Nicaragua's retaliation an ``irresponsible overreaction.'' Ortega described it as ``a very moderate response.'' The departure leaves the embassy with 15 diplomats, the minimum that a host government can restrict an embassy under international agreement, and nine Marine guards. The incidents raised tension between the United States and Nicaragua less than two months before the scheduled Feb. 25 general elections. Nicaragua views the Panama invasion as proof of its assertion that the United States may invade it to oust the leftist Sandinista government.

DOC.HEAD: First US Troops Leave Panama
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts new 7th graf to update that troops arriving at Kelly Air Force Base; pick up 7th graf pvs: `Fitzwater's remarks ...'
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. combat troops left Panama on Monday, and President Bush expressed hope the rest could leave ``as soon as possible,'' the White House announced. Press secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters aboard Air Force One that the first troops to leave were two batteries of artillery, both from Fort Ord, Calif. One of the units consisted of 68 soldiers and the other of 73 GIs. ``The president is glad to see some of the troops coming home and hopes the rest can leave as soon as possible,'' Fitzwater said. Although the troops being brought home were not a large share of those troops sent to Panama, the spokesman said, ``You've got to start with one.'' He said ``we want them all to come home as soon as possible'' except for the 12,000 that are permanently assigned to Panama. Another 14,000 were sent in as part of the December invasion. Fitzwater said the remaining troops in Panama most likely would leave ``on a piecemeal basis'' but offered no time frame. The troops were coming into Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio, Texas. Fitzwater's remarks were telephoned to Washington from Air Force One while the president and First Lady Barbara Bush were en route to the nation's capital from Alabama. They stopped there for bass fishing following a six-day vacation. Bush said on Monday his New Year's resolution is, ``peace, a world at peace.'' For Mrs. Bush, it's ``no more desserts.'' But Mrs. Bush conceded her resolve might not last 24 hours. The Bushes shared their New Year's resolutions with reporters and well-wishers as they stepped from Air Force One. Mrs. Bush also voiced delight over the addition of a grandchild to the first family. ``Great news,'' she said, revealing that son Marvin and his wife Margaret had just adopted a 2-month-old boy, Charles Walker Bush. The couple also has an adopted daughter, Marshall, 3. The Bushes now have a dozen grandchildren, five boys and seven girls. ``There's something exciting, we heard about the baby the day our brother-in-law died. There's something nice about that, isn't there? Sort of magical,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters en route to Alabama from Houston. ``I cried from happiness and sadness all day.'' Alexander Ellis II, husband of Bush's sister Nancy Ellis, died last Friday of a stroke at age 67. The Bushes will attend his funeral in a Boston suburbon Tuesday. Mrs. Bush said Ellis had been ill and in much pain. ``He was a wonderful man, so wonderful that we wanted him not to live because he would have been a vegetable,'' she said. The Bushes stopped here for several hours of bass fishing with a friend, Ray Scott, founder of ``Bassmaster'' magazine, which the president has often described as his favorite. Both Bush and his wife fished, Mrs. Bush first from a porch on the water and then the two in separate boats. Bush kidded his wife when she caught a one-pound bass. ``That's a cute little one Barbara got. Nice little fellow...Nice going, wonderful darling.'' Bush himself caught at least two fish _ one about the same size as the one his wife caught and another weighing several pounds. Bush also reported he exchanged New Year's greetings with his Cabinet members and French President Francois Mitterrand. The Bushes were on their way back from a hunting, fishing and golfing vacation in Texas. On Sunday they visited two military hospitals in San Antonio where he spoke with 44 U.S. servicemen wounded in Panama. The president was returning to face the same military stalemate in Panama over the fate of deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega that existed when he began his vacation on Dec. 27. But Bush and his wife were in upbeat moods as they were welcomed in a small welcoming at this Air Force base near Montgomery. Bush, asked if he had a New Year's resolution, replied promptly: ``Peace, a world at peace.'' Mrs. Bush was just as quick with her vow of ``no more desserts.'' She said she ``always'' is combatting a weight problem and told reporters on Air Force One she made the same resolution every year _ and once again might not keep it. The Bushes said they did not stay up to welcome the New Year in. They were in bed by 9 p.m. at their Houston hotel after a Chinese dinner by candlelight. ``We were the earliest people in bed in America, I think,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``Nine o'clock, reading in bed.'' ``I haven't seen midnight for 40 years, I don't think,'' she added. Mrs. Bush said she and the president had some champagne in their suite, but didn't open it. ``I like champagne, but it doesn't like me,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Endara: Noriega Unfit for `House of God;' 1st U.S. Troops Leave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with expulsion of 20 U.S. diplomats in Nicaragua. Picks up 5th `Endara said;' ADDS three grafs with canal administrator taking office
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara said Monday that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega doesn't merit shelter ``in the house of God'' and urged the Vatican to expel the former dictator so U.S. forces could take him into custody. The White House meanwhile said the first American troops to return home since the invasion began Dec. 20 left Panama on Monday. Two artillery batteries totaling 141 soldiers from Fort Ord were en route to California, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters aboard Air Force One. ``The president is glad to see some of the troops coming home and hopes the rest can leave as soon as possible,'' Fitzwater said. Fourteen thousand troops were rushed in at President Bush's order to join 12,000 troops permanently stationed in Panama. In a related development, 20 U.S. diplomats left Nicaragua on Monday night for Miami after they were expelled by President Daniel Ortega. Ortega gave the diplomats 72 hours to leave the country in retaliation for the search Friday of its ambassador's residence in Panama City by U.S. forces. Bush apologized for the incident, but noted the troops were searching for weapons and found numerous in the residence of Ambassador Antenor Ferrey, including rifles and Uzi machine guns. U.S. officials returned the weapons after learning the home was a diplomatic residence. Endara said Panama lacked a secure enough prison to hold Noriega on criminal charges, but that he would like to see Noriega tried in Panama after the United States prosecutes the general on drug trafficking charges. ``Only after the American authorities are done ... can we have the opportunity to extradite him to Panama and make him pay in Panama for the crimes and offenses he has committed here in Panama,'' Endara said after a New Year's Day Mass. ``But for the moment we can't do it.'' Noriega greeted the New Year shuttered in the Vatican embassy compound where he sought sanctuary Dec. 24, four days after a U.S. invasion toppled his government. On Sunday night, about 200 people held a silent candlelight vigil outside the embassy, praying that Noriega would be brought to justice. In an interview, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Panama said it was up to Noriega to decide on his own to leave his Vatican asylum. ``The image of us pushing him out the door isn't what we would expect,'' said Monsignor Marcos Gregorio McGrath. ``He will have to leave by his own decision.'' McGrath said the United States could offer Noriega greater personal security and a fair trial. ``He will have to weigh his choices and come up with that which is the least disagreeable,'' McGrath said at his home. Meanwhile, the U.S. Southern Command, which oversees military operations in Central and South America, said it arrested Rodolfo ``Papito'' Chiari, a close Noriega crony who also served as his interior and justice minister, on Saturday. The military communique gave no details. The Southern Command also said 50 members of the ``Machos del Monte'' battalion of Noriega's Defense Forces surrendered Sunday near Rio Hato, 80 miles southwest of Panama City. Endara said the impasse could end if the Vatican and the papal nuncio ``say once and for all that Noriega doesn't deserve to be sheltered in the house of God, that he is a common criminal of the worst kind and should abandon the sacred place.'' He again appealed to Monsignor Sebastian Laboa, the papal nuncio, to turn over Noriega. ``I've only asked the nuncio to throw him out of the nunciature. What happens outside is another matter,'' said Endara. ``Of course I must admit that when he is outside, he will fall in the hands of the United States, not because the nuncio will give him to the United States, but because the embassy is surrounded by U.S. soldiers.'' Noriega was indicted in 1988 in Florida on drug trafficking charges. Noting that its Panama City embassy is accredited to the Panamanian government and not U.S. forces, the Vatican has not released the general, where he would be apprehended by U.S. troops that ring the embassy. The Vatican also insists that Panama has not made a formal request for custody of Noriega. But Vatican officials have indicated they are eager to see the general leave. On Sunday, Attorney General Rogelio Cruz said Panama would file murder charges against the ousted dictator in connection with the alleged execution of 10 officers who tried to oust Noriega in a botched coup Oct. 3. The filing of murder charges in Panama could give the Vatican grounds to turn him out and resolve the diplomatic stalemate. If Noriega did emerge from the embassy, McGrath said, ``Panama would not take him to avoid the question of whether to extradite or not to extradite.'' Many countries, including Panama, have laws against extraditing their own citizens abroad. American officials were considering dusting off a 1904 treaty that set forth extradition rights in the former Panama Canal Zone, a 10-mile-wide strip of territory along the canal that was U.S. territory. The zone reverted to Panama in 1979 under the 1977 Panama Canal Treaties, which call for control of the waterway to be turned over to Panama at the turn of the century. In another step in the transfer process, a Panamanian became the top administrator of the waterway on Monday for the first time in the 75-year history of the canal. Fernando Manfredo, a 62-year-old economist who has been deputy administrator of the Panama Canal Commission for 10 years, became acting administrator. Bush rejected Noriega's candidate and named Manfredo to the post well before the invasion. The Endara government, in power since Dec. 20, was not able to propose its own candidate by the Jan. 1 deadline set in the treaties.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Says 51 Percent of Soviets Prefer Capitalism
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reported Monday that more than half the Soviet citizens who responded to a recent Japanese poll said they preferred capitalism to socialism, and America ranked first among their favorite foreign nations. The poll was conducted simultaneously in the Soviet Union, the United States and Japan. It compared opinions in the three nations on a range of issues, the newspaper Mainichi Shimbun said. According to the poll, 72 percent of Americans, 60 percent of Soviet citizens and 41 percent of Japanese said they supported their government. The government in Japan imposed a new sales tax last April and was hit by bribery and sex scandals the past year. Americans also expressed the most happiness with their present lifestyles, with 92 percent saying they were satisfied, compared with 73 percent of Japanese and 26 percent of Soviets, the newspaper said. The Soviets were asked if they believed capitalism or socialism was superior. Fifty-one percent picked capitalism, 32 percent said socialism and 17 percent said they didn't know, Mainichi Shimbun reported. People polled in each nation were asked their favorite and least-favorite foreign countries. The most popular nation in Japan was the United States, favored by 30 percent of respondents, followed by Switzerland, with 10 percent, and Australia, with 8 percent. The Soviet Union ranked 10th, with less than 1 percent of positive replies. Among Soviet respondents, the United States also placed first, with 32 percent, followed by Japan with 10.9 percent and Israel with 10.3 percent. The most popular Communist nation, China, ranked 10th with 2 percent. Eighteen percent of Americans picked Canada as their favorite foreign country. Next was Britain with 15 percent, with Japan a distant third at 2 percent. The Soviet Union was the least-favorite nation of the Japanese respondents, with 25 percent of the negative replies, while the United States tied for third place with 4 percent. Afghanistan, where the Soviet Union stationed troops for 10 years, ranked as the Soviets' most disliked nation with 9.5 percent, while the largest number of Americans _ 16 percent _ picked the Soviet Union. Would nuclear war occur in their lifetime? Ten percent of the Japanese polled thought it would; 14 percent in the United States, and 16 percent in the Soviet Union, the newspaper said. The survey was conducted by telephone from Nov. 28 to Dec. 12 and included 4,001 Japanese, 3,015 Americans and 2,970 Soviets selected randomly, the newspaper said. NTT Telemarketing Co. conducted the polls in the United States and Japan, and those questioned were 20 years or older. The Soviet Sociology Academy's survey center conducted the survey in the Soviet Union, including both Communist Party and non-party members who were at least 18 years old. The newspaper provide no margin of error.

DOC.HEAD: Four Die in Canadian Nursing Home Fire
DOC.TEXT: An early morning fire killed four people Monday in a nursing home in Gloucester, just south of Ottawa, fire officials said. They said eight other residents of the building's south wing were rescued, and six of those were taken to a hospital. The officials said the fire began in or near a utility closet and damage was confined to a hallway. They did not list a cause for the blaze.

DOC.HEAD: Throwing Garbage Out Window Now Passe in Hailing New Year in Italy
DOC.TEXT: To the relief of streetsweepers, Rome residents showed again on New Year they have all but given up the custom of breaking old furniture and hurling the debris, along with the garbage, out windows and off balconies. The custom signified throwing out old problems in hopes of better times. One tradition that remained was diving off Cavour Bridge for a New Year's Day swim and three Roman men braved the chilly Tiber to do just that. Temperatures dipped to 25 degrees overnight, a relief to thousands of Roman women who parade in their furs on holiday afternoons whether it's cold or not. Southern Italian cities kept the dubious distinction of most fireworks injuries in New Year's festivities that stretched into Monday morning. Two people were killed and 779 were reported injured in accidents blamed on fireworks or firing off pistols in New Year's Eve celebrations, police said. A 47-year-old man in a small town in Puglia, the heel of boot-shaped Italy, was killed when a bullet fired in the street struck him in the shoulder blade, the Italian news agency AGI reported. The man was inside a house, toasting the New Year with friends, when hit. An 11-year-old boy playing with fireworks on the beach of Ischia, an island off Naples, died Monday of wounds suffered when the device went off in his hands. New Year's Eve celebrants playing bridge at a club in Messina, Sicily, were robbed of cash, furs and jewelry worth $180,000 by five masked bandits armed with pistols and shotguns, AGI quoted police as reporting.

DOC.HEAD: Convertible Dinar Introduced
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia introduced a new dinar Monday freely convertible to Western currencies and worth 10,000 old dinars, the state Tanjug news agency reported. The new dinar was fixed at seven to one West German mark, and its introduction is part of government attempts to battle inflation that exceeded 2,600 percent last year, said Tanjug. A mark is worth about 84 cents. Tanjug said a government austerity program also includes a wage freeze and liberalization of most prices still under subsidy over the next six months. Unemployment here in 1989 was at 17 percent, and the foreign debt is at $17 billion in this nonaligned communist country. The living standard has been in steep decline since 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Abolishes Death Penalty, Secret Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 3 grafs SUB for 5th graf, `In Iliescu's ... UPDATING with Bogdan's death. Picks up 6th, `The Ceausescus ... with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: The new government Monday abolished the death penalty and the hated secret police, as Romanians celebrated their first non-Communist New Year's Day in more than four decades. Interim President Ion Iliescu promised political pluralism and a shorter workweek, re-established private ownership of land and suspended wasteful construction projects in progress under toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Romanian Radio reported no incidents of sniper fire or clashes between the army and die-hard secret police loyal to Ceausescu, indicating a return to peace following two weeks of unrest that claimed thousands of lives. People dressed in black lighted candles in central Romana Square for their relatives and friends who died in the revolution. Another death in Bucharest was that Monday of Deputy Foreign Minister Cornelieu Bogdan, 68, who was ambassador to the United States under the communist regime, relatives in Washington reported. They said he had a history of heart trouble and was believed to have died of an aneurysm at work. Just Sunday, Bogdan told reporters in Bucharest, ``The Communist Party is dead'' and no danger existed of Communists returning to undisputed power here. In a New Year's address carried by the official news agency Agerpres, Iliescu announced the end to capital punishment, saying Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, ``were the last persons who deserved this fate.'' The Ceausescus were found guilty of ``genocide'' during their 24-year rule, and were executed on Dec. 25. Iliescu also re-established the right to own private property, with farmers again permitted to own about an acre of land surrounding their houses. He said farmers could lease more land, with its yield also sold on the private market. In the past, the state was the only buyer. He said the workweek would be reduced from six days to five, and he reiterated the government's commitment to introducing multiparty democracy after more than four decades of Communist rule. Iliescu's interim governing council of the National Salvation Front also signed a decree Monday guaranteeing the right to repatriation of Romanian citizens living abroad, Agerpres reported. The news agency said the decree gave former exiles priority in buying housing with hard currency and allowed them to bring home goods bought abroad without paying duty. Iliescu also formally announced the abolition of Securitate, the secret police, Romanian radio reported. Hundreds of armed special police were still believed at large Monday, despite orders last week by the provisional government to surrender themselves and their weapons. Prime Minister Petre Roman, in an interview broadcast Monday on Romanian television, said the government's priorities before planned elections in April were ``liberalization and changing laws.'' Roman also dismissed suggestions by FR3, a French television station, that the revolution had been planned by leading dissidents. He said the uprising ``was a spontaneous movement and a popular mass movement against the dictatorship.'' The announced dismantling of Securitate was preceded by the detention of the agency's former head, Gen. Iulian Vlad, along with three ranking members of the ministry controlling the police, Agerpres reported. It did not specify what charges, if any, the four face. Maj Ihai Lupoi, the new minister of tourism, told a news conference, ``In the first days, General Vlad worked with the revolution. After four or five days he was arrested for reasons I don't know.'' Lupoi also said Ceausescu's villa and its secret tunnels might be opened to tourists. The death toll from the revolution's two turbulent weeks remains uncertain. One Western diplomat said he had information that indicated about 7,000 people had died. ``Our best estimate is nowhere near what the government says,'' he said. Estimates at one point reached as high as 80,000. At least six new political parties have emerged since Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22 by a nation outraged over the massacre by security forces of hundreds of people in the western city of Timisoara participating in an anti-Ceausescu protest. Iliescu is a former Communist Party secretary who fell out of favor with Ceausescu for speaking his mind but has the political experience that dissident intellectuals and other former opposition figures lack. His address comes ahead of the expected arrival in Bucharest Thursday of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. A Western diplomat said Iliescu might discuss with Shevardnadze the possiblity of allowing free travel across the Soviet-Romanian border in Moldavia, a territory partly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Iliescu also made available public agricultural production figures according to which the year's cereal production amounted to 16.9 million tons, instead of 60 million tons claimed by Ceausescu. Other totals also were well below claimed amounts. To pay off the country's foreign debt, Ceausescu had in recent years exported Romania's best agricultural products while forcing rationing upon his people. The new government is now opening warehouses and making those items available to Romanians.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Announces Measures to Cut Inflation, Head Off Social Unrest
DOC.TEXT: The government, faced with economic chaos and possible social unrest, Monday night announced measures intended to prop up the national currency, reduce high interest rates and stabilize real wages. In a nationwide address broadcast, Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez said the amount of australs _ the national currency _ in circulation would be limited in the hopes of preventing Argentines from buying U.S. dollars and further diluting the austral's value. Investors whose certificates of deposit come due beginning Wednesday _ Tuesday is a bank holiday _ will be paid up to 1 million australs ($500) in cash and will have to accept long-term bonds for the balance, Gonzalez said. Also, the Central Bank will print only enough australs to cover government salaries, pensions and normal business expenses, he said. ``The price of the dollar should go down,'' Gonzalez said. ``The reason for this affirmation is very simple: there are going to be very few australs in circulation.'' Last Thursday, the final business day of 1989, the austral slid to 1,950 to the dollar, indicating a lack of public confidence in the government's latest economic program. In February the rate was 17-1, and 1,000-1 last month. As banks struggled to retain funds, interest rates rose to 600 percent a month. Stores, anticipating inflation, marked up prices drastically or closed in the face of panic buying by shoppers trying to stock up on goods they feared they later would not be able to afford. On Saturday, the head of the armed forces, Gen. Isidro Caceres, warned that the economic problems could result in ``states of anarchy.'' However, he publicly endorsed President Carlos Menem, in office since July. On Monday, also a national holiday, the director of an influential group of small businessmen said they might not open their 1 million stores nationwide on Tuesday. Juan Carlos Lightowler Stahlberg, director of the Board of Merchant Business Activities, said before Gonzalez' address, ``Unfortunately ... every operation in cash (now) is done at a loss'' because inflation makes it impossible to estimate prices to charge enough to be able to restock. The latest plunge in value of the austral, which contributed to the resignations of one economy minister and two Central Bank presidents, is ``totally unjustified and the result of collective hysteria,'' Gonzalez said. However, exchange and interest rates will continue to be set by market forces, he said. Wages and prices also will be set by market forces and not by government guidelines ``because we are convinced that controls don't work in any country in the world.'' The economy minister denied the U.S. dollar would be used as a type of alternate currency, as local newspapers and analysts predicted. With inflation estimated at 50 percent for December and 5,000 percent for 1989, Gonzalez admitted the economy ``every day is more `dollarized''' in terms`of prices. Real wages have contracted by about 60 percent this year, and he said savings in australs have been ``pulverized'' by devaluations totaling 99 percent since February.

DOC.HEAD: Socialism a Goal for Vietnam in 1990
DOC.TEXT: Unlike his onetime East European partners in the Soviet bloc who plan democratic reforms in 1990, Vietnam's Communist Party leader Nguyen Van Linh cited ``building socialism'' as a New Year's resolution. In a New Year's message carried by Voice of Vietnam radio, he urged Vietnamese to follow the example of Ho Chi Minh, the late revolutionary leader whose 100th birthday will be celebrated in 1990. ``This is the best way for every one of us to rise up to the level of the task entrusted by history to our entire party and people _ to build a socialist society with its objective and motive being of the people, by the people, and for the people,'' Linh said. Linh has introduced some economic reforms and a degree of political liberalization since late 1986, but Hanoi's leaders have refused to consider a multiparty system. Remaining economic problems in Vietnam include unemployment, poor management skills and an outdated infrastructure. Linh urged all citizens and party members to ``conduct themselves in an exemplary fashion in study and action in keeping with Uncle Ho's thoughts, virtues, and work style.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede WASHINGTON
First Unwounded American Troops Leave Panama, Arrive in Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with details of arrival; pickup 5th graf pvs: `Fitzwater said ...
DOC.TEXT: The first uninjured American combat troops to leave Panama arrived Monday at Kelly Air Force Base here for a layover before returning to their home base at Fort Ord in California. Kelly spokeswoman Phoebe Brown said 56 soldiers arrived on a C-141 transport and were scheduled to leave for Monterrey, Calif., at 5 a.m. Tuesday. Pentagon spokesman Maj. David Super said the troops were from the 7th Infantry Division at Fort Ord. He said a second plane carrying troops was due in at Kelley, but he was uncertain when. Ms. Brown said she did not know anything about a second plane of returning troops flying to the base. ``Their military mission is finished. It's just a continued tailoring of the military force in Panama as the need for combat troops is diminished,'' Super said. ``The growing mission down there now is for nation-building and civil affairs.'' President Bush on Monday expressed hope that the remaining U.S. soldiers in Panama could leave ``as soon as possible,'' the White House said. Earlier, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater`told reporters that the returning units consisted of 68 soldiers and the other of 73 GIs. ``The president is glad to see some of the troops coming home and hopes the rest can leave as soon as possible,'' Fitzwater said. He said ``we want them all to come home as soon as possible'' except for the 12,000 that are permanently assigned to Panama. An additional 14,000 were sent in as part of the December invasion. Fitzwater said the remaining troops in Panama most likely would leave ``on a piecemeal basis'' but offered no time frame. Fitzwater's remarks were telephoned to Washington from Air Force One while the president and First Lady Barbara Bush were en route to the nation's capital from Alabama. They stopped there for bass fishing following a six-day vacation.
